Regina, January 23, 1950.

B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

On October 25th, 1949, a letter from this Office, file 2516-6-1-107 (656) was forwarded to the Department with enclosures from Superintendent Jones and the M & K Plumbing and Heating Company, regarding a heating plant for building No. 34 at the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School, Prince Albert.

In the last paragraph of my letter I asked if funds could be made available to have this work done this fiscal year and I have not as yet had a reply. Could I please be advise if there is any possibility of having this work completed before March 31st, as time is getting short. Requisitions would have to be prepared and sent forward immediately to have necessary purchases made and the work completed.

If this is not possible I would like to be assured that a sufficient amount is included in the 1950-51 Estimates, to have the work done before next winter and paid for from the 1950-51 appropriation.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
February 13th, 1950.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

This school is being operated under the auspices of the Church of England, in the former military camp at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. In view of the failure of water at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, it has been found necessary to close this school temporarily and transfer twenty-nine children to the Lac la Ronge Residential School. In addition, Regional Supervisor J.P.B. Ostrander has reported that there are still a number of Church of England children who require institutional care.

In view of the above, it is necessary to provide additional accommodation, and Regional Supervisor Ostrander reports that if we renovate Army Building No. 20, part of it can be used for a dormitory, part for a manual training shop, and the remainder for a room for physical training purposes.

Mr. D.M. Morrison, Supervisor of Construction, from Mr. Ostrander's office, recently inspected this building and states that the following work is necessary: Build partitions; supply and install blackboards; supply and install partitions and doors for all toilets, including necessary hardware; redecorate and paint entire building throughout; repair roof on the entire building; transfer heating from existing locations and install same according to Provincial and Dominion Building Codes; install new electric wiring; renew and repair all defective plumbing; supply and install battleship linoleum in the dormitory.

The Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, who are presently completing a contract for us.
on another building in this camp, and whose work has always been satisfactory, have forwarded a tender in an amount of $13,131.60, for the work which the Supervisor of Construction, Mr. Morrison, considers necessary. The price mentioned may be reduced if some material salvaged from other army buildings, can be used to advantage.

The company mentioned is prepared to carry out the work before the end of the current fiscal year, and as funds for the improvements are available in the 1949-50 Appropriation, I recommend that an Order in Council be obtained accepting the Harvey Lunam Construction Company tender. A Memorandum to Council is enclosed.

PP/ST Enc.

Director,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6317, file 656-5, part II)
File 656-5 (E1)
Ottawa, February 13th, 1950.

PRIVY COUNCIL

Requesting authority for acceptance of the tender of Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount of $13,131.60, to carry out work of renovating Building No. 20, Prince Albert Military Camp, to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

Two extra copies of Order in Council are required.
February 13, 1950.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, for renovating Building No. 20 in the Prince Albert Military Camp, to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School;

THAT efforts have been made by Departmental Officials to obtain competitive tenders for the carrying out of the work required, and it has only been found possible to secure a tender from Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount not exceeding $13,131.60;

THAT the Harvey Lunam Construction Company has carried out other work for this Branch in an efficient manner;

THAT it is considered that the renovation of this building is necessary for the welfare of the pupils.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, to carry out the work required in an amount not exceeding $13,131.60.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

PP/ST

Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Regina, February 10th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 8th instant,
File 656-1 (E), in connection with the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

Since Major Clark's visit, and report dated February 4th, I have succeeded in getting the other information necessary for submission, and I am enclosing herewith the following: copy of report of Mr. D.N. Morrison, Supervisor of Construction, on Building No. 20; quotation of the Harvey Lunam Construction Company on the total cost of erecting partitions and general repairs to Hut No. 20 to prepare it for a dormitory, a manual training shop, and a separate room for physical training, at a total cost of $13,131.60 if AA Battleship Linoleum is laid in the dormitory, and $12,427.60 if no linoleum is used; and quotation of the M & K Plumbing and Heating Company, of Prince Albert. It will be noted from the quotation of the M & K Plumbing and Heating Company it is expected that a considerable quantity of material can be salvaged from other buildings to reduce the amount of $4,892.40 for the heating and plumbing part of the tender by Harvey Lunam. I may say in this connection that the Harvey Lunam tender includes the $4,892.40 quoted by the M & K Plumbing and Heating Company.

After discussion with Major Clark and Mr. D.N. Morrison it was decided to send Mr. Morrison to Prince Albert to go with Indian Superintendent Jones to the school to examine various matters and, particularly Building No. 20, as it was hoped that the necessary expenditure for Building No. 20 can be dealt with before the 31st of March. Everything mentioned in Mr. Lunam's quotation, and Mr. Morrison's report agree with Major Clark's suggestions, but, unfortunately I have not a copy of the rough plan which Major Clark prepared, as I gave my copy to Mr. Morrison and he left it with Mr. Jones. I am hoping that when this letter arrives in Ottawa Major Clark will still be in the Ottawa office in order that this may be referred to him for agreement as to detail.

If it is necessary to get other quotations on this work it will then...
work it will then be necessary to have an architect put on
the job, and a proper blueprint and specifications prepared.
That, of course, will take so long that it will not be possible
to get the work done out of the current year's appropriation,
therefore I sincerely hope that the Department can accept this
present tender as fair, and can trust the Harvey Lunam Construction
Company to complete the job satisfactorily at or before the
31st of March. I have every confidence in the Harvey Lunam
Construction Company, and I also have the services of Mr. D.N.
Morrison, who can be in close touch with all of the work while it
is progressing, and see that it is carried out according to
intentions.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian agencies,
Saskatchewan.

JPBO/ed
Encl.
Regina, February 2nd, 1950.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Indian Affairs Branch,
304 Post Office Building,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

Re: LAC LA RONCE Indian Residential School
Building 20

I inspected this building with a representative of
The Harvey Lunam Construction Company on February 1st and 2nd, 1950.
We found the plumbing and heating system nearly all disconnected
and many parts have been removed from this building. The Viking
boiler which originally heated this building is partly stripped. The
Lunam Construction Company have submitted their tender for the sum
of $13,131.60 for complete repair of this building. This tender
includes:

Plumbing - the toilets in this hut need new flush valves,
ball valves, and seats. The showers will require new
controls and heads. Some pipes will need renewing and
repairs are required to some of the spring taps. Mr. C.A.F.
Clark recommended installation of bath tubs. These have
been omitted owing to the added cost of breaking the floor
and installing new drains, also in view of the fact that
they are considered impractical by the Principal of the
school.

Lighting - some wiring is to be done in conduit, with 17
lights in the east wing; 1 light in the furnace room; 2
lights in the Wash Room; 2 lights in the shower and toilet;
and 21 lights in the west wing, and switches to control these
lights, all wiring to pass inspection.

All doors and windows are to be repaired and fitted,
and the floor of the manual training room is to be prepared and
covered with battleship linoleum. The radiators and windows of the
playroom are to be covered with heavy screening, and the interior
of the building redecorated. I feel, however, that before any extensive
interior decorating is done, the leaky roof will have to be repaired. This is not included in the tender. I would suggest cedar shingles for the purpose, as these buildings are only on cement footings, and there is considerable movement of the buildings due to frost and numerous other conditions. The sides of the building also should be recovered. I would suggest cedar lap, or drop siding for this purpose, and paint for this purpose, for the same reason. This, also, is not included in the estimates.

This building was formerly heated by a Viking boiler which is partly stripped. The caretaker assures me we can find, from various sources, sufficient parts, etc. to complete it. There is also part of a pump, with no motor, or impeller. The caretaker also assures me that he can find a motor and impeller, but this is problematic. If this old equipment can be used, the Lunam Construction Company's quotation will be reduced by $1,991.40.

D.N. Morrison,
Supervisor of Construction.
Dear Sir:

Re: Army Hut No. 20, for Department of Indian Affairs, Canada, Prince Albert, Sask.

We wish to confirm that our tender for work at the above building, Prince Albert, Sask., is figured on the following specification:

The Contractor is to install heavy wire mesh screens to protect the windows in physical training room. Also supply and install heavy wire mesh screens to protect all radiators, pipes, electric lights, etc., in same room.

All windows throughout the building to be refitted or replaced where necessary and all windows to be fitted with weatherstrip satisfactory to the Superintendent of Indian Agency. Reglaze and replace broken glass where necessary on all windows in this building.

Supply all labour, material, etc., for building all partitions as outlined on plan, including all necessary hardware for doors, etc., to the entire satisfaction of Superintendent of Indian Agency.

Supply and Install Blackboards in selected locations.

Supply and Install Partitions and Doors for all toilets, including all necessary hardware, etc.

Redecorate and Paint entire building throughout.

Thoroughly repair roof of entire building.

All heating to be transferred from existing locations and to be placed on outside walls and to be installed according to Provincial and Dominion Building Codes. Four Fans to be installed behind radiators in order to circulate the heated air.

New Electric wiring to be installed according to Provincial and Federal building codes.

All Defective Plumbing to be renewed, or repaired where necessary.

The Purpose of these alterations and renovations, etc., is to make this building into a Dormitory as outlined, also Manuel Training Shop as well as a Physical Training separate room.

The Contractor is to thoroughly inspect all Plumbing, Heating, Electrical Work and all other work which may require repairing or replacing to give an entirely satisfactory job when the contract is completed, as no extras will be tolerated. The Contractor is to supply all permits inspection fees, etc., as well as all other charges for a complete and thoroughly satisfactory job.

The entire Price of this work as outlined and including the Supplying and Installing of AA Battleship Linoleum in Dormitory, is Thirteen Thousand One Hundred and Thirty One Dollars & 60/XX Dollars ($13,131.60). Should Linoleum be omitted our price will be reduced to ($12,427.60) Twelve Thousand Four Hundred and Twenty Seven & 60/XX Dollars. Yours very truly

Manager
M. & K. Plumbing and Heating Co.
H. P. MASCHO AND W. J. KERNAGHAN, Props.
All Kinds of Repair Work Estimates Furnished on Request
TELEPHONE 2527
15 RIVER STREET, W.
PRINCE ALBERT, SASK.

February 2, 1950

Debt. of Mines & Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Sirs:

Re Hut 20, we beg to quote as follows:

Heating, using a new Viking Boiler, No. 28-7-W, a new Armstrong Circulating pump, seventeen hundred and fifteen square feet of five column radiation, together with piping, valves, and fittings, a three foot by seven foot storage tank, with a three hundred gallon water heater, at a total cost of four thousand eight hundred and ninety two dollars and forty cents ($4,892.40).

In this building, there is at present, a Viking boiler, partly stripped, but the caretaker assures me he can find in various sources sufficient parts, etc., to complete it. The cost of this boiler is seven hundred and sixty six dollars and forty cents ($766.40). The cost of the jacket heater is one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00), the tank, one hundred and eighty dollars ($180.00), eight hundred and forty square feet of radiation, eight hundred and forty dollars, some piping and fittings to the value of fifty five dollars ($55.00), or a total of nineteen hundred and ninety one dollars and forty cents ($1,991.40). There is also a part of a pump with no motor or impeller. The caretaker also assures me he can find the motor and impeller, but this is problematical.

What we propose is this: We are quoting four thousand eight hundred and ninety two dollars and forty cents, but any of the above material that can be used would reduce this quotation in the amount of the value of the goods you supply.

Plumbing: The toilets in this hut will need new flush valves, ball valves, and seats. The showers will require new controls and heads. There will be some piping needing renewing, and repairs to some of the spring taps. We would quote a price of four hundred and ninety one dollars to refurbish the plumbing ($491.00).

We trust this will be satisfactory, but should any further information be required, we will be glad to supply it.

Yours very truly,
M & K PLUMBING & HEATING CO.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

With reference to Department letter of the 11th instant,
File 656-6 (El), regarding renovations to Buildings Nos. 2 and
22, I have talked to Mr. Lunam within the last few days about
rushing this work for completion before the end of the fiscal
year, and he assures me that it will be done. The work had to
stop because the weather was so extremely cold that men could not
work. The temperature was from 35 to 55 degrees below zero for
weeks.

Incidentally, Mr. Lunam will be in Ottawa the latter
part of this week, and is to call at the office of the Super-
intendent of Indian Education.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Colonel B. F. Neary,
Dept. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Additional Equipment for
Lac la Ronge School, Prince Albert.

Following our conversation in your office this morning, the following rush wire was sent to the Principal of the above school:

"Following discussion with Colonel Neary request you submit immediately to Superintendent Jones requisition for sufficient additional kitchen utensils, dishes, beds, bedding, furniture, etc., to provide for a total of two hundred sixty pupils plus staff as per formula referred to in paragraph three Manual of Procedure Stop Please treat as urgent because Indian Affairs want requisition earliest possible date."

The "Formula" to which reference is made is that issued by the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, under File 150-97 dated 21st June, 1948.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Supt. of Indian Education,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Regina, February 3, 1950.

J.F.S. Ostrander, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The present laundry is located in the transverse bar of N-hut No. 35. The equipment includes four ironing boards, one circular tub, one extractor, one drier, and electric iron. I am informed that this equipment is not sufficient to handle the laundry for this organization.

The present laundry room is 35 feet in length and 24 feet in width, and it would be impractical to install new equipment in this room.

The sewing room, linen room, and storage rooms are located in the west end of a lean-to on the south side of the drill hall, building 27. It is therefore necessary to carry the laundry from building 35 to building 27 which is a considerable distance.

In addition to this inconvenience, the water is piped into this building at the east end and a small stove has to be kept burning at all times to keep these lines from freezing. This creates an additional fire hazard, as there is no brick chimney for this stove. And with the transverse bar of this hut in use as a laundry it renders the adjacent wings practically useless for all practical purposes.

If the laundry is moved to the lean-to in building 27, by removing a temporary partition installed by C.W.T.S., and the sealing of double doors a building 65 feet by 86 feet should be obtained for the laundry, without altering the present sewing, linen and storage rooms. This portion of the building is now being used for manual training classes, and a storage for two staff members' cars. It will be vacated on completion of the new manual training room in building No. 20. I am informed this building is easily heated and will be large enough for additional equipment required.

I have also been informed, the former principal of the school, Mr. Fisher, wanted the laundry to be put in building 35. I interviewed Mr. Scrase, the present Principal, and he would like this change made.

The Department of Indian Affairs feel that owing to the fact that the laundry was put in building 35 at the request of the former Principal, the expense of moving this equipment should be paid for by the school. This difference will have to be settled between the school authorities and the Department.

D.H. Morrison,
Supervisor of Constructional

J.P.B. Ostrander, Esq.,

REGINA,
Saskatchewan.

Re: Old Laundry Equipment at Lac La Ronge
Indian Residential School.

I inspected the old laundry equipment at the Lac La Ronge
Indian Residential School, consisting of three pieces, which include:
one Extractor, serial No. SS10-M7107; one Drier, serial No. 22730-M787;
and one Tub, serial No. 1215-M7249. All of the above mentioned
machines are manufactured by the Canadian Laundry Company Limited.

The Extractor appears to be in very good condition and is
ready for use. The Drier appears to be in good condition, but has
been used on a low pressure system, as it is equipped with a low pressure
trap. I have been unable to ascertain the reason for this, but it is
possible it is some defect in the coil and it will not stand high
pressure. The tub is in very poor condition. The revolving part which
is wooden is warped, shrunk and rotted in several places. I am advised
by Mr. Paul Mascho, of the M & K Heating and Plumbing Company that it
is beyond economic repair. The line shaft pulleys and mounting brackets
for this equipment are all in good condition. All machines are equipped
with driving points.

To use the drier and extractor in the laundry, at this school,
it will necessary to equip them with individual driving motors. It
appears that the drier has been used on a low pressure system, and in
view of the high pressure system (80 pounds) in this laundry, I would
deem it advisable to install this equipment in one of the schools where
a line shaft and low pressure could be used, and new equipment be purchased
for Lac La Ronge, if and when the laundry is moved to larger quarters.

D.M. Morrison,
Supervisor of Construction.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Regina, February 2nd, 1950.

J.P.B. Ostrander, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Indian Affairs Branch,
304 Post Office Building,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

General Inspection Report on the
LAC LA RONDE Indian Residential School

Sanitation
Garbage in the kitchen has been allowed to accumulate for several days. I am informed that the City of Prince Albert move this garbage, but have not been picking it up as regularly as they should. I asked Mr. Serase to dispose of the refuse daily, as I feel he has sufficient staff to perform this extra duty. This matter will be referred to Dr. A.B. Simes, Regional Medical Superintendent, Indian Health Services, Department of National Health and Welfare, with regard to disposal and type of containers for garbage to be used in the kitchen.

Fire Equipment
There is not sufficient fire fighting equipment at this school. I have been informed by Mr. E.S. Jones that a number of hand extinguishers recommended by the City Fire Inspector have been ordered.

Fire Hazards
There are no chimneys for heating stoves in Buildings 33 and 34. There are no receptacles for ashes from furnaces and stoves. These ashes are piled on the ground, in the open, and the wind can blow these hot ashes among much inflammable material. Some of the buildings have been used for storage, and are badly neglected. This not only creates a bad impression and criticism, but is an additional fire hazard.

General Condition of the Grounds
The grounds generally appear neglected. I have asked Mr. Serase to have them cleared. He has promised his co-operation.

D.N. Morrison,
Supervisor of Construction.

This building is the same type as the other buildings, and is very easily heated with a heating system of the same capacity as the other buildings. REPORT ON LAC LA RONDE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Building 30 (Boys' Dormitory)

A room 30' in length and 26' in width, located in the west end of the north wing of this building was formerly used as a boys' playroom.

The beaver board lining of this room was not on a solid wall, therefore it was completely ruined by the boys while playing. This room is now being used as a boys' dormitory and should be completely re-lined.

REPORT ON LAC LA RONGE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Building 3A (Mess Hall).

This building is an "H" type army hut, of which one side, and the transverse bar of the "H" are being used. This wing is divided into two portions, one 100' x 26', which is used for students, and one 26' x 20' which is used for the staff. The students' mess is heated by two small heating stoves, and the staff mess by one of the same.

There are no brick chimneys in this section of the building, and the Klondike chimney is being used. This condition is viewed with much concern by the City Fire Inspector.

I would recommend the above condition be rectified at once, as serious fire is apt to result if it is allowed to exist.

May I say I am in complete agreement of plans outlined by Mr. E.S. Jones for remodelling this building.

D.N. Morrison,
Supervisor of Construction.

It will make both wings usable. They need the space. Cost about $600, Mr. Jones said to me. Where are his plans?
Regina, February 1st, 1950.

J.P.B. Ostrander, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Indian Affairs Branch,
304 Post Office Building,
REGINA,
Saskatchewan.

REPORT ON LAC LA RONGE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Building 23 (Classroom)

We have received numerous complaints from the teaching staff regarding the heating of two classrooms in this building, one of which is located at the north end of the west wing, and the other at the north end of the east wing. The classroom at the north end of the east wing is 42' long and 32'6" in width. There are 5 windows along the east wall and one at the north end of the west wall. The entrance to this classroom is at the north end and is protected from the weather by a small cubical. The door of this cubical is on the north side and is in a direct line with the door leading into the classroom. This room is heated by two 24-coil hot water radiators which have been placed along the east wall of the building, and are about 10' from the north and south walls, with the same distance between them. I am informed by the teacher of the room that these radiators are always too hot to touch, but the room is very cold, and the day of my visit was the first day it had been warm. On further inspection I found all inside windows and sashes very loose, and in many cases the windows do not close properly. The doors are very poorly fitted, with gaps from ¼" to ½" at the top, bottom, or both.

The floor of this building is not covered, and is very drafty. I would recommend covering this floor, but I feel that if the windows and doors are properly sealed the classroom will be warm enough.

Sections of the outside wall covering should be repaired. I have asked Mr. Scrase to have his engineer, Mr. Bird, attend to the doors and windows, and report the resulting changes to us as soon as possible.

The classroom located.......
The classroom located at the north end of the west wing of this building is the same size as the former. The storm porch and doors are located in the same manner. Five windows are located on the west wall and one on the east wall. Two 24-coil radiators are located along the west wall, in the same manner as the classroom formerly described. The same conditions exist in this classroom with regard to doors and windows, and the same recommendations have been made to Mr. Scrase. The classrooms in the south end of this building are not so hard to heat, but the doors and windows are in need of repair.

The air in these classrooms, at the present time, is very foul, and it is my opinion that an air circulating system of some kind should be installed. This would not only protect the health of the students, but help solve the heating problem as well.

There are "ventilators" in the roof. If the room were warmer, correction might take care of air movement. Forced air would be good, of course.

D.H. Morrison,
Supervisor of Construction.
Regina, February 11th, 1950.

Building 23

Building 34

We do not appear to have received from Mr. Jones the plans to which Mr. Morrison refers. We understand that to effect the improvements in this building as suggested by Mr. Morrison, it would involve an expenditure of over $5,000.00. If it is possible for you to let us have the plans and your recommendation in the near future, it might be possible for us to find the funds in the current year's appropriation if the work or most of it could be completed before March 31st.
Building 30

With reference to Mr. Morrison's suggestion that this building be relined, Mr. Clark points out that there was lumber stored in the building used as a gymnasium. If this is not available at the present time, you might let me have a requisition for the material required.

The following is an Army Message sent to Colonel Neary today in connection with the engine at the former Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School which we were considering transferring to the File Hills Colony School for a lighting plant:

"REFERENCE MY LETTER FEBRUARY THIRD AND YOUR ARMY MESSAGE FEBRUARY TENTH TEGERT RECOMMENDS OVERHAULING ENGINE AT PRINCE ALBERT BEFORE SHIPPING TO FILE HILLS COLONY SCHOOL FOR LIGHTING PLANT STOP RECOMMEND INDIAN SUPERINTENDENT JONES BE AUTHORIZED BY WIRE TO HAVE ENGINE OVERHAULED AT ONCE COST POSSIBLY TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY DOLLARS LETTER FOLLOWS"

The engine has been kept under cover since the Lac la Ronge School burned, but it is recommended by Mr. Teget that it be overhauled before put to use. It is in Prince Albert now, and whether it is used at the File Hills Colony School or some other point it will have to be overhauled before it will be of any use for a lighting plant.

I would recommend that it be overhauled at once, but if parts are needed it will be some little time before the parts are all delivered, therefore it seems impossible to make immediate use of it to provide electricity for the File Hills Colony School.

In any case it is quite evident now that the school will have to open without a lighting plant, and as the teacher is moving in next week, I am asking Mr. Lunam to prepare the place temporarily so far as the sewage is concerned, with final arrangements being completed after the matter of power is satisfactorily settled.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

This school is being operated under the auspices of the Church of England, in the former military camp at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. In view of the failure of water at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, it has been found necessary to close this school temporarily and transfer twenty-nine children to the Lac la Ronge Residential School. In addition, Regional Supervisor J.P.B. Ostrander has reported that there are still a number of Church of England children who require institutional care.

In view of the above, it is necessary to provide additional accommodation, and Regional Supervisor Ostrander reports that if we renovate Army Building No. 20, part of it can be used for a dormitory, part for a manual training shop, and the remainder for a room for physical training purposes.

Mr. D.N. Morrison, Supervisor of Construction from Mr. Ostrander's office, recently inspected this building and states that the following work is necessary: Build partitions; supply and install blackboards; supply and install partitions and doors for all toilets, including necessary hardware; redecorate and paint entire building throughout; repair roof on the entire building; transfer heating from existing locations and install same according to Provincial and Dominion Building Codes; install new electric wiring; renew and repair all defective plumbing; supply and install battleship linoleum in the dormitory.

The Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, who are presently completing a contract for us.
on another building in this camp, and whose work has always been satisfactory, have forwarded a tender in an amount of $13,131.60, for the work which the Supervisor of Construction, Mr. Morrison, considers necessary. The price mentioned may be reduced if some material salvaged from other army buildings, can be used to advantage.

The company mentioned is prepared to carry out the work before the end of the current fiscal year, and as funds for the improvements are available in the 1949-50 Appropriation, I recommend that an Order in Council be obtained accepting the Harvey Lunam Construction Company tender. A Memorandum to Council is enclosed.

RECOMMENDED

DEPUTY MINISTER

Director.

Enc.
February 13th, 1950.

The Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, who are presently completing a contract for us.
on another building in this camp, and whose work has always been satisfactory, have forwarded a tender in an amount of $13,131.60, for the work which the Supervisor of Construction, Mr. Morrison, considers necessary. The price mentioned may be reduced if some material salvaged from other army buildings, can be used to advantage.

The company mentioned is prepared to carry out the work before the end of the current fiscal year, and as funds for the improvements are available in the 1949-50 Appropriation, I recommend that an Order in Council be obtained accepting the Harvey Lunam Construction Company tender. A Memorandum to Council is enclosed.

Director.
To be returned to Indian Affairs Br., File 656-5 (El)
Ottawa, February 13th, 1950.

REGIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL

Requesting authority for acceptance of the tender of Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount of $13,131.60, to carry out work of renovating Building No. 20, Prince Albert Military Camp, to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

Two extra copies of Order in Council are required.
February 13, 1950.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, for renovating Building No. 20 in the Prince Albert Military Camp, to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School;

THAT efforts have been made by Departmental Officials to obtain competitive tenders for the carrying out of the work required, and it has only been found possible to secure a tender from Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount not exceeding $13,131.60;

THAT the Harvey Lunam Construction Company has carried out other work for this Branch in an efficient manner;

THAT it is considered that the renovation of this building is necessary for the welfare of the pupils.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, to carry out the work required in an amount not exceeding $13,131.60.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.
Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 17 FEBRUARY 1950

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 13th February, 1950, from the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, for renovating Building No. 20 in the Prince Albert Military Camp, to be used in connection with the operation of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School;

That efforts have been made to obtain competitive tenders for the carrying out of the work required, and it has been found possible to secure only one tender, that of Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount not exceeding $13,131.60;

That the Harvey Lunam Construction Company has carried out other work for the Indian Affairs Branch in an efficient manner.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, Regina, Saskatchewan, in an amount not exceeding $13,131.60, as above set out.

Clerk of the Privy Council.
Mr E S Jones  
Indian Superintendent  
Prince Albert Saskatchewan

February 27th, 1950.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Laundry Machinery

1. Lac la Ronge Residential School

Our requisition dated February 18th, 1950 - The machinery ordered on this requisition is intended to replace certain laundry machinery transferred to the Lac la Ronge School at the time of the closing of the Chapleau Residential School approximately two years ago. At the time the machinery was transferred, it had been in use for over 20 years at Chapleau. There is no question that this particular machinery has served its usefulness, and as mentioned above, it is for this reason that we ordered the machinery requested on the requisition dated February 18th.

2. Qu'Appelle Residential School

Our requisition dated February 27th, 1950 for ironer - Attached is a requisition for a new ironer. The authorized pupilage at the Qu'Appelle School is 300, and the ironer presently in use is too small for the purpose required, but can be used to advantage at the St. Phillip's Residential School. If the new ironer as requested on the requisition is supplied at an early date, we will transfer the ironer at Qu'Appelle to St. Phillip's, which is a much smaller school.

We had an interview this afternoon with Mr. W.H. Buzby of Stanley Brock Limited, and we understand that if that firm could obtain the business in connection with both Qu'Appelle and Lac la Ronge Schools, they would be in a position to make a fairly liberal allowance on the old laundry machinery.
formerly at Chapleau and now at Lac la Ronge Residential School as mentioned above.

We recommend such action for your consideration.

PP/ST Attach.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Ottawa, 28 February, 1950.

C.M. Drury, Esq.,
Deputy Minister,
Department of National Defence,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Drury:

I am informed that there is on the outskirts of the city of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, a small parcel of land, on which your Department holds a lease, but which is at present not in actual use.

It has been suggested that this land could be used advantageously for agricultural purposes by the Lac la Bonge Indian Residential School which is in temporary quarters in the nearby war-time barracks (No. 122 C.A.(B)T.C.).

The land comprises two city blocks lying between Tenth Avenue West and Twelfth Avenue West and between Twenty-second Street and Twenty-fourth Street.

It is desired to obtain the permission of your Department to enter upon the land in time to put in a crop which will be harvested this year, and to continue such use so long as the arrangement is mutually agreeable and convenient.

As the parcel of land to which I refer is only about ten acres in extent, I would welcome information concerning other tracts in the neighbourhood which could be made available for school-farm use.

Yours sincerely,

Laval Fortier.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, OTTAWA, Ontario.

I have for acknowledgement letter 656-5-(E.1), dated February 22nd, 1950, re accounts Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School. In this regard may I refer to Departmental letter 656-5-(E.1) of November 10, 1949. In regard to Invoice No. 8383 amounting to $19.08, this I consider the responsibility of the Harvey Lunam Construction Company. Invoice No. 8230 and 8281 amounting to $29.65; this covered a very simple repair, the nature of which must be expected often in the type of heating plants in use at this institution. The pump and motor are attached together as one unit. During winter months this unit operates twenty-four hours of each day and consequently needs close supervision and maintenance. In fact, I gave the same attention to the motor and pump on the Agency office plant. It is evident the present engineer employed at the school has a very limited knowledge of electrical equipment. He is of course an employee of the school and I maintain the school should be responsible for both his mistakes and inability. Invoice No. 8620 amounting to $98.52, this I consider is a just charge against our Branch and must admit this was an oversight on my part. However, had this been drawn to my attention a considerable saving could have been brought about, for instance, the asbestos covering the old Jacket heaters could have been dissolved by soaking with water, and later used to cover the new Jacket heaters. Some of the piping too could have been salvaged. I have prepared vouchers covering the whole of the accounts, but I do think the instructions contained in letter 656-5-(E.1) of November 10, 1949, should be adhered to.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

With reference to Department letter of February 24th, 656-5 (El), I am enclosing herewith contract agreement completed by the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, in connection with the alterations at Army Hut No. 20, Ex 22, A.B.T.C., which is now used as Lac La Ronge Residential School. Mr. Lunam has deposited a Certified cheque, in the amount of 10% of the contract, $1,313.16, which will go forward to the Department in today's mail accompanying Receiver General Sheet No. 6.

It will be of interest to the Department to know that Mr. Lunam is making excellent progress on this contract, and it will be completed with all speed possible.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Potato Peeler - All Saints' (Lac la Ronge) Anglican Indian School, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

It would be appreciated if the potato peeler can be provided during the present financial year if at all possible.

With reference to Department army message of the 7th instant, and my reply by army message of the 9th instant regarding the heating of building No. 34, Lac La Ronge Residential School, I visited the school yesterday to discuss the matter of plans with Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones. It was my intention to interview Mr. H.P. Mascho of the M & K Plumbing and Heating Company, Prince Albert, with a view to getting plans and a quotation from him, however, Mr. Mascho was out of the city and will be for several days. It is necessary to discuss it with him, as he made the original suggestion as to the method of installing the plant and it can hardly be taken out of his hands at this stage.

There is a suitable boiler in stock in Prince Albert at the present time, and I asked Mr. Jones to take the necessary steps to submit a voucher for the boiler and a quantity of pipes and connections which will be necessary, in the hope that the voucher will be accepted and can be paid out of 1949-50 appropriation. Of course, if the purchase is to be made through the Departmental Purchasing Agent, with the writing for quotations, etc., it would be impossible to make the purchase before the end of the fiscal year.

The remainder of the cost of the new heating plant will be materials and labour to construct a small boiler-room and connect up the plant. This cannot be done until after the 1st of April, because of the continuing severe cold. It was twenty-five below zero when I left Prince Albert last night.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Fire Alarm
All Saints' (Lac la Ronge) Anglican
Indian School, Prince Albert, Sask.

On 8th December, 1949, following my visit to the above School, I wrote you as follows:

"Fire Alarm - Principal has been conducting regular fire drills and has everything well organized. However the gong they use is quite weak and with storm windows on the buildings it often is not heard. There should be a hooter, siren or louder alarm installed."

May this be given early consideration please in the interest of the safety of pupils and staff at this School."

I have now received the following report, dated 13th March, 1950, from the Principal of this School:

"No hooter, siren or fire alarm has been installed at this school.

It is unsatisfactory having to use the dinner gong for fire drill."

I again request that early consideration be given to the provision of a suitable fire alarm horn, siren or hooter at this School in the interest of the safety of children and staff and of the protection of the buildings and contents.

May we be advised what you propose to do about this.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

HARVEY LUNAM CONSTRUCTION CO.
GENERAL CONTRACTORS

311 Westman Chambers
Regina, Saskatchewan.
February 9th, 1950.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Affairs Department, Canada,
304 Post Office Building,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re: Army Hut No. 20, for Department of Indian Affairs, Canada, Prince Albert, Sask.

We wish to confirm that our tender for work at the above building, Prince Albert, Sask., is figured on the following specification-

The Contractor is to install heavy wire mesh screens to protect the windows in physical training room. Also supply and install heavy wire mesh screens to protect all radiators, pipes, electric lights, etc., in the room.
All windows throughout the building to be refitted or replaced where necessary and all windows to be fitted with weatherstrip satisfactory to the Superintendent of Indian Agency. Reglaze and replace broken glass where necessary on all windows in this building.
Supply all labour, material, etc., for building all partitions as outlined on plan, including all necessary hardware for doors, etc., to the entire satisfaction of Superintendent of Indian Agency.
Supply and install Blackboards in selected locations.
Supply and install Partitions and doors for all toilets, including all necessary hardware, etc.
Redecorate and paint entire building throughout.
Thoroughly repair roof of entire building.
All heating to be transferred from existing locations and to be placed on outside walls and to be installed according to Provincial and Dominion Building Codes. Four Fans to be installed behind radiators in order to circulate the heated air.
New Electric wiring to be installed according to Provincial and Federal building codes.
All defective plumbing to be renewed, or, repaired where necessary.
The purpose of these alterations and renovations, etc., is to make this building into a Dormitory as outlined, also Manual Training Shop as well as a Physical Training separate.
The Contractor is to thoroughly inspect all plumbing, heating, electrical work and all other work which may require repairing or replacing to give an entirely satisfactory job when the contract is completed, as no extras will be tolerated. The Contractor is to supply all permits, inspection fees, etc., as well as all other charges for a complete and thoroughly satisfactory job.

The entire price of this work as outlined and including the supplying and installing of AA Battleship Linoleum in Dormitory, is Thirteen Thousand, One Hundred and Thirty One Dollars and 60/XX Dollars. ($13,131.60) Should Linoleum be omitted our price will be reduced to ($12,427.60) Twelve Thousand, Four Hundred and Twenty Seven & 60/XX Dollars.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) H. Lunam - Manager.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Potato Peeler - All Saints' (Lac La Ronge) Anglican Indian School, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

On 8th December, 1949, following my return from Prince Albert I pointed out that over 2 bushels of potatoes were consumed daily at the above School and asked that the early provision of a potato peeler be given consideration. Since that time the pupilage has been increased by some 30 transferred from Gordon's and, naturally, the daily consumption of potatoes has increased.

It would be appreciated if the potato peeler can be provided during the present financial year if at all possible.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.
Ottawa April 20, 1950.

E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Box 787, Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Nightwatchman Lac la Ronge
(All Saints') Anglican Indian School, Prince Albert, Sask.

In your 656-5(E.l) of 11th June, 1949, you advised that you were prepared to allow a Nightwatchman at the above School, because of the peculiar conditions existing there, until 30th June, 1950, and that the matter would then be reviewed. Under the same file number and under date of 24th June, 1949, you stated that the salary allowed would be $60.00 per month for the period ending 30th June, 1950.

The Principal of this School points out that a continuously employed full-time Nightwatchman will be required after the termination of the present authorization. We agree with the Principal because of the number of buildings and the nature of their construction and therefore request that authorization of a Nightwatchman at a salary of $60.00 be extended until 30th June, 1951, with the proviso that the matter will be reviewed again in the spring of 1951.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.
April 21st, 1950.

Lac la Ronge Residential School - Laundry

Reference your 611-107/6-1-656 of April 22nd

I discussed this matter with Canon Cook yesterday in the presence of Major Clark. It seems evident that Mr. Scrase does not now want to change the laundry to a drill hall building as previously agreed upon with Canon Cook.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Dining Hall, Lac la Ronge (All Saints') Anglican Indian School, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

Hereunder is an extract from a letter received today from the Principal of the above school.

The changes to be done in the dining hall seem to be the most pressing work for the school this summer. Mr. Jones informs me that the work will be done.

Steam heating has to be put in -- thus removing danger of fire from a number of stoves in dining halls and passages. A boiler room has to be built at the back and water tanks and heaters will be moved from kitchen into the boiler room, thus giving more kitchen space.

I need both wings of the dining hall in use, with 150 children seated in each wing.

Battleship linoleum is required for the floors and interior of building requires painting.

I hope that this work will commence as soon as the children leave the school in June.

Cooking for the staff and children who remain during the summer can be done on a range that is in the laundry building.

I feel that having the dining hall and kitchen in good shape before September is the Number One project.

I support fully the above report of the Principal and request that authorization be given so that the work can be commenced as soon as the children leave at the end of the present school.

(P.T.O.)
term and be completed before the beginning of the following school term.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Memorandum:

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Laundry Equipment - All Saints Indian Res. School

The statement that extra equipment will be surplus is surprising, and should not cause us to refuse delivery of the equipment ordered.

The present laundry has been criticized adversely because of its location in a building apart from the storage and repair rooms. The Department consented to move the laundry into the drill hall building and thus stream-line the procedures with clothing, but this cannot be done until the school vehicles and the Manual Training shop have been moved into other buildings in order to make room for a proper laundry installation comprising enough equipment to handle the load expeditiously.

We have already provided elsewhere for a Manual Training shop. It is now up to the local people to find garage space elsewhere. They usurped this space originally without authority. Its continued use as a garage invites hazards such as overtook Round Lake but with a tremendously greater potential loss. The vehicles belonging to the school and staff members should be housed in a building where a fire would not destroy other equipment.

Our plan for the permanent installation is first of all to make the space in the drill hall available. Then the new machinery should be set up on expert advice as part of the full installation. Drains will be placed in the floor and spaces left so that there is room to fit in duplicate units at certain points. The new machinery will thus be able to operate while the machinery from the hut No. 33 is being transferred and set up alongside the new machinery.
The installation of new machinery in the drill hall involves previous attention to the provision of a chimney and hot water. If at all possible we should avoid building a new chimney and use the excellent chimney already in existence near the point where the new machinery will be set up. I have made additional copies of this memorandum so that if you wish it may be submitted to others concerned for their comments.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.
Ottawa, May 16, 1950.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Regina, May 23rd, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Dining Hall,
Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

With reference to Department letter of the 13th instant,
File 656-5 (Ex), regarding Canon Cook's comments on Building No. 34,
used as dining hall, I have to say that the matters mentioned are
practically in accordance with the understanding between Mr. Scrase,
Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones, and myself as to what should be
done this year, and there has been considerable correspondence to
that effect.

However, in my opinion it is necessary to get advice
from the Engineering Services before taking further steps. After
plans are prepared by Engineering Services (Mr. W.W. Perrie preferably),
tenders should be called in accordance with those plans.

I do not recommend that Mr. D.N. Morrison be placed
in charge of such an important piece of work, and to have it performed
by local labour, as we could run into a great deal of difficulty with
regard to the supply of material. It is the intention to send
Mr. Morrison to the Beauval Residential School to supervise the work
at that school, and he will be tied up there most of July and August.
The work at Building No. 34 should also be done in July and August,
therefore there is some urgency about it.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
June 1st, 1950.

Memorandum:

MR. CHAS. E. BUCK,
CHIEF ENGINEER

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, this school is operating in the military camp just outside the town of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

Building No. 34 is being used as a dining hall, but it is not satisfactory in its present condition owing to the large enrolment at the school.

We have been informed by Regional Supervisor Ostrander that the following work at least should be done to the building in order to make it satisfactory for the purposes required:

1. Steam heating is to be put in - thus removing danger of fire from a number of stoves in the dining halls and passages.

2. A second room should be built at the back and water tanks and heaters moved from the kitchen into the boiler room, thus giving more kitchen space.

3. Battleship linoleum is required for the floors.

4. The interior of the building needs painting.

....2
The above suggestions apply to both wings of the building used as a dining hall, as 150 children are seated in each wing. Mr. Ostrander states that Mr. W.W. Perrie is familiar with the situation at this school.

It is most important that this work be done during the summer holidays (July and August 1950) so that the dining hall will be in proper condition when the school reopens on September 1st.

Both Regional Supervisor Ostrander, Regina, and Superintendent Jones, Prince Albert, should be advised of the exact date on which the engineer will visit this school.

Your immediate kind attention to the above matter would be appreciated.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Laundry Equipment,
Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School:

In accordance with your instructions I discussed this matter with the Reverend Principal last Sunday.

I confirmed the fact that his present urgent need is for a drier rather than an extractor, as it needs two driers to keep up with the other units because of the difficulty in this climate of hanging things out to dry. It is not convenient to wait for a dry yet dust-free day to hang the whitewear out.

This drier can be set up in the meantime beside the other working units. Room was allowed for it in the plan for the set-up. The instructions also called for the fitters to install the steam-pipes so that the addition of another drier would be only a minor operation.

The second washer and extractor should be stored on the school premises until the provision of garage space for trucks, etc., is made away from the Drill Hall where the full laundry installation was intended.

It was our hope that the larger school would do the laundry for the smaller school (St. Albans). It has been doing some of the latter's laundry for weeks because of a break-down in the equipment at St. Albans. This further demonstrates the unwisdom of depending on single large units. Two medium-sized units like washers, etc., are better for school purposes, on the same principle as supplying two medium-sized heating units (boilers).

Copy to Regional Supervisor, Regina
Superintendent, Prince Albert

C.A.F. Clark

Reference is made to the outstanding account submitted by the Prince Albert Foundry Co., Prince Albert covering repairs to a high-pressure boiler now in use at the All Saints Indian Residential School. The account is submitted herewith under cover of Agency voucher No. 379.

FORM No. LA. 413

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6317, file 656-5, part II)
Chief, Education Division

Alterations at Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School.

In March of this year weather conditions retarded the project for changing the heating arrangements for Hut No. 34 (dining-room). I have not in the meantime seen the comments of our Heating Engineer or Supervisor of Construction concerning the plan and estimates.

I understand that it is proposed to eliminate from the kitchen two hot water tanks with their coal heaters, and I wonder whether the extra costs that this would involve are necessary. In favour of the change is the argument that the firing would be done by a skilled fireman—when there is one. Against it there is the point that the cooking staff will have to attend to the many stoves anyway, and hot water is in their interest. A responsibility that someone else does not fulfill would be another source of friction.

Most important is the necessity to get the job done as efficiently and cheaply as possible this summer.

On the point of cheapness of installation and part-time (as it should be) operation could we get an opinion on the feasibility of forced hot air rather than hot water? As it is a two-winged building the factor of flexibility might affect the cost of operation. We have two large hot-air furnaces in the Drill Hall which are said to be too expensive to use. A smaller unit of that type might supply sufficient fresh warm air to the dining-rooms. Ventilation as well as warmth is a consideration. It is for that reason that I think the engineering branch might review the present plans and alternatives.

Copy to:
Regional Supervisor, Regina
Dept., Carlton Indian Agency.

Mr. J. P. B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Post Office Building, REGINA, Saskatchewan.

I am enclosing herewith tenders submitted by Mr. W. I. Dier, Builder and Contractor, Prince Albert, and the Harvey Lunam Construction Co. of Regina, covering the erection of six ash bins which I hope to have the authority to construct at the various buildings in connection with the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School.

Both the city engineer and the fire chief have requested these improvements be made with as little delay as possible so that they will be in readiness for use when the cold weather sets in next fall.

During the past two winters ashes from the boilers have been dumped at a reasonably safe distance from the boiler rooms. You will realize that there is always a possibility of a wind starting up and carrying live ash on to the buildings.

E.S. Jones,
Superintendent,
Carlton Indian Agency,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration.

Enclosed is copy of a letter from Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones, of the Carlton Agency, in connection with the construction of ash bins for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. Also enclosed are quotations from the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, and W.I. Dier, both for the amount of $450.00 for material and labour.

I am today forwarding a letter and other documents in connection with construction of a boiler room and installation of a heating plant in Building No. 34, Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, and I would suggest that as both contractors have quoted the same amount for the construction of the ash bins, the matter of awarding the contract for them be delayed until the boiler room and heating plant for Building No. 34 are completed.

Encl.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter from Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones, of the Carlton Agency, with regard to installation of a heating plant for building No. 34, Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. Also enclosed is a blue print prepared by the M & K Plumbing Company, showing the proposed heating plant; letter from the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, quoting $2100.00 for construction of the boiler room; a quotation from W.I. Dier, Contractor, of $2,078.56 for the boiler room; and rough plan of the boiler room.

I have discussed this with Mr. W.W. Perrie, Resident Engineer, and we are of the opinion that there is no possibility that the Department will be prepared to proceed on this construction without properly prepared blue prints and specifications, and advertising for tenders. Indian Superintendent Jones also informed me that the M & K Plumbing and Heating Company quote $8,200.00 on the heating plant, as outlined in the blue print. This amount, together with approximately $2100.00 for the building, indicates that the whole will cost over $10,000.00, therefore advertising for tenders will certainly be necessary.

May this matter be given consideration as soon as possible, and request made that an engineer visit the premises and prepare plans and specifications.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Fire Siren for Lac la Ronge (All Saints') School, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

During the past few months there has been an interchange of correspondence with you regarding the provision of a fire alarm at the above school, the present gong being entirely inadequate in view of the scattered buildings.

Just prior to my departure for Prince Albert a few weeks ago we discussed this matter and you asked me to ascertain whether a suitable siren is available in Prince Albert and at what cost; alternatively, if nothing available locally, to ascertain where one can be procured.

During my visit to this School I accompanied Rev. A. J. Scrase, the Principal, (Supt. Jones was out of the City and therefore not available to go with us) to the Prince Albert Fire Hall where we discussed the matter with the Chief of the Fire Department. He recommends a Model V Federal Siren (such as is mounted on his car) operated from a 6-volt battery; he prefers battery to line operation because of the danger of disruption of power lines in event of a fire. The Chief informed me that this particular siren is handled by The Prairie Fire Extinguisher Company, Moose Jaw, Sask., so I wrote that firm for a quotation and enclose the original of their reply received today.

You will note that the price of the Model V Federal Siren, 6 volt, is $29.00 f.o.b. Moose Jaw. To this should be added the cost of a 6-volt battery (car battery) which I understand is about $20.00 in Prince Albert.

As discussed by telephone this afternoon we shall be glad if you will authorize the purchase and installation of the above at an early date as a safeguard to the pupils and staff, a number of whom will be in residence in this school throughout the summer.

(P.T.O)

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6317, file 656-5, part II)
Prairie Fire Extinguisher Co.

June 14th 1950.

Indian School Administration,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Sir;

Many thanks for your letter of June 13th wherein you seek quotation on the following item:

One Only Model V Federal Siren, 6 Volts,

We are pleased to quote this at $29.00 each, F.O.B. Moose Jaw, Sales Tax Includedm., Education Tax extra, 3%, but you could advise us whether this last item is chargeable against shipments consigned to your Institution.

We have one of these Sirens in stock, but it is a 12 Volt Siren and if it would not work on your intended installation, we would bring in the Six Volt along with another we are bringing in for another Fire Chief.

We must apply for Import Permits from Ottawa on these Sirens, but we do not have any trouble getting them.

A catalogue of Vehicle Sirens is being sent you under separate cover.

Yours very truly,

PRAIRIE FIRE EXTINGUISHER CO.

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School

For some time past the M.S.C.C. has requested that a proper fire alarm be supplied for the above school. When General Turner was in Prince Albert recently, he interviewed the Chief of the Prince Albert Fire Department, and he recommended the purchase of a siren and battery.

General Turner has written the Prairie Fire Extinguisher Company, Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, and was informed that they are prepared to supply a Model V Federal Siren, 6 volt, for $29.00 f.o.b. MR. CHAS. E. BUCK,
CHIEF ENGINEER

Re: Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

I desire to direct your attention to my memorandum of June 1st with reference to the renovations required at Building No. 34 which is at present being used as a dining hall.

You will note from the third last paragraph of my previous memorandum that it was stated that it was most important the work at this building be carried out during the summer holidays (July and August, 1950).

I would appreciate it if you would let me know what action has been taken in this matter, as we are very anxious to have the work completed before the school reopens after the summer holidays, namely September 1st, 1950.

Dear Colonel Neary:

On 13th June, 1950, during my visit to Prince Albert I sent you, through this office, information regarding certain items needed at the above school. In addition to those, the following were brought to my attention during my visit:

(a) Handicrafts

I was informed that your Major Clark, who visited this school recently, recommended that a Handicrafts Instructor and an Assistant Manual Training Instructor be added to the Staff.

Will you please let us know whether or not your Department will pay the salaries of such personnel (as you now do in the case of the Manual Training Instructor) and also what grant, if any, you are prepared to make towards the cost of materials for handicrafts work. The question of provision of materials also arises in the case of St. Alban's School where one of the Staff has been very successful in her teaching of the girls in plastic work, bead work, embroidery, weaving, etc.

(b) Prayer & Hymn Books

These are needed at Lac la Ronge School and also at St. Alban's. Will they be supplied by you on requisition by the Principals to your local Superintendent?

(c) Bread-Slicer

With 250 children (and possibly 300), besides staff, the slicing of bread by hand is a long and laborious process. It will be appreciated if a bread-slicer can be supplied before the commencement of next term.

(d) Electric Irons in Laundry

3 additional electric irons, with wall outlets for plugging in, are needed.

(P.T.O)

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Roothouse - Lac la Ronge (All Saints')
Anglican Indian School, Prince Albert,
Saskatchewan.

Reference is made to my telegram of June 13th, 1950,
from Prince Albert and sent you on 14th June through this office; also
to our conversation in your office this morning.

Last summer a roothouse was provided by banking up
a portion of leanto on the Drill Hall, partitioning off the banked-up
portion and insulating under the roof. However, the results were de-
finitely most unsatisfactory as all the vegetables produced in the
School garden and stored in this structure froze and the beets, carrots
and turnips were a total loss. It was found possible, but only by
means of special cooking, to utilize most of the frozen potatoes.

This year the School garden comprises 6-7 acres of
potatoes and 2-3 acres of other vegetables. Unless proper winter
storage for this produce is provided, the loss of money, time and
labour will be very great and will involve heavy waste of essential
food.

It is urgently requested that early action be taken
towards provision of proper storage space either by reconstructing the
present accommodation or providing some suitable alternative. It is
suggested that advice of local officials of the Department of Agri-
culture be sought as regards methods of making the present accommo-
dation satisfactory. From a casual inspection it would appear that
insulation is needed on the sides and ends and that a roof vent should
be installed to ensure proper ventilation.

Will you please let us know what you propose to do
in this connection because if no suitable storage is provided the
Principal will have to try to dispose of all the produce that cannot

(P.T.O.)
be consumed before cold weather sets in.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent
Box 787,
Prince Albert, Sask.,
June 29th, 1950.

Re: Lac la Ronge Residential School
Your File 1808-108/6-1-656

We are in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the swimming pool at the above school.

Approval is granted for acceptance of Mr. Dier's quotation of $210.00 for material and labour to place the swimming pool in good condition. It should be understood that the Department will not be responsible for the cost of extra water required or any cost of operation.

In reply to Department letter of July 3rd, file 656-5(EL), with which was enclosed a copy of Mr. Turner's letter to Mr. Neary regarding the root house at Lac la Ronge Indian school, Prince Albert, on my last visit to Prince Albert I discussed the matter with Mr. Jones, the Reverend Principal was not available.

I would recommend that our Branch make a request to Mr. G. Brault, Chief Architect of the Department of Public Works, asking him to instruct Mr. Ramage, of the Saskatoon office Public Works, to inspect the root house in question and submit a report to our Branch with his recommendation. After Mr. Ramage has made his inspection and reported, his recommendations could be carried out before the time to use the root house for winter storage of this year's crop.

May I please be advised.

J. P. B. Ostrander
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies
Saskatchewan
Mr. J. P. B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Post Office Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

I have for acknowledgement letter 1874-107/6-1-656, dated July 6th, 1950, enclosing a copy of a letter from the Anglican school authorities to our Branch pertaining to the Root Cellar constructed last year at the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School. I withheld my reply in the hope Mr. Scrase, Principal of the school, would return from holidays which would enable me to discuss the matter with him. I now understand Mr. Scrase does not expect to return until August 12th. I was advised last year the Department would consider furnishing a Root Cellar providing the cost was not too high. I wrote the University of Saskatchewan giving them an outline of our requirements and requested I be furnished with plans of the construction of Root Cellars. On receipt of the plans mentioned I had two different contractors work out the cost. Both estimates were in the neighborhood of $4,000.00. I considered the plans too elaborate and was of the opinion something much cheaper and just as suitable could be constructed. In this connection I solicited the services of Mr. Ramage, engineer of the Department of Public Works, who kindly gave of his time and assistance in preparing the plan, which was eventually carried out.

In his letter, General Turner has been very unjust in his criticism of the construction of the Root Cellar concerned or his is not aware of the actual facts.
I recall seeing approximately forty bushels of potatoes harvested and placed in the portion of the lean-to adjoining the Root Cellar. These potatoes represented so much muck. It is my understanding they were later placed in the Root Cellar with other vegetables, the fumes from which I submit would have a tendency to rot every vegetable in the Root Cellar. Further, when the cellar was constructed, a stove was set up in the building with the intention of putting on a fire when temperatures remained below normal for any length of time. From inquiries made, it is very apparent the stove was not used once during the winter.

It is my opinion the plan and the construction of the Root Cellar is practical and suitable for the storing of vegetables. What is needed is to educate the Principal and the staff of the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School in the correct method of harvesting and storing vegetables, also the careful checking of the cellar during the winter months.

I would appreciate if arrangements could be made to have Mr. Ramage of the Department of Public Works examine the building and submit a report.

At the present time, a portion of the earth has been washed down by recent heavy rains. A considerable amount too, was brought down from the upper portion of the embankment by the children who used the embankment for a slide the whole of last winter and the greater part of the summer.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent,
Carlton Indian Agency,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration.
Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, July 4, 1950.

You may know that the properties owned by Municipal, Provincial and Dominion Governments and some others are exempt from municipal taxation.

REPORT on the INSPECTION of

WILLIAM CHARLES' and JAMES ROBERTS' BANDS.

Date of Inspection, Aug. 8th to 23rd, 1905:

Boarding School. 12.

There is nothing as yet to mark the site of the proposed boarding school except the clearing from half an acre of land of the light growth of poplar timber with which it was covered. But it was expected the saw-mill referred to in paragraph 3 above would be in operation about the end of August, and shortly after that the work of building would begin. The site selected is as healthful and as suitable in every respect as could be found in the locality.

Respectfully submitted,

W. J. Chisholm,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Nistawasie, Sept. 23rd, 1905.
Battleford, Sask.
July 21st 1909

346826

I am informed that Mr. Leetoot Reid is likely to proceed shortly to Lac la Rouge to carry out surveys under instructions from your department. I would respectfully request that the land on which the Indian Boarding School is situated may be surveyed by Mr. Reid. We claim for the school about half a mile frontage on Lac la Rouge and about a quarter of a mile back.

I would also request that the school be allowed a small timber reserve on the Big Stone Lake, anything from half a mile to one square mile.

The probability is that timber limits may be secured in that part of the country before long, and we may have difficulty in getting timber for the use of the school. I am writing for Lac la Rouge on the 3rd prox. and a reply addressed to me at Prince Albert that may reach me before I leave would be a great favour.

Yours faithfully,

J. A. MacKay
Ottawa, July 29, 1909.

Memo.

Mr. Bray,

Mr. Reid may be instructed to survey for the Lac la Ronge Boarding School land to the extent requested by the Ven. Archdeacon Mackay, i.e., with a frontage of one-half mile on the lake and a depth of about one-quarter of a mile.

This would appear to be a reasonable amount for the use of the school.

No action will be taken to secure a timber limit for their use at present.

Acting Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, July 29, 1909.

Sir:

Referring to your proposed surveys of Indian reserves at Lac La Ronge I beg to inform you that in accordance with the representations made by Ven. Archdeacon J.A. Mackay it has been decided to allow to the Indian boarding school at Lac La Ronge a tract of land having a frontage on the lake of about half a mile with a depth of about a quarter of a mile. I have to request you to be good enough to consult with Mr. Mackay who is probably now at Battleford, or with the Principal in charge of the school, and to survey the said tract of land in the usual manner. The general instructions regarding surveys for this Department with which you are familiar will cover this case.

Mr. Mackay also requested that a timber limit be also surveyed for the school but the Department has decided that no action be taken in this direction for the present.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs.

J. Lestock Reid, Esq., D.L.S.,
Battleford,
Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6317, file 656-9, part 1)
Ottawa, August 5, 1909.

Very Reverend Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 21st ult., I beg to say that the Department has instructed its surveyor, Mr. J. Lestoek Rea, D.L.S., to allot to the Lac la Ronge Indian Boarding School a tract of land as requested by you and asked him to consult with you or with the Principal.

No action is to be taken with reference to the survey of a timber limit at present.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Prince Albert, Sask.

Oct. 4th 1915

The past season has been very unfavorable for the Indians in the northern part of the country where they are dependent on the fur hunt. They have felt the pinch considerably and the coming season is not more promising. In the district in which Lac la Rouge is situated very destructive fires have waged in the course of the summer, owing to an exceptionally dry season and it may be assumed that there has been great destruction of fur-bearing animals. Furs will be scarce and the price will be low so that there will be a good deal of want. In my operations at Lac la Rouge school last summer, I endeavored to give the Indians all the employment I could in my limited means, and, besides employing them at the saw mill, I gave them work in clearing and draining a swamp near the school. The drain is good and the land when drained is excellent.

The Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs

A. Hanna
all that is required in labour. This work is de-
sirable in more ways than one—
1. It would afford the Indians some employment
and help them out in their need.
2. It would be an object lesson to them and
teach them that there is plenty of land within
their reach that might be made productive
by intelligent labour.
3. The land brought under cultivation would
be a great help towards the support of the school.
We should be very thankful if the De-
partment could grant us $500.00 (five hun-
dred dollars) for this purpose.

Yours obediently,
J. A. MacKay

Ottawa, 29th February, 1916.

Very Rev. Sir:

On the 15th October the Department sent you cheque No. 2116 for $500.00 being an advance wherewith to defray expenses of drainage of land in connection with the Lac La Ronge Indian Boarding School. It is desired that you will kindly account for the expenditure of the proceeds of this cheque without delay, as the present fiscal year will close on the 31st of March, and it is necessary to have the money accounted for before the close of the year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
