Lac la Rouge
March 16th 1918

Sir,

Referring to your letter No 212538-1 of the 29th ult. I herewith enclose a voucher for the expenditure of $79.67 which is all that I have spent so far on drainage. This I had ordered before I received the $500.00 from the Department. When I received the cheque from the Department, cold weather had set in and it was too late in the season to resume work on drainage. As you state that it is necessary to have the money accounted for before the close of the fiscal year, I have asked the Revillon Freres' agent, through whom I have been making the payments, to give me a voucher for $403.33, to make up the balance of the $500.00, only the account is for lumbering, not drainage. As a matter of fact I have spent over $800.00 on lumbering, but I do not intend to spend this money on lumbering eventually. I intend to spend the whole of the $500.00 on drainage as soon as ever the season opens and work of that kind can be obtained. I do not know that this way of doing things will be satisfactory, but it is the best that I can do at present.

I am Sir,
Yours obediently,
J. A. MacKay

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
&c.

Ottawa, March 31st., 1916.

Very Rev. Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, with enclosure, relative to the advance of $500.00 made to you by cheque No. 2116 wherewith to defray expenses of drainage of land in connection with the Lac la Ronge Indian Boarding School; and in reply I return herewith the voucher for $420.33 which you have submitted. When the $500.00 has been expended on the drainage as intended, the full amount should be accounted for. The Department will require evidence that the Indians received the money through orders. These orders should be attached to the account, which should bear your certificate to the effect that the work has been performed and that the charges are fair and just.

I also return the account of $79.67 which you submitted, which amount has already been expended from the proceeds of the cheque for $500.00. This account is incomplete without the orders and it should be certified by you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLeod

Boarding School
Lee la Roche
Sask.

Dec 18, 1916.

Sir:

I am sending account of expenditure of the $500.00 received for the purpose of draining and clearing muskeg. The money was paid mostly in orders on the Revillon Freres and Hudson's Bay Company. The orders I am sending are all duplicate orders copied from the stub of the original order book, and are as follows: $298.00 on the Revillon Freres and $31.25 on the Hudson's Bay Co. The men were paid at the rate of $1.25 per day, and rations. The School supplied rations at a cost of 70 cents per man per day. Which amounts
(263½ days @ 70 cents per day) $184.45

So that the total amount expended when the muskeg work is $513.75.

I may say that about (10) ten acres has been cleared and drained, half of which was under cultivation last Summer. Owing to the land being part of a large muskeg it is subject to frost, so that last year we were able to grow green feed only, but with further draining and clearing good farm land may be obtained. It is the largest piece of cultivated land within a radius of (100) one hundred miles, so that it is an entirely new industry up in this part. The muskeg or swamp is many thousands of acres in area, and when drained and cleared makes the very best of rich land.
The soil being a black loam of 3 and 4 ft in depth, and of mould were cleared I think the Indians here would take hold of the idea of farming. They will soon have to do something other than trapping for a living, for fur is getting scarce.

Last year the Department kindly sent garden seeds for the Indians which I urged them to sow, and the results were very satisfactory, for nearly every Indian had his garden patch last Summer. I think next Spring I could get more sown if the Department would kindly send more.

Thanking you for the help you have given us towards starting a farm.
I beg to remain.

Your obedient Servant:

(Row) Charles F. Hume,
Acting Principal

Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
OTTAWA, 12th September, 1923.

Re Lot 12 La Ronge Settlement, Saskatchewan.
Area 76.7 acres.

With reference to your letter of the 4th March 1910, your reference 212538, in connection with the Industrial School Lands at Lac La Ronge, Saskatchewan, shown on the plan of Indian School Lands No. A at Lac La Ronge, surveyed by J. Lestock Reid, D.L.S., in 1910, will you be good enough to say whether this parcel corresponds to Lot 12 mentioned above, which has been applied for by the English Church Mission at the time of the survey of La Ronge Settlement in 1920. Rev. C. F. Hives of the English Church Mission reported at the same time an advance of money by your Department in connection with the boarding school and hospital on Lot 12.

A copy of the plan of La Ronge Settlement is enclosed.

Will you please state also whether you have any objection to the sale of Lot 12 to the Church of England being considered, or is it the desire of your Department to have the said parcel known as Indian School Lands No. A, transferred to the control of your Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

N. O. Coté

Sir,

Lestock Reid, D.L.S., and applied for in Departmental letter of the 4th March 1910. It is the desire of this Department that this lot be transferred to the control of this Department for the purposes of the Indian boarding school and hospital, as the above mentioned buildings have been erected on this lot by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

The Right Rev.
The Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Bishopsthorpe, Prince Albert.

My dear Bishop,

Referring to the enclosed letter from the Department of the Interior addressed to you forwarded to me by Mrs. Malaher I have to explain that the Church of England has no claim to the lots therein mentioned. The large lot of 76 acres has a frontage of half a mile on Lac la Ronge. It was surveyed at my request as a School Reserve when I was building the original Boarding school, and it belongs to the Indian Department with all the school buildings. The smaller lot, 8 acres, was cleared for purposes of cultivation while I was in charge of the school, and I had a special grant from the Indian Department for the purpose. The whole thing, school buildings and land, belongs to the Indian Department. When we handed over the school to the M.S.C.E. we, that is the Diocese, had no property to hand over. All that we handed over was the control. If Mr. Hives has made affidavits or statutory declarations in support of the claims of the Church of England, he has done so on his own responsibility or under instructions from the M.S.C.E. The Church has no claim and has no object in entering a claim for the land. The Government has built the school and the Government is supporting the school, and the whole property belongs to the Indian Department of the Government.

I hope this will give you the information necessary to make a clear reply to the Department of the Interior.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) J. A. MacKay.

LAC LA RONGE,
VIA PRINCE ALBERT, SASK.

June 10th, 1931.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

From the present indications there is not likely to be very much work in which the Indians of this locality can find employment during the coming summer, and it possible there will be considerable hardship among the people.

At the school we are greatly in need of more land for cultivation. At the present time we have not more than three acres, and that not very good. I am wondering whether the Department will make this school a grant of $1000.00 to clear some new land. In this way we can obtain more land, and at the same time provide employment for the people here.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, June 27, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, requesting that a grant of $1,000 be provided for the purpose of clearing new land for cultivation at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. In reply I have to say that our appropriation for the present fiscal year was considerably reduced. It is possible to provide funds for only the more urgent requirements at our Indian schools. I regret that the Department will be unable to provide any grant this year to clear more land at the Lac la Ronge School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. G. W. Fisher,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lac la Ronge,
via Prince Albert,
Sask.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM REV. T. B. R. WESTGATE, D.D.,
FIELD SECRETARY, M. S. C. C., 39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave., Winnipeg, Man., dated August 27, 1931.

Original on 132-2-5.

During the latter part of July and the beginning
of August I visited our Society's Indian Residential
School at Lac la Ronge, Sask., and reported the following
requirements to our Commission:

(10) Increase in the school land from 75 acres, this
being the amount attached to the school at present,
to at least 640 acres.

(11) Clearing of more land, say 25 acres, so that hay
and green feed may be grown for the stock.

With regard to the clearing of more land, our
Commission instructed me to make known to your Department
the serious problem they have to face from year to year
in securing an adequate supply of hay for the stock. The
school management now go from island to island in the lake
cutting a little here and there wherever it is to be found.
They are experimenting with oats on small pieces of ground,
and from results obtained, feel confident that the hay and
green feed problem can be solved if more land is cleared.
Your Department made a grant for this purpose a few years
ago, and the money was well spent in clearing about five
acres of land near the main school building. A great many
stones, however, will have to be removed before this area
can be seeded to advantage. The bush fire of 1927 which
destroyed the forest around the school and endangered the
school buildings at the same time, revealed considerable
land about a mile or two behind the school, which could be
brought under cultivation if properly cleared of stumps
and shrubbery, and as this would afford employment for the
Indians in the settlement, our Commission strongly recom-
mend that not less than 25 acres be cleared as soon as
possible. As this area does not at present lie within the
boundaries of the school property, our Commission feel
that steps should be taken to have the school land in-
creased sufficiently to enclose it, and they trust that
your Department may be able to help them in the way
indicated.
Ottawa, September 8, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 27th ultimo which relates to additional land for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. The school land may be described as Lots 9 and 12 in the La Ronge Settlement, comprising a total of 64.8 acres. The land to the north is, I believe, owned by the Provincial Crown, and, before an application is made for a parcel, it will be necessary to know with some accuracy just what land is desired by the school. Please have the Principal indicate what land is desired, on a rough sketch, giving distances as far as possible and showing the relations of the present school lots.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
MEMORANDUM RE LANDS OF THE LAC LA RONGE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Approximately 84.5 acres, having been granted by P.C. 689 of May 4, 1925 ("the said lots be and they are hereby transferred to the control of the Department of Indian Affairs for the purposes of the Indian Boarding School and Hospital at La Ronge").

May be briefly described as:

Lots 9 and 12 of La Ronge Settlement in the Province of Saskatchewan.
The land which was set aside for this school is all rock and muskeg. I went into this matter very closely and was informed that there was some land about one-half mile north of the school where a sufficient acreage could be cleared to enable them to grow their own feed for stock. I walked over this land in company with the engineer and found that his statement was correct. It would be quite possible to obtain the clearing of 25 or 30 acres, which would meet the requirements. In order to provide this, another quarter or half section might be set aside for the use of the school. The land I speak of, I am satisfied, will never be taken up by settlers, as owing to the fact that it is surrounded by rocky land and muskeg, and has no lake frontage, it is practically valueless as it stands. I was informed that this land could be cleared with the help of the big boys at a cost of about $20.00 per acre. They have already cleared about three acres of this, but the Principal does not feel that he would be justified in spending any considerable amount until they have a proprietary right to the land. Unless some such arrangement is made, it would be impossible to increase the number of cows.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM COMMISSIONER GRAHAM,
dated October 8th, 1931.

Original on 132-1-5.

With regard to the Lac la Ronge School, it will be noted that the situation of this school is not by any means as favourable as that at Beauval, there being very little land under cultivation or fit for that purpose. The Inspector points out that some might be obtained if the Department could arrange for the purchasing of same, or for having it set aside. I do not know how this affects the arrangements made with the Provincial Government re setting land aside for the Indians, but would suggest that it be set aside as an Indian reserve, and the school then allowed to use it. I would be glad to be advised in this connection, and I will then take the matter up with the proper authorities here. We should certainly provide for the growing of hay for feed for the cattle, so that the children could obtain milk as part of their diet.
Ottawa, October 27, 1931.

Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 8th instant, which has reference to the need of more land at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. This question has already received the attention of the Department, and, on the 8th ultimo, I wrote to the school authorities, asking that a rough description, with sketch showing the land desired, be submitted to the Department. When this is to hand, I will write to you further concerning overtures to the Provincial Government.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter of September 8th, 1931, #132-2-9, requesting further information as to the parcel of land which our Society desires to be added to their Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge in Saskatchewan, I beg to state that I have just received the information requested from the Principal. The delay has been due entirely to the delay in the delivery of the mail from Prince Albert, the delay being caused through the almost impassible condition of the roads. Enclosed herewith you will find - (a) a plan of the La Ronge settlement as received from the Surveyor General, and (b) a rough sketch of the additional land desired. The land at present attached to the school as stated in your letter, is Lots 9 and 12, or a total of 84.6 acres. From the rough sketch submitted by Mr. Principal Fisher, you will see that the additional land desired lies immediately behind these two Lots.

The Principal states that "quite a lot of the area shown is muskeg, and parts are too stony to do very much with", but, he expresses the opinion that at least twenty-five acres could be found, which, if cleared, would be suitable for cultivation.

I beg to recommend that the whole section, one mile square as indicated on the Principal's sketch, be added to the school property. The hay and wood problems at this school are an annual burden of anxiety to our...
Society, and I have good reason to believe that this burden will be considerably lightened if the additional land is provided, and we can receive some help from your Department in having it surveyed and cleared. I commend this request to your early and sympathetic consideration and remain,

Your obedient servant,

T.B.R.W.

Field Secretary, M.S.O.C.

P.S. I shall be obliged if you will let me have the plan of the La Ronge settlement back again when you have finished with it. T.B.R.W.
Ottawa, February 22, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with enclosures, relative to additional land for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I am arranging to have the school's needs placed before the Provincial Government, and you will receive an additional letter at a later date. I am returning the plan of the settlement.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D. D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. G.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
25th February 1932

Sir,

The Missionary Society of the Church of England have an Indian residential school established on Lots 9 and 12 of the Lac La Ronge Settlement. The school finds itself handicapped for lack of land for agriculture and a scarcity in the supply of wood. For the better prosecution of their work among the Indians they are requesting that a parcel of land containing slightly more than one square mile be secured for their use.

The lands are described as:- Commencing at the North-East corner of Settlement Lot No. 13; thence North 65 degrees 58 minutes East along the North boundaries of Lots 2, 3, 6, 5 and 4 to the North-East corner of Lot 4; thence North 24 degrees and 2 minutes West at right angles 80 chains; thence South 65 degrees 58 minutes West 80 chains and 80 links; thence South 24 degrees and 2 minutes East 80 chains, more or less, to the place of beginning, containing seven hundred and ten acres, more or less.

It is stated that a very considerable portion of the land is muskeg and parts are too stony to be of much use but that about 25 acres of cultivable land may be found, the remaining portion is required for wood and pasture.

Enclosed is a plan of Lac La Ronge Settlement which shows the situation of the parcel. May I request your Government to have this land set aside for the use of the Industrial School?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

John Barnett Esq.,
Deputy Minister
Department of Natural Resources
Regina, Sask.

CANADA
Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 24th ultimo, wherein you make mention that the Missionary Society of the Church of England have an Indian Resident School established on Lots 9 and 12 of the Lac la Ronge settlement, and they request that an area of slightly more than one square mile adjoining the above mentioned lots be set aside for their use owing to a lack of land for agriculture and a scarcity in the supply of wood.

In reply thereto I wish to advise that after taking into consideration the possibilities of further development in the Lac la Ronge district in the future and also that we have established a policy whereby hunters, trappers and fishermen are charged permit fees and dues for cabin sites and rental for land which they may require for grazing and cultivation purposes, also that it is necessary for us at all times to bear in mind the need of other settlers in the community, we find that we are unable to grant the request to alienate lands for an extensive area for the purpose mentioned.

However, if the authorities of this Society desire to apply for a permit for cultivation and grazing on certain areas the application can be further considered. The annual rental for the area to be cultivated would be at 50¢ per acre and the grazing 2¢ per acre.

At the present time we grant free permits to institutions of this nature in the northern parts of the Province to cut 25 cords free of dues. In excess of this amount the dues are at the rate of 10¢ per cord for fire killed or dry timber and 15¢ a cord for green poplar, other species are permitted at the regular rate of dues.

Yours faithfully,

John Barnett
Deputy Minister of Natural Resources.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
March 17, 1932.

Dear Mr. Barnett:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to this Department's application for a parcel of land at Lac la Ronge, for the use of the Indian Residential School there. Perhaps I did not make it clear that this is a government-owned institution and that the request is that title to the parcel be in the Federal Crown. This school has over 100 children in residence and they are given a vocational as well as an academic training. At all these schools, there is a good-sized farm, for example, at the Qu'Appelle Indian School at Lebret, 1120 acres. There are over 700 acres in the farms at the Round Lake School, near Stockholm, and at the Indian Residential School at Duck Lake. I may say that at 9 of the 14 Indian residential schools in Saskatchewan this Department has title to farms which are not Indian reserves.

Although this parcel is not required as an Indian reserve, it is considered necessary in connection with the administration of the school, and, under the terms of Treaty 10, the Crown is under obligation to maintain educational institutions for the Indians. In fact, it is mere accident that a farm was not set aside for this school by His Excellency the Governor in Council some years ago, before the return of the natural resources.

I should be grateful if you would review the matter in this light and give this application on behalf of our wards favourable consideration.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

John Barnett, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Natural Resources,
Regina, Sask.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

With reference to your letter of February 22, 1932, #132-2-9, in which you stated that our request for additional land for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School was being placed before the Provincial Government of Saskatchewan, I shall be obliged if you can let me know at an early date, if our request has been granted. Our Commission are anxious to have the farming activities at this school extended, in order to reduce the heavy cost of maintenance, but they are finding this quite impossible with the limited area attached to the school at present.

A prompt reply will oblige,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

TBRW/W Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, May 12, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the application for additional land for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. The Department has been in correspondence with the Deputy Minister of Natural Resources for Saskatchewan, and I am hopeful that we will receive a Provincial Crown grant for the parcel in question. Even if our application is unsuccessful, we would, no doubt, be able to secure a permit for cultivation and grazing purposes, or we could arrange to purchase what is needed. In view of these facts and the location of the school, I think it quite safe for the Reverend Principal to proceed with any farming activities he wishes. Of course, it would be advisable for him to confine his activity to that section of the parcel requested, which is nearest the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,

WINNIPEG, MAN.
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In the report which Col. Mermagen, Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission presented after his visit to the Lac la Ronge School last month, he refers to the urgent need of having more land cleared, and especially the land in the immediate vicinity of the school, in order that a greater acreage might be available for raising garden produce. As this land is very stony, and can only be made fit for cultivation by removing the stones, and drawing soil from a considerable distance, the Commission felt that they could not undertake so great a work without some financial assistance. After consultation with the Principal, the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer was of the opinion that the sum of $400.00 would be required to accomplish this work, and I was instructed to ask your Department to authorize this expenditure. As the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of the Commission spoke very highly of the work which is being accomplished in every department of this school's activities, our Commission are keenly desirous of encouraging the school management by supplying their needs to the fullest extent of their power, and if your Department can undertake the clearing of the land, so that it may be in readiness for seeding next summer, you will render a very valuable and timely contribution to the work.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Mr. Murison:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools which I inspected during the time I was Paying Officer for the Ile a la Croese Agency.

LAC LA RONGE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I find the nature of the land here is not adaptable for cultivation and the Principal informs me that it is only with some effort on the part of this institution that enables them to maintain what little stock they have. In this I concur.

In going over the land I was forcibly impressed with the fact that this institution will never support its staff and members by any produce derived therefrom, regardless of the amount of labour expended in any attempt to do so. While here, I was questioned concerning a further grant of land to them.

(Sgd.) S. H. Simpson,
Paying Officer.
Sir:

I beg to forward a report on the schools included in the Isle a la Crosse agency, submitted by the Paying Officer for this year, Mr. S. H. Simpson.

LAC LA RONGE RES. SCHOOL.

You will note he mentions that he was questioned regarding a further grant of land to them. I took this matter up quite fully last year, looked over the ground, and made a recommendation regarding land which might be set aside. This is a matter which I think should receive some attention before it is too late to secure suitable land. There is very little fit for cultivation in that whole area and it is important, if this school is to be continued, that sufficient arable land be secured upon which to grow the feed requirements of the stock belonging to the institution.

(Sgd.) W. Murison,
Inspector.
6th October 1932

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Minister of Natural Resources

REGINA, Saskatchewan,
March 6th, 1946

The Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

As you have no doubt been informed, the Provincial Government has undertaken certain development work in the Lac la Ronge area. This program will be extended this year and will require an adequate supply of building material.

Last year an arrangement was made with the Principal of the Indian Residential School, Mr. Fisher, to recondition the sawmill located at the point mentioned for the purpose of sawing lumber for our immediate needs as it was difficult to get new equipment in due to the roads at that season of the year being impassible, and time was also a definite factor.

This mill had been used by the Native People and due to mismanagement, had deteriorated to such a point where it was almost completely wrecked. The boiler was in fairly good shape.

The agreement was that we were to pay rental for the mill and charge this to the costs of repair and rebuilding. We were later informed that the mill belonged to the Department of Indian Affairs.

As we will require additional building material for this coming year, and have a crew of Indians getting out logs for this purpose at the present time, we are desirous of knowing whether or not your Department would be interested in selling this mill, and if so, at what price.

We have an opportunity to purchase a used mill in good condition, which can be moved in. However, in order to do this, a definite decision will have to be made at an early date as the spring break-up within the next two or three weeks will make it impossible to provide transportation until the middle of the summer.

....If a ..........
If a satisfactory deal can be made with your Department, it is felt that it would be needless to take in a second mill as there is not sufficient timber to justify such action.

The mill would have to be moved to a new site as at the present time it is extremely difficult to get the logs out of the water and over the rocks. In addition, all the bed pieces are rotted and there would have to be a complete new foundation.

In the majority of cases last year we used Indian labor to cut the logs as well as do the main work around the mill. Their services proved quite satisfactory. We did some custom sawing for several of them, which provided lumber for their own requirements. We would be prepared to continue doing this for the local residents. In fact, we would encourage them to get out sufficient logs to enable each of them to build himself a house. In this way new living quarters would be provided, the only cost being the work of getting the logs out. Payment for sawing could be made by working at the mill. In other words, no cash outlay whatever would be required on their part. We are most anxious to assist these people in becoming self-supporting and see they are encouraged to help themselves.

Due to the transportation difficulties previously mentioned, we will appreciate your early attention to this matter.

Yours very truly,

J. L. Phelps
Minister of Natural Resources & Industrial Development

SINCE dictating this communication Mr. Phelps has taken the 'flu and is therefore unable to sign same.

I enclose, for your information, copy of a letter received by Mr. Hoey from the Minister of Natural Resources for the province of Saskatchewan. Please let me have your comments on this letter as soon as possible, in order that Mr. Hoey can reply to the letter.

When writing you might also let us have definite information regarding the matter about which you spoke to me on the occasion of your last visit to this office. I refer to the provincial trucks crossing the property of the Lac la Ronge School when proceeding to and from the fish curing plant on Lac la Ronge.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend H.A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary,
Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
38-43 The Bible House,
184 Alexander Avenue East,
Winnipeg, Man.
January 16th, 1946.

The Secretary,
Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission,
M.S.C.C., The Bible House,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

You will have already received a copy the Hon. J.L. Phelps letter to me, dated January 12th, 1946. This letter was received by me today. I enclose for your information, a copy of my reply.

Let me say first of all, that we are in a difficult position, in which the Government has the whip hand.

We are the victims of a mistake made in the past, for which we must pay dearly.

My understanding is, that when the survey was made, which was in the time of the Rev. C.F. Hives, the sawmill stood in front of the school, on the land which is now used as the road. I understand that a "Gentleman's Agreement" (whatever that may mean) was entered into by Mr. Hives and the Surveyor, and instead of the road being surveyed along the Lake shore, where it should have been from the first, the road was carried across the school garden. Our warehouse stands over one of the official survey posts. From there it cuts diagonally across the school garden to a point of the veranda of the Principal's residence in passing. A more senseless arrangement could have never been made. But I suppose no-one ever thought of a Lac la Ronge Townsite then.

It would appear that we have much to lose, unless some satisfactory arrangement can be made with the Government. If the Government (meaning Mr. Phelps) should decide to follow the old survey, then our position here would be no longer tenable. To my mind there can be no question whatever of selling the Government land for the road. We will have to give whatever is required for that purpose, in order to save the area within our fences. Regarding the other part, I feel it would be to the Commission's advantage if an official of the Commission would come up to Lac la Ronge, and look over the whole situation. It would be so much easier to view things on the spot. Trucks are coming in from Prince Albert almost every day, and there would be no difficulty getting in and out. John Friesen would be glad to bring in whoever may come. I feel that this matter is urgent.
There is one other thing I feel I should say, and I have this on good authority. Mr. Phelps is a little misleading when he said that the Hudson's Bay Co. is giving them land for $1.00 per acre. This is true, but he does not say that the Hudson's Bay Co. is also retaining a certain amount of land which they plan to cut up into lots and which be leased to those who desire them.

I am attaching a very rough plan of our property, that is the block upon which the school and garden area, and you will see at once just where we stand.

Hoping to have an early reply from you on this matter,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
G.W. Fisher,
Principal.
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan  
Indian Affairs Branch,  
Department of Mines And Resources,  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of March 9th,  
132-2-9, enclosing a copy of a letter from the Minister of  
Natural Resources for the Province of Saskatchewan. I am  
glad to take the opportunity of laying before the Department  
various questions in connection with this school property  
which are being raised by the Provincial Government.

(1) The School Saw-mill: I have before me a letter from our  
Principal dated January 14, 1945, speaking of the visit of  
the Hon. Mr. Phelps and his suggestion about buying or renting  
the school saw-mill. Our Principal wrote as if the mill be-  
longed to us and we were in a position to sell it if we de-  
sired. He recommended that a sale should be negotiated in  
view of the increasing difficulties experienced in operating  
this mill. On the other hand, he was ready to accept the sug-  
gestion of Mr. Phelps that the mill should be taken over "on  
a rental basis with the government making the necessary re-  
pairs and charging the cost of same against the rental charge  
per operating hour of $1.50 per hour." At that time we auth-  
orized Mr. Fisher to secure the best possible price for a sale  
or to rent the mill on the proposed basis. It is a little  
difficult for us to find out how this mill was purchased in  
the first place but we readily agreed with the Principal that  
the time has passed when it was wise or profitable for our  
school to engage in milling operations.

(2) Property: We have been negotiating with Mr. Phelps in re-  
gard to the property on which our school is located. He de-  
sired to purchase a substantial portion of the land to enable  
the Provincial Government to carry out some of its program of  
development. The price suggested was $1.00 per acre in view  
of the fact that the land was to be used for public purposes.
and it was stated that the Hudson's Bay Co. were prepared to relinquish part of their property on these terms. We felt unwilling to do anything which would in any way interfere with the interests of our school, but declared that in principle we were prepared to co-operate with any plans for the good of the community provided our own interests were safeguarded. We were uncertain as to the ownership of this particular property and have been in communication with the Land Titles Offices in Regina and Prince Albert and also with the Diocese of Saskatchewan, as one of our early missions was established at this point and it seemed probable that the Church had been in possession of the land for a considerable time. I now have, through your kindness, a copy of the Order in Council, PC689 dated May 4th, 1925, in which lots 12 and 9 were transferred to the control of the Dept. of Indian Affairs. We are suggesting to Mr. Phelps that, from this point, he should negotiate with you in regard to this whole question.

I am enclosing a plan of the settlement showing the location of lots 12 and 9. On a recent visit to Lac la Ronge, I learned that the Hudson's Bay Co. possesses lot 13 and that the land desired over-laps that lot and the western portion of lot 12 on which the school is situated. I found that the inner portion of lot 12 is of very little value as it largely consists of muskeg and swamp. It would be possible, however, to dispose of part of the bush area nearest to lot 13 without jeopardizing our interests in any way.

(3) Road: The attached rough plan, copied from a sketch sent by the Principal, will illustrate the road question which has also been raised. In this connection, I am enclosing a copy of a letter from Principal Fisher dated January 16th, 1946. It is strange that a road could have been surveyed in this manner but I take it that the desire was to go up to higher ground as at times the lake has risen considerably and a road nearer the shore might be affected. You will note that the trail continually used at present by the trucks which frequently go to and from the fish filleting plant passes through the middle of the boys' playground and then between some of the school buildings. Mr. Phelps has held out the prospect of a new survey and an alternative road passing between the church and the lake and then continuing between the school garden and the shore as indicated. This would be probably more expensive, as a certain amount of filling would be necessary at the corner of the school garden where a well is situated. There is, however, an abundant supply of rock lying around the shore for this purpose. In consideration of having the road constructed in this manner, we would certainly be prepared to recommend that some portion of the land might be turned over as requested.

(4) Day School: It will be recalled that the small building shown on the plan east of the Principal's residence was constructed in the first place for hospital purposes. The Dep-
artment made a grant of a few hundred dollars at the time and our Commission has spent a good deal more from time to time. It was not found practicable to operate a hospital and for a number of years we have operated a day-school. The Provincial Government gave a grant of about $500.00 a year and we employed an additional teacher who had charge of this day-school for non-treaty and white children in the community. She also gave some service in the school as a member of the staff. The new Provincial Government took this school over entirely and has rented the building from us. We had enlarged it to take two classes and there are now two teachers. The school is being administered by a local Board and we are receiving a rental for the property. The Director of Northern Education, Mr. A. Piercy, is now pressing us to sell this building and about an acre of land around it for playground purposes. He has ambitious plans for building a large day-school, possibly with three rooms, but for the present desires to take over the present building and enlarge it. We have pointed out that we are not in a position to sell this building as the Indian Department has an equity in it. On the other hand, our Principal has suggested that it will be necessary for us to operate a third class-room for day pupils, as a number of treaty families are likely to move into the settlement by reason of developments taking place. He has suggested that we might agree to sell the building and construct a new class-room with the proceeds.

These various matters have been rather perplexing to us and we are not very happy at the whole situation, as our experience suggests that an Indian boarding school is better in a quiet place than in a developing community. We have been informed that the Provincial authorities plan to develop Lac la Ronge for tourist purposes by reason of the good fishing, that they intend to build a large boarding school for non-treaty children and also a hospital, and that our land is really required for these purposes.

I trust that these matters have been clearly outlined and shall be happy to supply any additional information to enable decisions to be reached.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood
Secretary.
Ottawa, March 23, 1946.

Dear Mr. Phelps:

I regret the delay that has occurred in replying to your letter of March 6th, in which you discuss the advisability of purchasing or renting the sawmill located at the Lac la Ronge residential school.

The records here indicate that this sawmill was not purchased from Parliamentary appropriations and is consequently the property of the Church authorities, probably the property of the M.S.C.C. Any agreement, therefore, that may be reached between your department and the Church authorities for either the purchase of this sawmill or its use on a rental basis will be satisfactory to this department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

The Honourable J. L. Phelps,
Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, March 22, 1946.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to certain matters affecting the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

The Director has written to the Minister of Natural Resources for Saskatchewan to the effect that our records indicate that the sawmill at the Lac la Ronge School was not purchased from Parliamentary Appropriation and consequently can be considered the property of the Church Authorities. It is therefore in order for you to make whatever arrangements you desire for the sale of this sawmill to the Saskatchewan Government.

I have also discussed with Mr. Hoey the question of the road. He feels that it would be advisable for the M.S.C.C. to have someone go to Lac la Ronge in connection with these various matters. While proceeding there, your representative could call at the Saskatchewan Government offices and discuss the matter with the Minister. At the same time, your representative could call on our Inspector of Indian Agencies, Mr. Ostrander, whose headquarters are in Regina. In making the above suggestion, we feel that it will save both time and effort to have personal interviews.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sirs:

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan
Re: Lac la Ronge, Indian School

I beg to acknowledge your letter 132-2-9 of March 22.

I have today received additional confirmation of the fact that the sawmill at our School was purchased in the first instance with Church funds. We shall accordingly advise the Saskatchewan Government in regard to this.

I fully agree that the method of personal conference is advisable in regard to the other property questions that have been raised. You will recall that I made a special visit to Lac la Ronge at the beginning of February and my personal recommendations have already been made to you. As the property is in the name of the Crown I felt that I was not in a position to negotiate further with the Provincial Government. It is not easy for me to visit Regina at present but I may be able to do so about the middle of next month when I plan to visit our schools in the Calgary area. I am a little afraid that the Hon. Mr. Phelps will desire action earlier than this as the season appears to be advanced and work at Lac la Ronge may be possible in the near future. I shall communicate with Mr. Phelps and endeavour to arrive at some definite conclusions with him.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Secretary.
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

For some time past we have been negotiating with the Indian and Eskimo Residential School at Lac la Ronge, as well as the Hudson Bay Company in an effort to secure portions of the lots in that settlement to use in the expansion programme of this Department. The Government contemplates considerable development work in this area in the near future, which will require additional properties.

The Hudson Bay Company have offered to turn over to the Department a substantial block of the land held by them in this particular area. When it came to dealing with the Residential School, Mr. Fisher, the Principal was quite willing to exceed our request, as he felt they had a great deal more land than they would ever require for their own use. However, when the matter was investigated it was discovered that Lots 12 and 9, comprising 76.7 and 8.10 acres respectively, were transferred to the Department of Indian Affairs by Order-in-Council on May 4th, 1925.

We would, therefore, appreciate having your Department transfer back to us, providing the Residential School is agreeable, approximately 50 acres contained in the above mentioned lots. Please be assured that we are quite prepared to allow the School to retain the area in Lot 12 required for the maintenance of their Institution.

We will have our Surveyors go in and make the necessary new surveys, which would include changing the location of the present road, which by the way passes through the center of the school property; in fact some of their main buildings are built on the road survey. However, the Department is quite prepared to have a road diversion constructed and bear the cost of same.

Your early reply in this regard would be greatly appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

J. L. Phelps,
Minister of Natural Resources & Industrial Development.
Ottawa, April 1, 1946.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

Today we received a letter from Honourable J. L. Phelps, Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development for the Province of Saskatchewan, requesting us to transfer to the Provincial Department approximately 50 acres of the land contained in Lots 12 and 9, the present site of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. His letter reads in part as follows:

"Please be assured that we are quite prepared to allow the School to retain the area in Lot 12 required for the maintenance of their Institution.

"We will have our Surveyors go in and make the necessary new surveys, which would include changing the location of the present road, which by the way passes through the center of the school property; in fact some of their main buildings are built on the road survey. However, the Department is quite prepared to have a road diversion constructed and bear the cost of same."

I discussed Mr. Phelps' letter with Mr. Hoey this afternoon and he suggested that I write to you immediately and ascertain your views in the matter. It appears, from your letter of March 16, that you might not be opposed to transferring to the Provincial Government the land that they desire.

If 50 acres were transferred, it would only leave approximately 25 acres for school purposes. Possibly this is enough in that section of the country. In the event of your consenting to our transferring the land, would it be advisable

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your 132-2-9 of the first and have read with interest the letter quoted from the honourable J. L. Phelps of Saskatchewan.

Our Commission will be agreeable to the transfer of a substantial portion of the school property but before agreeing to disposing of fifty acres I feel we should have the assurance of our Principal that the interests of the Residential School will be safe-guarded. From the plan which I sent you on March 16th, you will observe that lots 12 and 9 comprise eighty-five acres in all. However, the inland portion of lots 12 consists of muskeg of very doubtful value. It was in my mind that the Provincial Government desired probably twenty-five acres adjoining lot 13. Unless they are prepared to accept the area which we have described as muskeg it is plain that they will have to take portions on both sides of the school and this may hem us in considerably. It was estimated by our Principal that possibly one-third of the section of lot 12 on which the school stands was really unfit for use. You will understand, therefore, my hesitation to give an unqualified agreement to the transfer of so much ground.

Would it be sufficient for the present to give tentative approval of the proposal but with the reservation that the surveyors should give the Principal full information and that his agreement should be necessary before the final decision is made and the fencing of the school property on the new basis is undertaken. Only when the survey has been made and the extent of what will be left to the school is clearly known would it be possible to say definitely that we are satisfied. We can communicate with the school by telegraph and there need be no delay at all in reaching the final decision. I certainly feel that the Provincial Government should be asked to fence off the school property and am confident they can plan the new road in such a manner as to leave us in a stronger position.

I trust that this somewhat uncertain reply may be of some value and that the matter may be brought to a satisfactory conclusion.

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood

Secretary.
Ottawa, April 5, 1946.

Dear Mr. Phelps:

I am in receipt of your letter of March 27, with reference to securing approximately 50 acres of land at Lac la Ronge.

As you know, Lots 9 and 12 of Lac la Ronge Settlement were transferred to this Department on May 4, 1925, to be used for the purposes of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

While we have no desire to impede any new plans that your Department may have at the present time, I feel you will agree that it is my duty to safeguard the interests of our Indian residential schools. Before submitting your proposal to my Minister, I require additional information.

The Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada operates the Lac la Ronge School for this Department and before definitely agreeing to sell 50 acres of the land intended for the purposes of the school, I believe we should have the assurance of the Principal that the interests of the Residential School will be fully protected.

Some of the land which we own is of little use and possibly this is the portion which you desire to secure. However, it may be possible that you wish the land on both sides of the school and, if so, it might interfere seriously with the successful operation of the school.

I am prepared to recommend to my Minister that

The Honourable J. L. Phelps,
Minister of Natural Resources
and Industrial Development,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

.... tentative
tentative approval be given to your proposal but with the reservation that your surveyor should give the Principal full information regarding the portion of the land which you require and that his agreement would be necessary before a final decision is made. There would be a further condition that in the event of our transferring land to you the line fence between your property and ours would be constructed at the cost of the Provincial Government. You might also let me know what price per acre your Department is prepared to pay for this land.

Yours very truly,

Mr. R. A. Hoey,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am writing to you on behalf of our Church property at Lac la Ronge. Recently the Provincial Government has been endeavouring to purchase land which really belongs to our Residential School at this point. I also understand that there has been correspondence between our Indian Residential School Commission and the Saskatchewan Government in this matter. In a letter recently received by the Principal of our school at Lac la Ronge, there was a quotation from a letter written by the Honorable, Mr. Phelps. This quotation is really part of a statement received from your Branch by our Commission, and it reads in part:

"I have now through your kindness a copy of the Order in Council, PC689 dated May 4th, 1925, in which lots 12 and 9, were transferred to the control of the Department of Indian Affairs."

My reason in writing to you is that our Church and mission house both stand on lot 12, and I am anxious that this particular piece of land should be safe-guarded for our Church. It is my understanding that some years ago our Indian Residential School Commission handed over to the Diocese of Saskatchewan this Church site. In view of the above information, I am anxious to know what steps, if any, I should take on behalf of this Diocese to make sure that our interest will be properly safeguarded in the future. It is most apparent that the present Provincial Government is most active in our north country, and they have many schemes on foot. Lac la Ronge in particular seems to be one of their main points of activity, hence my anxiety.

Sorry to bother you but I know you will help me with your sagacious advice. With kindest regards,

I am, faithfully yours,

[Signature]

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
THE INDIAN AND ESKIMO RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL COMMISSION

of the

Missionary Society of the Church of England, Canada.

March 27th, 1946.

Mr. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Federal Department of Mines & Resources,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

Re: All Saints' Indian Residential School,
Lac la Ronge, Sask.

We have been in correspondence with the Minister of Natural Resources for Saskatchewan in regard to various property matters concerning the above school, which we administer for the Indian Affairs Branch. I have laid the whole matter fully before the Director after making a special visit to Lac la Ronge to gain first-hand information. I have now received a letter from Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, suggesting a visit to your city to talk the matter over with the Hon. J.L. Phelps, and also with yourself. I have also just heard from our Principal, the Rev. G.W. Fisher, to the effect that Indian Agent Jones has been spending a few days at the school and is sending a report to you.

I may say that the Provincial Government commenced by asking us to sell part of Lot 12 on which the school is located as they wished to carry out various developments. The offer was made to give us equivalent land elsewhere by way of exchange. After considerable difficulty we have found that the land is not ours to sell, as it was formally transferred to the Indian Affairs Department in 1925. I, therefore, turned the question over to the Director with an expression of opinion that we could readily part with the western portion of Lot 12 without any injury to the interests of the school.

A further question concerns the Day School building which has been regarded as the property of the Church and for which the Director of Northern Education, Mr. Pierce, of Prince Albert, has offered us the sum of $500.00. He also desired an acre or so of ground around it for playground purposes. We have, of course, nothing to say about the sale of the land but apparently the building is mainly the property of the Church, although an initial grant of $200.00 was made by the Indian Department at a time when a small infirmary was contemplated. We have operated a day school in the building, with the Provincial Government giving a grant which fluctuated in value but never covered the cost. Under the new Government a local board has been set up and the Day School is now being administered

Provincially with a rental of $20.00...
Provincially with a rental of $20.00 now being paid to us. In principle, we are prepared to sell this building but believe the price should be at least $1,000.00 in view of the cost of construction. If the building should be sold we can see no difficulty in recommending to the Indian Department that a small portion of land should also be disposed of as our school interests would not in any way be affected.

The third matter concerns a sawmill which is the property of the Church but at the present time is rented to the Provincial Government. The Hon. J.L. Phelps wrote to Ottawa on March 6th offering to buy this mill and the matter has been referred back to us as the Department is aware that it is our property. I have already informed Mr. Phelan that the Church is prepared to sell this mill at a fair price, but Principal Fisher's letter now suggests that your Department may wish to obtain possession of the mill for the benefit of the Indians. He said that Agent Jones would be writing to you in regard to this. There is a further question concerning a road. At present a road has been surveyed which cuts through our property and would represent a very serious difficulty and hazard if it should be constructed. Mr. Phelps has been giving consideration to a new survey which would carry the road along the Lake front to the Fish Plant which has been established. If this is done it will be possible to fence our school property and prevent trucks travelling through the children's playground and some of the buildings as is the case at the present time.

I trust that I have made this tangled matter reasonably clear and venture to suggest that you may be able to confer with the Hon. J.L. Phelps after receiving your report from Agent Jones. It is quite out of the question for me to leave the city for some time to come and I know that the Provincial Government is most anxious to proceed with its development program at Lac la Ronge at the earliest possible date. I can only reiterate that as far as Church property is concerned we are fully prepared to dispose of what is desired if it will further the plans of the Provincial Government, and if the various items can be disposed of without hurting the interests of our Residential School.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Sgd. H. A. Alderwood,
Secretary.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I have received a letter from Reverend H.A. Alderwood, D.D., Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Missionary Society, Church of England in Canada, in connection with some matters relating to the Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge and the Government of the Province of Saskatchewan.

I am enclosing herewith copy of letter referred to. Also enclosed is a plan of the Lac la Ronge settlement showing thereon Lot 12 referred to in Dr. Alderwood's letter. School buildings, grounds, and gardens, are situated on both sides of the highway in about the centre of Lot 12.

As the Department is aware, the present main building of this school is an old building and a fire trap. It should be replaced either by another residential school or a number of day schools at various points now being served by the residential school. If it is replaced by another residential school I believe the site should be changed as the total area held by the school is about 80 acres and most of it poor for farming purposes.

With this point in consideration, and in view of the fact that there is no other land available immediately surrounding the present buildings, making it impossible to commence farming or to grow sufficient feed for livestock, it will no doubt be necessary to erect the new residential school (if one is erected) at a different site. Consequently I see no reason why negotiations should not be entered into with the Provincial Government with a view to surrendering to them part of Lot 12 with a promise from them to give us an equal or larger acreage at a more suitable point when the decision is made to build a new school.

I have had a discussion with the Honourable J.L. Phelps in this connection and he seems quite willing to co-operate with us in any reasonable manner.

With regard to that part of Dr. Alderwood's letter which refers to the road it is quite evident that a road will have to be erected somewhere along or near the lake front thereby cutting through the Department property at some point. I do not see how this can be avoided.

Referring to that part.......
Referring to that part of Dr. Alderwood's letter which refers to the sawmill, I have already written the Department in this connection, my letter of the 1st instant, No. 499-303-4A. Please instruct me regarding further negotiations with the Provincial Government authorities in connection with the matters referred to herein.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Federal Building, Regina, Sask.

Further to our telephone conversation re: the Saw Mill at
Lac la Ronge.

This outfit consists of a power unit of one Watrous 20 H.P.
Engine, one 25 H.P. Boiler (Twin Units), one Brantford log carriage and
one Planer.

The Rev. George Fisher stated that to the best of his knowledge
this equipment was purchased for the late Archdeacon McKay out of money
appropriated by the Department to build the present Indian Residential School
at Lac la Ronge, for the purpose of sawing lumber for the school.

Since that time the mill has been used for sawing lumber for the
Indians, and some lumber has been sawn for outsiders, including the Hudson's
Bay Company, (when building their new warehouse in 1941). The following
amounts of lumber were put through the mill, as mentioned above, during the
past five years as taken from the Mill books:

| Year | Amount |
|------|--------|
| 1940 | 56,196 feet. |
| 1941 | 47,940 feet. |
| 1942 | 18,000 feet. |
| 1943 | 30,725 feet. |
| 1944 | 71,000 feet. |

In 1945 Mr. Fisher rented the outfit to officials of the Provincial
Government at the following rates: $1.50 per hour for the use of the mill and
$.75¢ per hour for the use of the planer.

Enclosed herewith is a complete statement covering this transaction
which was prepared by officials of the Provincial Government at Lac la Ronge.
You will note that all repairs, replacements and time used to clean up the
site was deducted from the rental dues outlined above for the use of the equip-
ment.

I feel that the mill has served the Indians well, and can continue
to do so for many years to come, consequently Mr. Fisher and myself do not favour
selling the mill. The matter was also taken up with the Indians, they are also
of the same opinion. I find some of the Indians did have lumber sawn in 1945,
and also found two Indians who took in logs amounting to approximately 4,000 feet,
who lost their logs, lumber, and all. However, I have hopes of straightening this
out.

Sgd. E.S. Jones,
Indian Agent.

Your letter of April 5th was received and the contents noted.

acre. The same arrangement in this case would be quite acceptable to us.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I beg to acknowledge your 132-2-9 of the 13th and am glad to know the present position of this matter.

We have just received word from our Principal that Mr. C. Piercy, Director of Northern Education for the Provincial Government, has again been in Lac la Ronge and is most anxious to secure possession of the day-school building and the land on which it stands. Our Commission has now agreed to sell this building for $500 but have pointed out that we have nothing to do with the land. I believe the plan which I sent you showed that the day-school building is east of our school and, in our judgment, this strip of land could be transferred.

Mr. Fisher advises us, however, of a further difficulty concerning the sawmill which stands on this strip of land near to the lake. We were quite willing to sell this and to divest ourselves of all responsibility for it. However, our Principal informs us that Indian Agent Jones, on a recent visit, was rather opposed to this suggestion and felt that it would be well to retain possession of the sawmill as the Indians have always had a good deal of benefit from it and there might be a good deal of new building in the near future. If we are to retain possession, it would seem to be advisable that the land on which the mill stands should not be transferred to the Provincial Government.

Our Principal raises the further question in regard to the land between our school and the Hudson's Bay Company property. There is a supply of wood on this which he would like to cut for school purposes and expresses the hope that in any agreement this may be provided for.
I trust that these tangled matters may soon be settled to the satisfaction of all concerned.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of April 16th regarding the transfer of part of our school lands to the Saskatchewan Government. This letter did not reach me until yesterday due to the curtailment of air-mail service on account of seasonal ice conditions. Hence I could not reply sooner.

Both the Indian Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C., and myself have been quite willing to transfer part of our school lands to the Provincial Government for its development projects, so long as an adequate amount of land is left for our own use. But we have not been satisfied with the price offered. It is true that the H.B. Co. is willing to accept $1.00 per acre for the land it transfers, but it should be remembered that the Company has an ulterior motive in wishing to keep the settlement as near as possible to its store. We have no such motive. In fact the coming of the settlement will add to our school problems.

Since the land would appear to be at the disposition of the Indian Affairs Branch, it would appear that the Department would have the final word in this matter. As I am working under the direction of the Indian Residential School Commission as it affects us, the Commission would have to give approval as far the School is concerned. I am, therefore, writing to Dr. Alderwood asking him to write you again on this matter.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, No. 132-2-9, enclosing copy of a letter the Department has received from Reverend G.W. Fisher, Principal of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, with particular reference to the transfer of part of the school lands to the Provincial Government.

I may say that following the receipt of Department letter of the 26th ultimo, No. 132-2-9, I discussed with Honourable J.L. Phelps the matters under consideration. Mr. Phelps informed me that he is not certain that the Provincial Government will now require the land as he is awaiting the report of his town planner after he makes a survey of conditions at the present Lac la Ronge Village to decide on the possibilities of development on the present site surrounding the residential school. Mr. Phelps states it is possible that a decision will be made to move the town site to another point on the shore of the lake.

If Mr. Phelps decides to make formal application for part of the Indian school lands the question of the value of the lands to be transferred could then be discussed. While I believe that $1.00 per acre, which the Hudson's Bay Company is willing to accept, is very low, I do not think that a very high price should be set even though it may eventually be in a town site. I am reasonably certain that the town site will not be established on the land surrounding the Lac la Ronge Residential School unless our Department first consents to relinquish a part of the school lands to the Provincial Government. If the Provincial Government is not assured of part of the school lands there is no doubt that they will decide to establish the town at another point on the lake shore. As previously stated, there is some possibility of this being done even if the Provincial Government is assured of the transfer of part of our land. I shall write the Department further after I have heard further from the Honourable J.L. Phelps in the matter.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your survey presently under way at Lac la Ronge I am including in this letter extracts from a memorandum received from our Principal at the Anglican Indian Residential School, Lac la Ronge.

"With further reference to the pending land surrender to the Saskatchewan Government, I would report that a preliminary survey is now being made, and it would appear to me that this survey is being made without much consideration being given to ourselves.

"Yesterday I was talking with the young man who is making this survey, and from what he told me, and what I could see of his operations, their plans call for the road passing between the Church and the School, and after making a slight turn, through our garden parallel to the school building.

"I pointed out that if they take much of our garden, we will not have very much worth-while left. It was suggested that possibly Government machinery could move the good soil to another place. But as I pointed out unless a considerable amount of work was done, the rest of our land was unsuitable for a garden.

"Later I saw the head of the surveying party, and tried to get more definite information as to what was going to be done. His attitude seemed to be that the land was Government property, (and while he did not say this) you in Winnipeg did not need to be considered. I hope I am wrong in this opinion. He did emphasize that this was but a preliminary survey, and that I should not be unduly worried."
"about things; and that our needs would be considered, but I do know that the suggested route of the road fits in very well with the present plans for the townsite, and that in the eyes of some of the people of Lac la Ronge our needs and prior rights do not matter."

As our Principal seems somewhat alarmed, unduly we hope, may we ask that you give consideration to our position at Lac la Ronge and protect our interests as you outlined in your letter to Mr. Hoey, written April 12th, 1946.

Yours very truly,

With further reference to my letter of May 20th, File 790-303-11 AGE, I have just returned from a visit to the Lac la Ronge School. While at the school I went over the property accompanied by Mr. Bereskin, of the Surveys Branch of the Department of Natural Resources.

No good purpose would be served in continuing to hold the school property referred to in the plan as Lot 13 and containing approximately 76 acres. The whole of this property is either solid rock or muskeg and it would be a great mistake to ever consider building another school on the property. I therefore told Mr. Bereskin to proceed with the subdivision of all but 7 acres into town lots. The survey will be at the expense of the Department of Natural Resources. The 7 acres referred to contain all of the Department buildings, playgrounds, and garden. The garden is 2½ acres which was made useful by hauling soil as there was no soil in which to have a garden.

I would recommend that the school property, with the exception of the 7 acres, be sold to the Provincial Government at $1.00 an acre with the understanding that the 7 acres, including 2½ acres of garden, will not be disturbed until it is possible to erect a suitable residential school in another year or two.

Arrangements might be made with the Department of Natural Resources to exchange with us a suitable area for a school at another point and they have agreed to do this. However, I have gone over the possible school sites in that area and I do not think that there is anything suitable for our purpose. As the surveyors are nearly finished with the work which they had, and were anxious to proceed with subdivision of the school property into town lots, I gave the surveyor permission to proceed with the survey. I trust that my action in this connection will meet with the approval of the Department.

I have given a great deal of thought to the matter of erecting another residential school to replace the present one at Lac la Ronge. This building should be a fire-proof building and should be situated on a fairly large acreage of good arable land with a good water supply. The Department is aware that the present Lac la Ronge School Building is a fire-trap and no money should be spent on it other than to meet immediate needs. I have instructed Indian Agent E.S. Jones to prepare a requisition covering the cost of installing two more fire escapes and submit it through this office. The interior of the building is badly in need of painting but there is a large supply of paint on hand at the school which will be sufficient to do most of the interior decorating and arrangements will be made shortly to have this done.

Mr. Wickenden, the new Principal, is an active and very conscientious man, and I believe he will make a successful school principal. Most of the school staff are new and I spent some time with them explaining their duties and the attitude which they should have toward the Indian children under their care.

I believe that serious consideration should be given by the Department before arriving at a decision as to the location of the new residential school when one is to be built. The Lac la Ronge School and the St. Alban's School at Prince Albert are both under the auspices of the Church of England and under the management of the Indian and Eskimo Commission. I would suggest that it would be better to build...
be better to build one large residential school to take the place of the two. Both are poor buildings and both need replacing. Neither of the schools has sufficient playground space or land for gardening and farming. There is a large acreage of unused land on the Little Red River Reserve, not far from the main highway, which is nearly completed between Prince Albert and Lac la Ronge. A large school somewhere on the Little Red River Reserve would serve the whole area so far as Anglican children are concerned. I believe it will always be necessary to have a residential school for the majority of Indian children of the Lac la Ronge area and many of the children from the reserves of the Carlton and Duck Lake Agencies. Unless the Department has decided to build no more residential schools I would recommend that consideration be given to my proposal that one large school be erected to take the place of the two when materials are available.

I would be glad to have the Department's comments in this connection and I shall be pleased to furnish any further information which may seem desirable.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, September 30, 1946.

Ottawa, 17 October 1946.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
REGINA, Sask.

We have received your letter of Sept. 23 with reference to selling approximately 76 acres of lot 12 now used by the Lac la Ronge School to the Province of Saskatchewan.

It is understood from your letter that the Province is prepared to make a survey of the land which they require without expense to this Department. This survey should give detailed information regarding the land which they wish us to transfer to them so that we can prepare the necessary documents.

It is noted from the fourth paragraph of your letter that the Department of Natural Resources in the Province of Saskatchewan would provide a suitable area at another point if we decide to erect a new school. Would it be possible for you to secure an official letter from the Department of Natural Resources outlining their policy in this regard? Is it understood that the Department of Natural Resources, Province of Saskatchewan, would only allow $1.00 an acre for the land that we are supplying to them? We would like a definite reply to this question as definite information must be included in any documents which we prepare.

We have also noted your remarks regarding the possible location for a new school to replace the present Lac la Ronge School. At the present, we are not in the position to make any decision regarding the erection of a new school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Re: Land - La Ronge Settlement.

Reference the proposed purchase of part of Lot 12 at La Ronge Settlement.

As requested a legal survey will be made of the portion Mr. Wickenden, school principal, wishes to retain for use of the school and church. This area will comprise about 7 acres and temporary markers have already been set. As the survey party has completed the work in the adjoining lots and has returned to Regina we would appreciate your confirmation that the balance of the lot will be sold to the Department before incurring the expense of surveys of the portion to be retained by the school.

The survey party has already subdivided two blocks of land in the Lot 12 and it is therefore suggested that the transfer of land be effected in two stages; first a transfer of the westerly 850 feet in width and finally a transfer of the balance excepting thereout the portion to be retained by the school and church. The land already subdivided consists of scrub, rock and muskeg and is of no value to the school either present or potential. A price of $1.00 per acre for this area is considered to be a reasonable one. A legal description for the purpose of effecting transfer is as follows:

All that portion of Lot 12 according to the Dominion Government Survey of La Ronge settlement, in Saskatchewan, as shown on a plan of survey approved and confirmed at Ottawa, on 23rd May, 1923 and contained within the following limits:
On the West by the westerly limit of said lot;
On the South by the southerly limit of said lot;
On the East by a line drawn northerly from and at right angles to the said northerly limit from a point distant 850 feet easterly thereon from the North West corner of said lot to the intersection with the bank of Lac la Ronge;
On the South by the bank of Lac la Ronge;
The portion above described containing 28.4 acres, more or less.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Reference our letter dated April 12th, 1946 in regard to purchase of Lot 12 La Ronge Settlement, Sask.

The Superintendent of Welfare and Training of your branch requested a letter from my department stating that provincial lands will be granted in exchange for Lot 12 in the event that approval is obtained and the school vacates its present site for a more suitable one elsewhere with sufficient garden and grazing space for school purposes.

Apparently the school principal considers the present site most unsuitable as the land is poor, the area is not the Indian center it was years ago, and also because a mixed settlement in the vicinity adds to the difficulty in maintaining discipline among the Indian boys and girls.

Should the Indian Affairs Branch dispose of all of Lot 12 to the department we are prepared to grant provincial lands elsewhere away from settled area with fuel wood, grazing and garden possibilities. It is suggested that the area granted should not exceed 76.7 acres, the area of the present holding.
As indicated in the attached letter it is suggested that immediate action be taken to dispose of the westerly 28.4 acres not required for school or church. Later on action can be taken to dispose of the balance with the exception of the 7 acres required for school, playing field, church, garden etc.

Trusting that this matter will receive early attention.

I remain,

Yours truly,

J.L. Phelps

J.L. Phelps,
Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development.
