Memorandum:

Lac la Ronge Residential School -

Mr. Ostrander received the telegram below just before he left for his leave. It is likely that you will receive then a letter from Mr. Phelps concerning the sale of the additional land.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Mr. Phelps:

With reference to your telegram addressed to me at Ottawa, and your letter of the 14th instant in connection with the remainder of the land held by our Branch at Lac la Ronge, and on which the recently burned school was situated, I discussed the matter with the necessary authorities while in Ottawa and I believe that there is no doubt that this land will be transferred to the province at a valuation decided upon in due course.

However, our Branch still has some buildings on the land and I believe some school equipment which was not totally destroyed. These matters will have to be cleared up and a satisfactory arrangement arrived at with the Church Authorities before the transfer can be made. Consequently there may be some delay. However, you may rest assured that the desire of your Department will be given full consideration before any action is taken about the property.

I am forwarding a copy of your letter and a copy of this letter to Ottawa in order that the matter may be given due consideration.

Yours very truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Minister of Natural Resources &
Industrial Development,
Provincial Government,

SASKATCHEWAN

MINISTER OF NATURAL RESOURCES
AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT

Regina, Saskatchewan,
February 14th, 1947.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander,
Department of Indian Affairs,
413 Post Office Building,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

As advised in our telegram of today's date, our Department wishes to buy the balance of Lot 12 at La Ronge Settlement.

You may recall that when negotiations were commenced leading to our purchase of the 28.4 acres portion of Lot 12 your officials considered La Ronge unsuitable for a residential school. Now that the school has been destroyed by fire, you may wish to abandon the site for a more suitable one elsewhere.

If you desire to rebuild this school on a new location we would be quite prepared to negotiate with you with a view to exchanging this land for property which might suit your purpose to better advantage. In the event you desire to dispose of the buildings, which still remain on the site, we would also be prepared to negotiate for their transfer.

We are at the moment considering plans for expansion in that area for the coming year and, while we do not wish to rush you unnecessarily, we would ask that, in the event of you desiring to make any disposition of this property, we be given first opportunity.

Yours sincerely,

J.H. Phelps,
Minister of Natural Resources
and Industrial Development.

Attention: Colonel B. F. Neary, Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

Re: Lac La Ronge School Site

Dear Colonel Neary:

I wish to acknowledge your letter of March 10th and may say that I had the opportunity of discussing this question yesterday with Mr. Phelan. I plan to leave tonight for a visit to several schools but scarcely feel able to go as far as Lac La Ronge. There are many questions relating to the situation which I cannot answer satisfactorily but I expect to see Mr. Fisher at Sioux Lookout, who was for 17 years the principal at Lac La Ronge. I shall also see Mr. Wickenden at the Gordon's School and believe that he can make many matters plain. I have left with Mr. Phelan a copy of the letter from the Secretary of the Indian Department in regard to the building of the principal's residence. From the rest of the correspondence it is evident that this structure was put up by our Commission with the assistance of a grant of $2,500.00 from the Department. Dr. Percy E. Moore has advised me that he desires to obtain this building for use as a nursing station and we shall see that no disposal is made of it until the question of ownership is settled.

I note that the Minister of Natural Resources of the Provincial Government desires to take over the land on which the school stood and may say that local officials of the province have been endeavouring to purchase other buildings on the site. I trust that the offer of Mr. Phelps to place other property at the disposal of the Indian Affairs Branch in exchange for this site may be favourably considered. Our principal has urged strongly that the new school should be constructed somewhere on the south shore of the lake where it would be removed from the harmful influences of the present settlement but would be within reach of the new road recently constructed.
It is my hope that I may see Inspector Ostrander in Regina and I should be in a position to discuss various matters more intelligently after my return.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Superintendent.
Ottawa, March 15, 1947.

Re: Your File: #339-303-11 A.C.E.

Your letter of March 12th was received. The transfer of the Natural Resources Agreement of March 20th, 1930 provided (Para. 10) that Indian Reserves should continue to be vested in the Crown Dominion. As the Lac la Ronge school site was then under the administration of the Department of Indian Affairs, it would not have been transferred to the Province, and presumably there would be no record in the Land Titles Office.

The Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development should now be able to record the Order in Council P.C. 21 of January 3rd, 1947 which was sent to you with our letter of January 5th, and on the authority of that Order in Council, the Land Titles Office should be able to issue a title to the Provincial Department.

Dear Sir:

Reference transfer of part of Lot 12 in La Ronge Settlement to the Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development, as covered in Order-in-Council P.C. 21 dated January 3, 1947. Your letter 132-2-9 (R3) dated March 24, 1937, refers.

Ottawa, October 16th, 1947.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 11th, your file 14, with reference to the transfer of part of Lot 12, Lac la Ronge Settlement, made to your Department by P.C. 21 of 3rd January, 1947; and we are indeed surprised to learn that the Registrar at Prince Albert has stated that the Order in Council is not sufficient on which to issue a Certificate of Title and requires a grant of the land.

In so far as our records indicate, all transfers of this nature, which have been made since the Natural Resources were turned over to the provinces, have been by way of Order in Council and when the very point at issue was considered by the Law Officers of the Crown Dominion some years ago, they expressed the opinion that an Order in Council is the proper and only mode of conveying lands or any interest therein from one Government to another. As Mr. Justice Newcombe pointed out in the Saskatchewan Natural Resources Reference Case 1931, 1 DLR 855 "There is only one Crown and the lands belonging to the Crown are and remain vested in it notwithstanding that administration of them and the exercise of their beneficial use may, from time to time, as competently authorized, be regulated upon the advice of different ministers charged with the appropriate service".

In short, the Crown is one and indivisible and it is merely the beneficial use that is transferred from the Dominion to a Province or vice versa, the title at all times remaining in the Crown.

A. I. Bereskin, Esq.,
Controller of Surveys,
Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development,
Natural Resources Bldg.,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.
As stated previously, we are of the opinion that a transfer by Order in Council is the only method which could be followed by this Department as regards the Lac la Ronge land and as such transfer follows similar transfers made since the Natural Resources Agreement, it would seem apparent that on the matter again being brought to the attention of the Registrar, he will accept the Order in Council as a sufficient basis for the issue of a Certificate of Title to the Province.

Yours truly,

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

Dear Sir:

I have been instructed by the Minister, the Honourable J. L. Phelps, to extend the Townsite of La Ronge and to purchase the balance of your Indian Affairs Lot No. 12 for this purpose. You will probably recall that last year this Department purchased a 28.4 acre portion of the lot at a nominal rate of $1.00 per acre.

Your plans for re-establishing the La Ronge Indian School, destroyed by fire last year, may not have been finalized but the proposal herein made appears flexible enough so that in the event your Department decides to rebuild the school it will have reserved ample land for school, playing field, teacherage, etc.

It is, therefore, suggested that the 48.3 acre remainder of lot 12 be transferred to this Department at a nominal rate of $1.00 per acre. We will then extend the townsite survey and subdivide the land into town lots and survey a four acre parcel for your school and hospital site, teacherage, church and apurtenant buildings. We will absorb costs of making a legal survey and transfer back to your Department land required for the school, etc. and land at present occupied by teacherage and church.

It might appear that your Department is receiving a small acreage of surveyed land in return. Actually much of the 48.3 acres is muskeg and the portion conveyed back would be a good part of the land suitable for settlement. As costs of survey borne by this Department will be about $500.00 the proposal seems an equitable one to all concerned.

...........
Should you decide to definitely abandon La Ronge for the site of a new Indian Residential School suitable provincial land could be exchanged for the area vacated in line with the Minister's earlier letter to the Honourable J. A. Glen.

I would respectfully urge that a survey be made. As it stands at present part of the road allowance surveyed by the Dominion Government in 1920 is occupied by some of the school outbuildings and sheds and the present trail from La Ronge Avenue in the Townsite meanders across your lot. The Department would like to improve the road leading to its Fish Filleting plant but cannot legally do so until right to the land is secured or approval granted for a roadway across the balance of your lot. Due to the completion of the Highway, La Ronge is becoming an increasingly popular tourist attraction and therefore this bad stretch of road should be improved.

As there is some urgency in this matter a reply at your earliest convenience would be appreciated. An air photo of La Ronge showing nature of the ground is attached.

Yours truly,

Sgd. A. I. Bereskin,

A. I. Bereskin,
Controller of Surveys.

Dear Mr. Hogg:

Re: La Ronge Townsite

The letter of November 14, 1947, from Mr. Bereskin, your Controller of Surveys, is acknowledged and the delay in reaching a decision in the matter is regretted.

We note your request for a conveyance of the balance of Lot L2 to your Department in order that you may be enabled to proceed with the survey of an extension of the townsite.

Please be advised that the question of rebuilding the residential school at Lac la Ronge destroyed by fire last February has not yet been decided between this Branch and the Anglican Church which is jointly interested with us in the matter. It would appear, however, that if the school is eventually rebuilt in the La Ronge district, the old site would not be entirely suitable for our purposes and that of the Church.

It is noted, however, that you undertake to reserve for the departmental use of this Department a four-acre parcel from the lands surveyed to be held for our use for school, hospital, church, teachersage and appurtenant buildings, which we interpret as meaning for any purpose in connection with the administrative requirements of this Department.

If you could add to that assurance, an assurance that, in the event of the residential school being rebuilt, you will cooperate with us in the selection

C. A. L. Hogg, Esq.,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development,
Regina, Saskatchewan.
of a suitable site in the vicinity and will convey to us such land as may be selected for that purpose as and when we are ready to proceed with the building, I would be prepared to recommend that the balance of Lot 12 be immediately conveyed to you by Executive Order, in order to permit you to go ahead with your proposed survey.

Any such conveyance would, however, have to be conditional upon your Government undertaking to reconvey the four-acre parcel referred to in your letter as soon as your survey plans had been recorded; and to the further assurance that it would at a later date make available and convey to us such other land at Lac Le Ronge as is required for school purposes should the four-acre site be considered unsuitable for that purpose.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Minister.

Dear Mr. Hogg:

Re: La Ronge Townsite

I am in receipt of a letter dated November 14, 1947, from Mr. Bereskin, your Controller of Surveys, requesting a conveyance to your Government of the balance of Lot 12 at Lac La Ronge to enable your Department to proceed with an extension of the survey of the townsite, and regret very much the delay in replying.

In looking into the matter, however, it has been ascertained that the land in question is occupied by buildings now owned by the Dominion Government as represented by the Minister of National Health and Welfare and that Department is unwilling that we should part with its ownership.

The actual facts are that the Department of National Health and Welfare has purchased the old mission buildings which it is remodelling into a nursing station and residence for its employees and for other purposes. We are also advised that a high value is placed on the small piece of cultivated land adjacent to the nursing station, which is land built up for gardening purposes and produces vegetables for the use of the nursing station.

It appears, therefore, that we cannot accede to Mr. Bereskin's request to transfer the remainder of Lot 12 to you for the reason that it is presently occupied by Government owned buildings. May I suggest another approach to the matter and that you select and describe the land actually required for the extension of the roads leading to your townsite subdivision.

In this connection it is suggested that your Controller of Surveys consult with Dr. A. B. Simes, Regional Superintendent for the Department of National Health and Welfare,

C. A. L. Hogg, Esq.,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development,
Regina, Saskatchewan.
who can be reached at the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle. I suggest this conference with Dr. Simes due to the fact that he has suggested to his Director here that it would appear to him to be possible to locate the road in such a way as to interfere little with the use of the property for the purposes of his Department.

In the meantime I regret that for obvious reasons I am unable to convey the land as suggested and am compelled to refer you to the officers of the Department on whose behalf the land in question is held. May I express the hope that you will be able to work out some mutually satisfactory arrangement which the local field officers can recommend and submit for consideration.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Minister.

DJA/MC

Dear Mr. MacKinnon:

Reference letter from your Department dated 8 April, 1948, expressing concurrence to having the matter of road alignment at La Ronge settled by our respective representatives.

The road diversion has now been completed across the corner of the garden to the mutual satisfaction, I believe of our representatives. As tourists from as far south as Florida visit La Ronge the road improvement has eliminated a source of complaint which partly nullified the good work of our respective governments in tourist promotion.

As La Ronge is growing rapidly we are now faced with the problem of expanding the townsite. All the suitable land has been subdivided and about 75% of the lots taken up. There is a good possibility that the recent uranium find 35 miles from La Ronge should it develop into a mine, will accelerate growth of La Ronge.

In order to prevent a shanty town springing up on the outskirts of the present townsite, which has been laid out in accordance with community planning principles, it is suggested that the 48.3 acres now held by your Department be sold to the province. To protect your interest following proposed is made.

1. The Federal government sell to the province the 48.3 acre parcel at the nominal rate of $1. per acre as was previously done in sale of your 28.4 acre parcel of land to the province.

2. The province will then subdivide the land into town lots and integrate your nursing station, church, cemetery, buildings and grounds into a townsite in accordance with modern town planning principle.

3. The province will bear all costs of survey and then sell and
transfer back to the Dominion all your buildings and appurtenant grounds required for your purposes at the same nominal rate of $1. per acre.

4. In addition to the above should you at any time require provincial lands for the purpose of erecting an Indian School or hospital we will transfer such lands, in any area which is mutually agreed upon at the same nominal rate of $1. per acre.

It is believed that above is a flexible arrangement as it will enable the Dominion to obtain provincial lands for school, hospital or ration store purposes at strategic points in northern Saskatchewan in order to best serve the Indian population.

I might say that only a small part, probably four acres of the 48.3 acres parcel is now in use. The land is not suitable for gardening but most of it is suitable for building lots.

The proposal has been discussed at executive level among our respective representatives and I believe that they are in general agreement to the above proposal. May I suggest that if the proposal has your general approval that details be settled by our representatives who are familiar with the situation at La Ronge.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) J. L. Phelps

Hon. J. L. Phelps,
Minister.

Dear Sir:

Re: Lac La Ronge Townsite

It is a matter of regret that we are unable to give you a conclusive answer to Mr. Phelps' letter of August 2nd as the Department of National Health and Welfare and our own Schools Administration cannot yet give us specific information as to their land requirements at La Ronge.

As soon as their respective plans are finally decided, we will be pleased to re-convey any surplus lands in Lot 13 to you subject to the conditions outlined in Mr. Phelps' letter.

I see no reason why we could not now transfer to the Province the land you require for the highway.

Yours faithfully,

Jas. A. MacKinnon.
Hon. Paul Joseph Martin,
Minister, Department of National Health and Welfare,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Martin:

Re: Lot 12—La Ronge

It is understood that your Department now has control of the 48.3 acre parcel remaining in Lot 12, as is indicated by the attached copy of letter received from Dr. Keenleyside.

Due to the influx of settlers, and the increasing tourist traffic, it has now become absolutely necessary to improve the road in the settlement. The unfavourable reaction and bad publicity due to settlers and tourists having to pass over a rough trail at La Ronge itself after driving 170 miles along one of the best highways in the province would adversely affect our work in promoting this area.

As shown on the attached sketch, the road could be built along the old road allowance, title to which is held by the Provincial Department of Highways. This would require the removal of many of your buildings which are sited on the road allowance, and as some of them are of good size, it would not be an easy matter to move them.

It would be preferable, in my opinion, to transfer the old road allowance to your Department, so that your buildings may then be located on Dominion land, in return for which we would be granted the right to extend La Ronge Avenue as shown on the sketch.
Hon. P. J. Martin, Ottawa, Canada.

March 10, 1948.

About a quarter acre of your garden would be affected in so doing, but we are prepared to pick up the soil with our power equipment, and extend your garden elsewhere so that the area under cultivation would be the same. This would probably be the best solution as the relocated road will be well away from the nursing station so that the patients will be unaffected by noise of traffic.

Should you decide at any time to vacate La Ronge Settlement, and establish a nursing station at some more strategic point away from a growing settlement, we would be glad to exchange an equivalent acreage of suitable provincial land for the 48.3 acre portion now held by your Department at La Ronge. Our object is to expand La Ronge Subdivision to provide more building lots for settlers and campers.

The matter of exchange of land or transfer, to us, of the portion of your 48.3 acre parcel not required for the nursing station purposes, could be considered at some future date, but our immediate concern is to improve the road sometime within the next two months. It would be appreciated, therefore, if this matter is given early attention.

Yours truly,

J. L. Phelps,
Minister.

AIB/CCS
Attach.
Ottawa, Ontario,
January 7, 1948.

Dear Mr. Hogg:

Re: La Ronge Townsite.

I am in receipt of a letter dated November 14, 1947, from Mr. Bereskin, your Controller of Surveys, requesting a conveyance to your Government of the balance of Lot 12 at Lac la Ronge to enable your Department to proceed with an extension of the survey of the townsite, and regret very much the delay in replying.

In looking into the matter, however, it has been ascertained that the land in question is occupied by buildings now owned by the Dominion Government as represented by the Minister of National Health and Welfare and that that Department is unwilling that we should part with its ownership.

The actual facts are that the Department of National Health and Welfare has purchased the old mission buildings which it is remodelling into a nursing station and residence for its employees and for other purposes. We are also advised that a high value is placed on the small piece of cultivated land adjacent to the nursing station, which is land built up for gardening purposes and produces vegetables for the use of the nursing station.

It appears, therefore, that we cannot accede to Mr. Bereskin's request to transfer the remainder of Lot 12 to you for the reason that it is presently occupied by Government owned buildings. May I suggest another approach to the matter and that you select and describe the land actually required for the extension of the roads leading to your townsite subdivision.

In this connection it is suggested that your Controller of Surveys consult with Dr. A. B. Simes, Regional Superintendent for the Department of National Health and Welfare,

C. A. L. Hogg, Esq.,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development,
Regina, Saskatchewan.
who can be reached at the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle. I suggest this conference with Dr. Simes due to the fact that he has suggested to his Director here that it would appear to him to be possible to locate the road in such a way as to interfere little with the use of the property for the purposes of his Department.

In the meantime I regret that for the stated reasons I am unable to convey the land as suggested and am compelled to refer you to the officers of the Department on whose behalf the land in question is held. May I express the hope that you will be able to work out some mutually satisfactory arrangement which the local field officers can recommend and submit for consideration.

Yours very truly,

Signed by - Deputy Minister.

Dear Mr. Phelps:

Lot 12 - Lac la Ronge

Your letter of March 16 along with a copy of a letter from Doctor Keenleyside and a sketch of the Lac la Ronge townsite is hereby acknowledged.

There are several reasons why we are hesitant to approve of your request to place the road allowance as indicated in the accompanying sketch. Field officers of Indian Affairs Branch as well as officers of our own department advise against allowing this road to be put in as requested by your department. It has been stated that a large proportion of the garden would be destroyed and as this is the only garden in the townsite and the earth was brought by canoe by the Indians of the district, it means a great deal to not only the Indians, but is essential in providing fresh gardens for the use of the nursing station.

The road as proposed by you would pass directly in front of the nursing station and would be a disturbing influence on the patients. At the present time, our sewage disposal lines and water supply pipe run from the nursing station to the lake shore. The road would be built over these lines which might cause difficulties in the future in repairing the lines.

It is also understood that there is a sawmill on the property owned by the Lac la Ronge Band of Indians and it is understood that the Indian Agent wishes to retain this mill on its present site for the benefit of the Indians.
As an alternative, it is suggested that instead of running a road south of the nursing station along the south shore, that you have it constructed north of the nursing station. Instead of crossing the school garden, it should turn left at the corner of Lac la Ronge Avenue and Hastings Street, then proceed to the end of that street. From this point it could be continued at right angles to Hastings Street until it joins the street between blocks 12 and 13. The road would then be back of all the buildings and would in no way create a nuisance or disturb the present arrangements. I am advised that there would be a better view along this road as it would be higher up than down along the lake shore.

The nursing station, although it is owned and will be managed by Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health and Welfare, will do considerable work for local non-Indian residents of Lac la Ronge. Dr. Moore has made definite arrangements with Dr. Hames, Deputy Minister of Health, Province of Saskatchewan, to supply this service to local residents.

I would appreciate it very much if you would give this alternative suggestion your earnest consideration with the hope that this proposal will be satisfactory for all concerned.

Yours sincerely,

Paul Martin.
Ottawa, Ontario.
February 16, 1949.

Dear Sir:

Lot 12 - Lac la Ronge

Following your visit and discussion on this block of land at Lac la Ronge, I have made further enquiries and now find that the title of this land is under the Indian Affairs Branch, Welfare and Training Division.

I have discussed it with Colonel B.F. Neary, Superintendent of Training and he tells me they require part of this land for dormitory purposes for their school. I would, therefore, ask that you get in touch with Mr. Neary regarding your request to this Branch on your recent visit.

There is a possibility that if the land were surveyed and you were able to forward a description and plan of it to Mr. Neary they might be in a position to allot part of it to you. However, this will be their responsibility and is not the concern of Indian Health Services.

I am sending Mr. Neary a copy of this letter and also the plans that you so kindly left with us.

Yours truly,

W.L. Falconer, M.D.,
Asst. Director, Indian Health Services.

February 8, 1949.

Dr. P.E. Moore,
Director, Medical Services,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Land for expansion of La Ronge Townsite

It is understood that Mr. A.I. Bereskin of this Department held preliminary discussions with your office on February 1st, in regard to securing more land from the Federal Department whereby La Ronge Townsite might be expanded to provide for present and future needs.

Mr. Bereskin has, no doubt, indicated that the need for more building sites is urgent, and that there is no other practicable alternative except expand over the unused acreage held by the Federal Government. So as to avoid an uncontrolled Indian village or squatter settlement springing up in the outskirts of the townsite, with consequent sanitation problems, it was proposed that we survey the Federal Block of 48.3 acres and integrate it into our existing townsite which is laid out along community planning lines.

I am pleased to hear that the proposal has your approval, and that permission has been granted to Mr. Bereskin for the making of a preliminary survey of your land. The preliminary plan will show the location of all your buildings, improvements and appurtenant grounds, and a decision could then be made of the land which is to be retained for your purpose and of the remainder to be transferred to the province.

The various points discussed and agreed upon, I believe, were as follows:

(1) So as to simplify subsequent land transfer, the Department of Indian Affairs would obtain formal title to the 48.3 acre remainder of Lot 12 if the land is not yet held in the
name of your Department. We will also make a search in the local Land Titles Office, and if the land is held by the Department of Health and Welfare, we will advise your office.

You may decide that it is unnecessary to transfer title from one Federal Department to another. We can see no objection to dealing with the present title holders of the land except that your office is more familiar with, and is more directly concerned, than the Department of Health and Welfare. In any event, if the large parcel is in your name, certificates of titles of the various lots required for your nursing station can be readily transferred direct to your Department.

(2) The Surveys Branch of this Department will make a Development Plan showing all your buildings, fences and improvements, so that necessary lands can be retained. A lot and block layout will also be superimposed so that a handy unit is provided for transfer of lands required for operation of the nursing station. The development and legal survey is to be done entirely at our expense.

(3) Upon entering a written agreement between our Departments for retention of the various town lots required for your purpose, your office will transfer the entire parcel of 48.3 acres at one dollar ($1.00) per acre, and then we will transfer back to you the various lots required for your purposes at the same nominal rate of one dollar ($1.00) per acre.

(4) The entire block is to be laid out in accordance with community planning principles with due consideration to sanitation, and orderly development.

(5) Our Department will also make the legal surveys of the roads and streets, and arrange for the cancellation of the old Dominion Government road allowance, which is now held in the name of the Provincial Department of Highways, and which is occupied by some of your buildings.

(6) Our Department will also contact Dr. Hames of the Provincial Department of Health, so that he will be familiar with the proposals in the event that the operation of a health center at La Ronge is turned over to the province.

May I be advised if the above proposals have your approval so that the necessary surveys may be made by next month before the expected influx of tourists and settlers.

Yours truly,

(sgd) C.A.L. Hoff, Deputy Minister
25th February, 1949.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 28th ultimo, File 656-9 (E), with which was enclosed a letter from Mr. C.A.L. Hogg, Deputy Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development, for Saskatchewan.

The provincial authorities have been urging, for the last two years, that we turn over to them as much as possible of the land which we are not using at the former site of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I think they should be definitely told that we are not yet ready to make a decision. Two matters are still unsettled. First, the building of a dormitory at Lac la Ronge in connection with educational plans there, and second, the establishment of a headquarters for our Assistant, Indian Agency, for that area. The letter from Mr. Hogg refers to 48.3 acres as not being used. I doubt that 10% of this land can be used for building purposes if and when they decide to build, as nearly all of it is solid rock. It would be very unwise to turn over to the Provincial Government any area until we deal with the problem of finding a suitable place to build a dormitory, a residence for the Assistant, Indian Agency, and a warehouse and office, as well as decide upon sewage disposal, and a water supply. These last two factors are very important when most of the surface is solid rock. They criticise us for moving too slow. I believe they have been too hasty in many things.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
March 19, 1949.

Dear Colonel Neary:  

Some time ago you asked if I could get information regarding the location of the garden plot at the Lac La Ronge property. Mr. Wickenden has drawn the enclosed sketch which gives a clear idea of the lay-out. I trust it will be of value.

"The enclosed sketch may help you in your negotiations with the provincial Govt. of Saskatchewan, and I wish to stress the fact that the measurements given are only approximate and that I have made use of snapshots in determining distances to aid my memory. You will note that it was planned by the surveyor in charge of the new town site to continue the highway east right across the school garden since it seemed the cheapest and most practical thing to do. Good garden land is very scarce in the Lac la Ronge district and the plot in front of the old school was, and is, valuable. I see no reason why any of this land should be sacrificed for building purposes. I have indicated the position of the present public school a little east of the cultivated land, and I don't see any reason why the same site should not be used for the new public school. A site, more or less opposite the missionary's residence, was suggested as a possible site by the Administrator of Education, in Northern Saskatchewan in the fall of '46. It will be hard to find a site with level and extensive playgrounds in any case."

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Keenleyside:

Re: Lot 12 adjacent to La Ronge Townsite, Sask.

In accordance with your letter of March 22nd, 1949, our Department has surveyed the balance of Lot 12 adjacent to La Ronge townsite.

Attached herewith is a development plan showing the various buildings and improvements. The area surveyed comprises practically all of the usable portion of the 48.3 acres now held by the Dominion Government. The area north of the subdivision falls off very sharply to the muskeg which occupies the major portion of the 48.3 acres remaining in Lot 12.

To facilitate the transaction it is suggested that the entire 48.3 acres be transferred to this Department and we will then, upon registration of the plan of survey, transfer the following Lots and Blocks to your Department to cover existing improvements and lands which may be required for expansion of your facilities:

Lot 7 in Block 12 - now occupied by a house;

All of Block 13 - upon which is situated two sheds, two cemeteries, barn, warehouse, power house, hospital, garden, greenhouse and fence;

Lot 6 in Block 14 - now occupied by a building formerly used as a school.

It is believed that the Anglican Church and manse "squatted" on Dominion lands and therefore Block 16 will be transferred to the Church authorities if you so direct.
The sawmill shown on the foreshore is of a portable type and it is our understanding that the Department of Indian Affairs have agreed to its removal. However, if desired, we are prepared to issue an annual permit for the use of the space necessary for its operation until such time as you have had the opportunity to take the action mentioned.

In addition to the above, we will cancel out the portion of the old road allowance now held in the right of the Provincial Department of Highways so that the warehouse and hospital building which now extends into the provincial road allowance, will be entirely absorbed in Block 13.

May I suggest that the transfer of lands between our Departments be at the nominal rate of $1.00 per acre as was previously done in the transfer of the westerly portion of Lot 12.

The settlement of La Ronge is a growing one and I feel that the integration of your lands and buildings in the survey will set the pattern for its orderly growth along sound community planning lines. La Ronge is becoming an increasingly popular fishing resort and is visited each summer by numerous American as well as Canadian tourists.

Four prints are attached for your convenience.

Yours very truly,

C. A. L. Hogg
Deputy Minister

CALH/MH
Encl.
MEMORANDUM

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

October 12, 1949.

Re: Letter of September 13, 1949, from Mr. C.A.L. Hogg, Deputy Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development, Province of Saskatchewan.

The title to Lot 12 adjacent to La Ronge Townsite, Saskatchewan, 76.70 acres, is vested in His Majesty in the right of Canada, under the authority of P.C. 589 dated May 4, 1925, "for the purposes of the Indian Boarding School and Hospital at La Ronge, Saskatchewan".

It did not pass to the Province with the return of the resources, as it was in an exempted class.

It is not an Indian Reserve nor is it Indian lands and is, therefore, not within the jurisdiction of this Branch. The Lot is Federal Crown land within the jurisdiction of the Lands and Development Services Branch and that Branch alone, according to my understanding, has the right to convey it, as requested by Mr. Hogg.

By P.C. 21 of January 3, 1947, 28.4 acres of the Lot were conveyed to His Majesty in the right of Saskatchewan, leaving a balance of 48.3 acres still vested in the Crown Dominion.

In the view of this Branch an Order of the Minister is required declaring that the land is no longer required for school purposes and directing that the administrative jurisdiction over it be transferred to the Lands and Development Services Branch. This the Minister may properly do as the school which formerly occupied this site was completely destroyed by fire in February, 1947, and is no longer used or required for school purposes.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6317, file 656-9, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The Order above referred to is hereto attached for the Minister's signature. It should, however, be drawn to the attention of the Lands and Development Services Branch that the Department of National Health and Welfare have an interest in the land by virtue of their ownership of many buildings thereon which they acquired from the Anglican Church and that Department should be consulted before any conveyance as requested by Mr. Hogg is made.

Further, as mentioned in Mr. Hogg's letter, the Anglican Church may have an interest and their concurrence in Mr. Hogg's proposal for the protection of their interest might be considered necessary.

Were the lot in question within the administrative jurisdiction of this Branch, we would have little hesitation in recommending that Mr. Hogg's proposal be accepted, as it appears to be a practical one.

If the Minister approves the attached Order, it is respectfully suggested that the file and the Order be forwarded to the Lands and Development Services Branch.

Director.

Re: Lot 12 adjacent to La Ronge Townsite, Saskatchewan.

We are enclosing copy of a letter dated September 13, 1949, from Mr. C.A.L. Hogg, Deputy Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development, Regina, together with a plan of a proposed addition to the Townsite of La Ronge. We find this plan somewhat confusing and suggest that you interview Mr. Hogg and Mr. Bereskin and see if you can clarify the picture for us.

1. Is it correct to assume that the area marked in green on the plan is the old road which the Province undertakes to close and do you concur in the proposal?

2. Is Block 13, as referred to in Mr. Hogg's letter, bounded as indicated in red on the enclosed plan?

3. Are you satisfied that both cemeteries and all the medical buildings, except the house on Lot 7, Block 12, are within Block 13?

4. It is our understanding that the new Superintendent's residence is being built near the hospital in Block 13. Will you please plot its exact location on the plan in relation to La Ronge Avenue.

5. Re Lot 6, Block 14 - It is assumed that this is our school and if so, is Lot 6 sufficient land or should we also retain Lots 9 and 10 to provide for extension, playgrounds, etc., before divesting ourselves of title to all lands surrounding it.
6. Re Lot 7, Block 12 - Is this one Lot sufficient for our purposes or should we also retain Lot 2 to give us a frontage on La Ronge Avenue?

7. Can you ascertain if the Anglican Church are content that we should convey to the Province the land in Block 16 south of La Ronge Avenue on which their church and manse stand?

8. Are you satisfied with the arrangement proposed by Mr. Hogg with reference to the sawmill?

If and when you are satisfied with the proposed arrangement, would you please ask Mr. Bereskin to prepare a legal description satisfactory to him for our use should the Minister agree to convey the remaining 48.3 acres in Lot 12 to the Province by Executive Order, as proposed by Mr. Hogg.

You should also ask Mr. Bereskin to prepare a schedule of legal descriptions of each parcel which the Province agrees to reconvey after registration of the plan.

You might discuss with Mr. Hogg and Mr. Bereskin whether or not, as owners of Lot 12, the Minister could not consent to the registration of the plan and after registration then convey to the Province any surplus which we could certify as not being required "for the purposes of the Indian Boarding School and Hospital", thus clearing our title from the condition imposed by the Order in Council which constitutes our title to the property.

Encs.

Director.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th ultimo, File 656-9 (R.T.), re Lot 12 adjacent to La Ronge Townsite, Saskatchewan.

A discussion was held today between Mr. C.A.L. Hogg, Deputy Minister of Natural Resources and Industrial Development; and Mr. A.I. Bereskin, Controller, Surveys Branch; and the writer; and the various matters referred to in Mr. Hogg's letter to Dr. Keenleyside and in the Director's letter referred to, were discussed at some length.

(1) The area marked in green is the old road which the province undertook to close before locating the new road shown on the plan as La Ronge Avenue.

(2) Block 13 referred to in Mr. Hogg's letter is as indicated in red on the enclosed plan.

(3) Both cemeteries and all medical buildings, except the house on Lot 7, Block 12, are within Block 13, with the exception that the old cemetery extends slightly over the boundary of Block 13 into Backlund Street as indicated on the plan.

(4) The new residence for the Assistant, Indian Agency, Lac la Ronge, the construction of which is almost complete, is located as shown in red ink in Block 13 on the plan.

(5) The school building on Lot 6, Block 14, was built some years ago as an infirmary in connection with the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School which was destroyed by fire. This building was later converted into a school to accommodate white and Metis children, and operated under the auspices of the Anglican Church. Subsequently it was leased to the provincial Department of Education by the Church Authorities. This arrangement ended with the opening of the new provincial school at La Ronge Village. I believe that the Anglican Church claims this building, but I have every reason to believe that it should be considered the property of our Branch as I believe Mr. R.S. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, who was Indian Agent, Carlton Agency, at the time this building was erected will confirm the fact that the cost of the building was met out of Parliamentary Appropriation. Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Superintendent, Carlton Agency, has discussed the ownership of this building with Reverend Archdeacon Paul, of the Anglican Church, who stated he was not sure of the ownership of the building, but that he would write to Canon H. E. Rives, at Battleford, whom he thought could answer the question.......

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6317, file 656-9, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
(5) the question. I would also suggest that the Department communicate with Mr. R.S. Davis, or I shall do so, if so instructed. With regard to retaining sufficient land adjoining Lot 6, Block 14, for school purposes, if such is desirable in the future, I would recommend that Lots 4 and 5, in Block 14, be retained in preference to Lots 9 and 10. I make this recommendation because of the fact that suitable playgrounds could be made on Lots 4 and 5, but not on Lots 9 and 10, because of the fact that the latter is nearly solid rock.

(6) In addition to Lot 7, Block 12, on which a house is situated, I would recommend retention of Lot 1 in conjunction with Lot 7, in preference to Lot 2. My reason for this recommendation is in the fact that if we retained Lot 2 there would eventually be a private occupant of Lot 1 whose property would be surrounded by our property on two sides and streets on the other two sides.

(7) Bishop Martin was absent when Mr. E.S. Jones endeavoured to contact him regarding settlement of the title to the land on which the Church and Manse stand in Block 10. However, Reverend Archdeacon Paul acted on behalf of Bishop Martin, and stated that he would like, if possible, to have title to this property transferred direct from the Dominion Government to the Church Authorities, and I would so recommend.

(8) I am not satisfied with the arrangement proposed by Mr. Hogg with reference to the sawmill. While in a sense this sawmill could be called a portable one, the method in which it has been set up on cement bases with twin steam set up which forms the power unit, the cost of moving it to another point would be almost prohibitive. This sawmill is used from time to time as a way to supply the Indians of that area with cheap lumber for erecting their homes. It must be near the lake in order to have the use of the lake water for steam, and it must be situated on fairly level ground where logs and lumber can be piled, and where there is room for disposal of saw dust, shavings, bark, and other refuse from the sawmill. It would be difficult to find any other place on the lake shore where such natural facilities are available. If the title to the land on which the sawmill is situated is to be transferred to the province, there should be some arrangement for a long term agreement, perhaps for 20 years, for rental of the property necessary to operate the sawmill, at a nominal rental.

As the matter of allocating this land is of some considerable concern to the Department of National Health and Welfare because of the fact that they are operating an Indian Hospital in Block 13, I discussed the matter with Dr. A.B. Simes, Regional Superintendent, Indian Health Services, and he has emphasized the fact that the Provincial Government should not be permitted to make use of the property close to the hospital for a tourist camp. This refers particularly to the land immediately south of Block 13, and between La Ronge Avenue and the lake front. This point is emphasized because of the fact that..................
the fact that I have heard rumours that a proposal in that direction has been considered. It is a well known fact that tourist camps are very noisy during the summer until the early hours of the morning, in fact the quietest period at such a place is usually between daylight and noon. It is imperative that we have quiet at all times around the hospital, not only for the sake of the patients, but also in order that the hospital staff can secure proper rest when off duty. This point was discussed with Mr. Hogg and Mr. Bereskin, but there was no clear-cut decision at the time. However, they agreed that the property in question should not become a tourist camp. It is my opinion that this part of the lake front (marked in yellow) should be retained as a landing place for Indians bringing patients to the hospital, visiting the hospital, or coming to transact business with our Assistant, when travelling by canoe.

With regard to the last three paragraphs of your letter, Mr. Hogg and Mr. Bereskin are both of the opinion that the suggestion in Mr. Hogg's letter to Dr. Keenlyside should be carried out in that the entire 48.3 acres should be transferred to the province and that the Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development will then, upon registration of the plan of survey, transfer to our Department the lands and improvements which we require. Technically, this may be the easier way, but I favour the suggestion made in the last paragraph of your letter, and I believe we should hold out for such an arrangement.

To summarize, we should have title to all of Block 13; Lots 1 and 7 in Block 12; Lots 4, 5, and 6 in Block 14, also that part of the lake front previously referred to and marked in yellow, and a long-term lease on the sawmill site at a nominal rental. Mr. Hogg has tentatively agreed to these conditions, and will forward me a letter, in duplicate, to that effect, following which I shall forward a copy to the Department. I have been assured that this will be within the next few days.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander,

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Reference your phone call to Mr. Bereskin raising further points in regard to the proposed transfer of lands at Lac La Ronge.

May I suggest that the procedure be as follows:

1. The Dominion Government transfer to the Crown in the right of the Department of Natural Resources and Industrial Development, Province of Saskatchewan the 48.3 acre parcel remaining in Lot 12, La Ronge Settlement, at the rate of $1.00 per acre. This transfer being made under authority of a Federal Order in Council which will also make mention of the various lots and block to be transferred back to the Dominion Government.

2. Our Department as owners of the 48.3 acre parcel will register the plan of survey and by Provincial Order in Council transfer back to the Federal Government the necessary lots and block mentioned in the initiating Federal Order in Council. We will also, as owners of the surrounding land, cancel out the old road allowance which is now replaced by La Ronge Avenue.

No difficulty is anticipated in following this procedure.

As requested, we will provide the various legal descriptions as soon as the Asst. Deputy Minister concurs to the suggestion that the various lots as outlined in your letter be retained by the Federal Government. It is realized that the matter should be completed as soon as possible and we are, therefore, requesting early reply by the Asst. Deputy Minister.

Yours truly,

C.A.L. Hogg,
Deputy Minister of Natural Resources.

Dear Mr. Jones:

Referring to our conversation about Lac la Ronge properties a few weeks ago, I wrote to Canon C.F. Hives, but as he has been away from there for many years, he could not give much information. However, this week, when the Bishop and I both returned from itinerating, I found out from him that the building formerly used as a school for non-treaty children, situated East of the Hospital, was built by the Indian School Commission, and after the Residential School was burnt down was sold to the Diocese to be used for Sunday School and various meetings. The Bishop has the papers showing transfer to the Diocese.

As the Bishop and Canon Payton are busy on another matter this afternoon, I cannot look up the papers now; but I will look them up as soon as possible, and note the number of the lot.

Yours sincerely,

Sgd. W.E.J. Paul

With reference to my letter of the 1st instant, File 2578-32-1-107, in reply to your letter of the 14th ultimo, File 656-9 (R.T.) regarding the Department owned land at the La Ronge Townsite, and, in particular, #5 of that report, which refers to the school building on Lot 6, Block 14, I am now in receipt of a copy of a letter which Archdeacon W.E.J. Paul sent to Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Superintendent, Carlton Agency, to the effect that this building belongs to the Church. A copy of that letter is enclosed herewith.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a report on the northern proportion of this agency.

Indian Residential school, Lac La ronge.

About ten head of cattle are kept at this school. Hay for these animals, last year cost over $800.00. A farm instructor is kept at the school and most of his time is spent in looking after these cows and getting feed etc. I would strongly recommend that these cows be disposed of and that the school ship in canned milk. This country is not one in which cows can be kept properly. These cows only supply milk for the children for a period of about six months of the year and if the money was put into canned milk the children would have all the milk they required the year around. I am of the opinion that a large saving could be effected.

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
August 11, 1938.

EX'D.

Reverend Sir:

In his report regarding a recent visit to the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School Indian Agent R. S. Davis writes as follows:

"About ten head of cattle are kept at this school. Hay for these animals, last year cost over $600.00. A farm instructor is kept at the school and most of his time is spent in looking after these cows and getting feed etc. I would strongly recommend that these cows be disposed of and that the school ship in canned milk. This country is not one in which cows can be kept properly. These cows only supply milk for the children for a period of about six months of the year and if the money was put into canned milk the children would have all the milk they required the year around. I am of the opinion that a large saving could be effected."

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

WINNIPEG, MAN.—August 22nd, 1933.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, No. 132-2-14, embodying an extract from the report of Mr. Indian Agent Davis, and in which he recommends that the cows now kept at our Lac la Ronge School be disposed of, and that canned milk be provided for the children instead.

As your letter came to hand just as Colonel Mermagen, Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission, was about to visit this school, the Commission suggested that definite action in the matter be postponed until he had discussed the recommendation with the Principal, and submitted a statement embodying their joint opinion in the matter. As soon as the Colonel has returned, and his statement has received the consideration of our Commission, I will write to you again.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

TBRW/JLC

Secretary of the Commission.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

With further reference to your Mr. Hoey's letter of the 11th ult., No. 132-2-14, and my reply to the same on the 22nd ult., I beg to state that our Commission has given much careful consideration to the suggestion made by Mr. Indian Agent Davis that the cows at our Lac la Ronge School be disposed of and that the School be supplied with canned milk.

For your information I may say that Colonel Mermagen, Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Commission, recently visited this School and carefully discussed with the Principal the Indian Agent's recommendation. After considering the matter, they decided that the Principal should set forth in writing his opinion, and from his statement the following is extracted:-

"Before a final decision is taken in this matter I would like to call the attention of the Commission to the fact that as shown in the Farm Reports, there has been an increase in the amount of milk produced at the school. This has been due largely to the fact that the cows kept have been better milkers. Taking the first three months of the years 1936-37-38 for purposes of comparison, the amounts produced were respectively:-
Jan. - Mar. Quarter, 1936 ...... 80 gals.
" " " " 1937 ..... 159 "
" " " " 1938 ..... 730 "
April-June " 1938 ..... 959 "

This shows that there has been a great increase during the last year, and the prospects are quite good for the coming year. Taking Mr. Davis' figures - $800.00 - as substantially correct as to the cost of keeping the cows at the School (this includes part of the Farmer's wages, and feed for cows) and providing we can maintain a milk production of from 6 to 8 gals. per day during the time the children are in School, it would appear that the cost per gallon of fresh milk would be cheaper than that of canned or dried milk. Based on a consumption of six gals. per day, the canned or dried milk diluted at the full strength as directions on containers, the cost would be, based on the children being at School for a minimum of 309 days per year:

Canned Milk: 48's @ $9.45 per cs. landed .79¢ per gal. or $1,664.96 per year.

Dried Milk: 48 lbs. to cs. @ $20.70 per cs. landed. 64¢ per gal. $1,186.56 per year.

These figures have not taken into consideration that a lower cost per case might be obtained for quantity purchase, or that the milk could be used in greater dilution."

In addition to the above, the Principal points out that the cost price of the hay ($800.00) includes the salary of the Farm Instructor for at least four months in the year and that the acceptance of the Indian Agent's recommendation would not relieve the Commission of the necessity of maintaining a Farm Instructor, as "the bulk of this agent's time is taken up in securing wood for the School furnaces". Should a Farm Instructor not be retained it would be necessary to engage another permanent worker in the capacity of General Assistant to act as teamster during the winter months and to secure the necessary hay supply for the horses during the summer.

In the light of the above information, our Commission feel that it would be better to allow the existing arrangement to stand for another year or two at any rate. The members heartily share the desire of your Branch of Government to train the Indian boys and girls in the Schools under their control to become self-supporting and useful citizens, and while the country around
Lac la Ronge may not be suitable for farming and gardening activities on an extensive scale, it is by no means impossible for such activities to be gradually extended. Such extension would surely help in achieving the desire that you and we have so much at heart.

For some years I continued to urge your Department to make a grant of $500.00 for clearing and bringing under cultivation quite a good piece of land not far away from the main school building. If it were at all possible to have this assistance, I am convinced that the results would justify the expenditure. If some further help could be given by your Department to drain the large muskeg immediately behind the School, it would not be long before the School management would be able to secure all the hay and oats required for horses and cattle, and the annual cost of operating the School would be considerably reduced.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

TERW/KH

Dear Mr Hoey:

I have before me a copy of your letter dated the 19th inst, and addressed to the Rev. Dr.Westgate, with regard to "the cattle at the Lac la Ronge Residential School." You conclude your letter as follows:

"In view of the information contained in your letter the existing arrangement may stand for another year or so."

This quotation seems to indicate a misapprehension concerning the basis of the arrangement under which the Church of England in Canada and, I think, the other Churches concerned, administer the Indian Residential Schools for which they are severally responsible.

On more than one occasion when it was my responsibility to address the Hon'ble, the Minister on behalf of a joint Church Delegation, I referred to this subject and emphasised the fact that the basis of the partnership between the Churches and the Government is one of co-operation not of subordination.

The original agreement between the Churches and the Government reserved to the Government the right of appointment of the Principals of the Schools; but the matters concerned with the ordinary administration lay within the competence and responsibility of the Churches. This statement of principle has never been disputed and, as far as the several Ministers addressed have been concerned, has received at least consent by silence.

I refer to the point now because, after 28 years of experience, I am of the firm conviction that any interpretation
of the agreement in question which would appear to place the Churches in a subordinate position to the officials of the Department could lead only in the end to great dissatisfaction and probably great disagreement.

The contents of this letter are not intended to mean that the Inspectors, or other officials of the Department are not at liberty to express their opinions regarding this or that general aspect of the Church's administration of the Schools but they are intended to mean that in details, such as the example under discussion, the matter rests solely within the competence and decision of the Church concerned.

Believe me, with kind regards,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

General Secretary.
Ottawa, October 1, 1938.

Dear Canon Gould:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you refer to a communication dated September 19, 1938, sent forward by the Department to Reverend Dr. Westgate.

I must express regret that Dr. Westgate felt compelled to bring this matter to your attention. There is not, in my judgment, the slightest danger that the Government or the officials of the Department will at any time encroach upon the jurisdiction of the Churches in the administration of residential schools.

I have myself, since entering the Department, encouraged our Indian agents and our inspectors to take an active interest in the administration of our residential institutions, in the hope that by so doing the Principals would be encouraged and the general administration of the schools improved. I have, for example, succeeded in securing the services of an official of the Department of Agriculture to make a survey of farming conditions at one or two schools, in an attempt to help the Principals. It was my hope, also, that I might secure an official from the Forestry Branch to undertake a worthwhile programme of reforestation and beautification at a number of our schools, particularly in the West.

The comment sent forward to the Department by Indian Agent Davis - copy of which I enclose - was forwarded in the hope that certain economies might be effected at

Reverend Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.C.L., D.D.,
General Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
604 Jarvis Street,
Toronto 5, Ont.

Lac la Ronge School. May I point out, also, that the suggestion made by the Agent has a very direct relationship to government expenditures. Last year, we made a special grant of $500. to the Lac la Ronge School, in an attempt to compensate the institution for the losses sustained by drought conditions throughout the province of Saskatchewan. A somewhat similar grant, paid on the basis of $5.00 per pupil, was sent forward to all the residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan. In addition to this, I have had before me now for a couple of years a request from Dr. Westgate for a special grant of $500.00 for the clearing of land. This land, it would appear, is necessary to maintain a herd of cattle at the institution. You will, I feel, understand my position, therefore, when I express regret that Dr. Westgate has brought this matter to your attention.

It is just possible that the departmental letter of the 19th ultimo, to which you have referred, was somewhat loosely worded. It is somewhat difficult, however, for our officials to keep constantly in mind the principles underlying the administration of our institutions, particularly so when our duties appear to be multiplying from day to day. I hesitate to send forward a copy of your communication to our agents and inspectors. I have discussed the administration of residential schools with them on more than one occasion and I know how reluctant they frequently are to visit these institutions. If, however, you feel that a copy of your letter, or a letter along somewhat similar lines, written by me, would enable our officials to more clearly define where their responsibilities begin and end with respect to our residential schools, I shall be glad to prepare and send out such a letter.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

My dear Mr Hoey:

Thank you for your letter dated the 1st inst.

I receive, I may say, copies of all correspondence written or received by Dr.Westgate. The copy of letter relating to the question under discussion was the cause of my communication to you. In other words, the matter was not drawn to my attention by Dr.Westgate.

I have in mind also Dr.Westgate's letter to you in which he states the results of his examination of the cost of the herd of cattle at Lac la Ronge as compared with the cost of a supply of tinned milk - his conclusion, I think being (I am speaking from memory) that the total cost per annum of the cattle is less than the total cost would be of an adequate supply of tinned milk. In addition, we must bear in mind the fact that the cattle provide no inconsiderable part of the meat supply needed for this school. When therefore all the items are taken into consideration it appears to me that, from the standpoint of economy, the cattle are cheaper than the tinned milk.

It is in connection with points such as this one that the Inspector or the Agent of the Department is liable to jump to conclusions and to make recommendations which are not supported by an examination of all the facts. Our Commission at Winnipeg, with its two very capable agents - Dr.Westgate and Colonel Mermagen - have given very careful consideration during the last seventeen or eighteen years to the question of relative cost, and operate the schools under very definite instructions of the Executive Committee of the Society that the closest economy, consistent in particular with the adequate feeding of the children, must be exercised.
Throughout the whole period, I may say, we have carried an annual net bank overdraft on account of the schools we administer, of a sum varying from $30,000 to $80,000. The approximate net amount of this overdraft on the closing of our books for the year 1937 was $55,000.

The chief cause of this state of affairs in recent years was the harsh, and in my opinion, unjustified action of the Government in reducing, without notice, and without consultation, the rates of per capita grants by successive sums of 10% and 5% - 15% in all. The first cut of 10% has, of course, been restored. We greatly need the restoration of the second cut of 5%.

The special grants last year mentioned by you of $500. to the Lac la Ronge School, and of $5.00 per pupil to the Residential Schools in the Province of Saskatchewan, was a very welcome and much needed action by the Department. It was, however, not an equivalent for the outstanding cut of 5% on the rates of per capita grants.

From the standpoint of the Church, the Agreement between the Churches and the Government, is not, in my judgment, equitable in that the liabilities of the Government are stated and known while the liabilities of the Church, over and above the estimated receipts for any one year from per capita grants, are unstable and unknown.

As an illustration, we have the fact that in the face of the cuts in per capita grants, the Churches were required by the Agreement to meet the adverse conditions brought about by what are usually, but erroneously, described as "acts of Providence." In other words the results, and they were disastrous and expensive, of drought and crop failure affecting over so many years, several of our largest schools.

With regard to my letter. I have always found it the best policy to be completely open and candid in my interviews, or correspondence, with the responsible officials of the Department. With this position I feel that you are in complete accord. Please, therefore, treat my letter as official to you only. In other words, I have no desire whatsoever that copies of it should be sent out to your officials in the field. Given Departmental Field Officials of experience and sympathetic approach, I would, for my own part, prefer not to limit unduly either the scope or the nature of their recommendations and even criticisms concerning points, such as the one under discussion (cattle versus tinned milk,) in their visits to the schools. There is always of course the odd man on the side of both the Church and the Department who is lacking either in experience or the personal qualities required for the proper discharge of his
Mr R.A.Hoey....................3

important duties.

Believe me,

Yours very sincerely,

SG:G General Secretary.
Leask, Sask.,
October 3rd 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of September 19th, file 132-2-14, enclosing a copy of a letter you received from Rev. T. B. R. Westgate in regard to the supply of milk at the Lac La Ronge Indian Boarding School. I note that they state that they receive an average of 6 gals a day of milk for 309 days. Their cows may give 6 to eight gals of milk in the summer months, but throughout the winter months, I doubt very much whether they get more than three gals a day, if they get that.

With reference to the last paragraph of Rev. Westgate's letter, Rev Fisher, the Principal has taken the matter of clearing this piece of land up with me many times and I advised him that I would not recommend it as this land will be useless when it is cleared as it is all rock formation. After they had spent $500.00 on clearing a piece of land like the one in question it would not produce enough to feed one cow. To keep land of this nature in good condition it would be necessary to import soil and use fertilizer, otherwise the land would only produce one crop successfully.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of

Zephanish Charles, Pupil No. 133

of the Lac la Ronge (Anglican) Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge, Sask.

who died at the School, L. L. R. (place) on May 24th, 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM No. 414.

A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? April 19th, 1937.

2. At what time of day?

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? This boy fell sick with measles during the epidemic at this school, and was put to bed on the above date.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Usual treatment for measles, and was cared for as T.B. patient after the measles disappeared.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? See answer to Question 5.

6. When was the doctor called? Dr. LaBlond was at the school at the time this boy took sick, and gave him attention.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? The whole school had been turned into a hospital to take care of the measles patients, so boy was kept at school.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? See answer to above questions.

9. Add any other useful information here. This boy had been apparently very well up to the time he took measles. Doctors' previous reports would indicate that his general health had been regarded as average. He evidently had the beginnings of T.B., which were made active by the measles.

Principal.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Matthew McKenzie, Pupil No. 154, of the Anglican Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge, who died at Lac la Ronge School (place) on May 30th, 1937.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? Was in bed about two months before he got measles on April 16th.

2. At what time of day?

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? Sent to bed to rest by Nurse Reid.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Kept in bed and generally cared for.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Child had temperature indicative of tuberculosis, and was given Aspirin Gr. V.

6. When was the doctor called? Dr. La Blond arrived at the school on March 13th to deal with measles epidemic, and examined this boy.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport?

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? As indicated in Answer 4.

9. Add any other useful information here.

This boy apparently never very strong. General appearance when he entered school would indicate he had had rickets. General health improved after coming to school, until a few months ago. (Entered school 14/7/33) After he got measles on April 16th, condition quickly got worse.

Principal.

Note: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.

I attended Matthew McKenzie from April 16th/37
to Oct. 23/37. The immediate cause of death was
Pulmonary Tuberculosis

The contributory cause of death was

C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of... have been recorded? If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

This child was in the dormitory, suffering from T.B., with sixty other children where the ventilation is not of the best and the room being terribly overcrowded. The food these children received is... poor... not the right quality for growing children. I recommend the Department have all these children X-rayed with all T.B. patients segregated and proper treatment given. The number of pupils attending school should be cut down as it is terribly overcrowded in the class rooms and dormitories. After our Measles epidemic... more... more... more... B. will develop. It is utterly impossible to control the spread of disease under present conditions. These children, in most cases, would be a lot better off at home.

[Signature]

Chairman—Indian Agent.
