1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Abelsan Burd have been recorded? If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

This child was in the dormitory with sixty other children, as in the case of Mathew McKenzie, and when the measles epidemic broke out it was impossible to stop him from getting it. Dear Sir:

Kindly find enclosed Reports of Inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the deaths of Matthew McKenzie and Absalom Bird, both pupils of the Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge, Sask.

The reason for my delay in sending in these reports is because I expected to be sent up to Lac la Ronge with the Treaty Party this summer, and I intended getting more information and details regarding the death of those two boys who both died after I left the School last April. I was not fortunate enough to get the position this year; yet, I still hoped to be able to take a little vacation on my own, this summer, at Lac la Ronge, and get the desired information, but my finances did not allow me this luxury.

Kindly explain to Doctor McGill the reason for my delay in this matter, and oblige

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have the honour to advise the Department that an application has been made by Mr. Dennehy, Teacher of the Boarding School on Muscowequan's Reserve, for permission to enrol 3 additional pupils as Boarders at that School, in addition to the 15 for whose maintenance there provision has been made, thus making 18 Boarders in all.

The children whose enrolment is asked for have been Boarders at the school during the Winter months, having been taken in by the Teacher out of pity, and at his own expense, and he now desires that a grant may be allowed for their maintenance for the March and June quarters of the current fiscal year, and under the circumstances, I would respectfully recommend that his request be granted as the unexpended portion of the appropriation for this school will allow this outlay.

Will the Department kindly instruct whether this may be done?

I may add that an amount was placed in the estimates for 1893-94 for 18 Boarders at this school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Deputy of the, Your obedient Servant,

Supt. General, Commissioner.

of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.
Indian Commissioner

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant submitting the application of Mr. Denchey, teacher of the Boarding School on Muckwagamais Reserve for permission to enroll 3 additional pupils as boarders and also for the appropriation of a grant for their maintenance for March and four quarters of the current year.

In behalf of the Catholic Missionaries of La 'Appelle the undersigned, Superintendent of the Catholic Missions in the Diocese of St. Boniface, begs leave to state respectfully that:

1. The buildings have become all together insufficient for the number of children to be accommodated. viz., the school-room is used for recreation-room for the boys, and the dining-room for a recreation-room and a sewing-room for the girls. The principal is miserably installed, and the plaster of the house is falling off.

2. The agent Mr. J. Finlayson, has asked for a grant of $2,000 (two thousand dollars) and the Inspector of the Catholic School M. J. A. Bétonnay as well as the doctor Mr. Hall, believe also that the necessity of new buildings is urging.

3. The Indians are quite decided not to send their children outside of the Reserve.

4. Mr. Finlayson, agent, has got a grant to the two Boarding Schools, Muscowequan's Boarding School.

F. W. Dennehy, Principal

July 8th. 95.

Dear Sir:

His Grace the Archbishop of St. Boniface having informed me that a grant of $1800.00 has been promised for the buildings of the Boarding School on Muscowequans Reserve at Touchwood Hills, I beg to make application for having the school removed from where it is now, and located at the place where we have our church, that is on the piece of land which we own at a distance of about one mile, and a half from the actual site of the school.

We have here a good stone building 24ft.x by 56, which is not yet completed inside, and which we could use for a part of the school. We could add to it another part 28ft.x 50. Also a stone building, and the two combined together would make a good and substantial school house as the accompanying sketch shows; which, I think could never be obtained if the sum of money granted would be employed to improve, or to enlarge, the old school building which is too fall soon into ruins.

This combination would also accommodate better the children who are now too far from the church.

Besides, as we intend to have in a,
a time more or less remote. Sisters to manage the boarding school, it would be necessary in such a case to have the school near the church.

For these reasons I think it would be advisable to make the change which I propose today.

I may add also that the Agent Mr. Wright who knows well all the circumstances of the case seems to be greatly in favour of the proposed change.

If my request is granted I would be greatly obliged if you could let me know it as soon as possible, in order to be able to have the work done as soon as possible, when the days are long and the weather more convenient for stone work.

I have the honor to be

Sir

Your obedient Servant

Sgd. J.P. Magnard.

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina.
EXAMINED
SCHOOL BRANCH.

Regina, Man.,
31st January, 1896.

Sir:-

In reply to your letter of the 24th inst. (received here on the 29th) reporting the intended marriage on the 27th inst. of pupil No 030, Angelique Dejarlais of the Miscowequan Boarding School, and quoting official letter of even number of the 30th September 1894 as authority for her discharge; I beg to say that the authority was given for the reason that Mr. Dennehy's application for her discharge claimed that she was "required at home by her widowed mother who is sick and alone and can no longer do without her eldest daughter".

The force of this plea was fully recognized by authority given for her discharge, but the fact that she has been in constant attendance at the school ever since that time -16 months- seems a tolerably clear indication that the condition of things as represented by the Principal, necessitating the discharge, has

The Indian Agent,

Touchwood Hills,
Kutawa P.O.,
Assa.,
has ceased to exist.

This view is apparently confirmed by the fact that the discharge is now being made not that the girl may aid her mother, but in order to allow of her marriage with Thomas Green; this being the case it would appear that the proper course would have been to renew the application for discharge with the usual information required in such cases as outlined in Circular No 0122, of the 17th January 1895.

Since however the marriage arranged for the 27th has presumably taken place, it remains for you to report for the Department's information, on the prospects generally of the newly married couple being able to maintain themselves and the probability of their carrying out in their home the lessons they have learned at the school.

Particular information should be given concerning their house, its size, finish, furniture, whether erected on a "location", how many acres ready for cultivation, number and classification of cattle, and any other information tending to show that the girl's discharge with a view to her marriage was advisable and desirable.

It
It is taken for granted that they live in a house of their own, and by themselves, thus rendering their retrogression less probable.

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

sgd. A.E. Forget.

Sir:-

In reply to your letter above referred to, relative to the marriage of pupil No 030, Angelique Dejarlais, of Muscowequan's Boarding School, to Thos Green of Muscowequan's band, I beg to say that the husband is working for Mr Dennehy, Principal of the Boarding School, for $3.00 per month and board. The newly married couple are living by themselves, in a good comfortable house Isklofest, near the school, which belongs to Mr Dennehy. They have their house fairly well furnished, such as bedstead and bedding table, chairs, stoves, dishes, cupboard, etc. They have 5 cows 2 steers and one heifer.

I think they have both done as well as can be expected, and that the marriage was advisable and desirable.

I have, etc,

TO SECURE PROMPT DESPATCH SEND REPLY TO
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, 3rd May, 1897.

To Secretary,

I do not think the Department ought to agree to the proposition hereunder, although recommended by the Indian Council. The plea of a desire to avoid taxation may or may not be objectionable; but if once the Department became the owner of the school buildings, it would not be able to decline to entertain applications for grants to increase, enlarge or improve the buildings as it can now. On the other hand, if disposed to accept the transfer of the property, the Department ought to insist on an absolutely unconditional deed. Otherwise, if at any time the buildings should be handed back to the Church authorities, the Department would lose the value of any improvements made by it.

H.C. Ross.

Ottawa 10th May, 1898.

Sir,

I enclose herewith for your report thereon, and also for such action as you consider necessary, a letter of the 27th ultimo, from Mr. Fred. W. Dennehy, in which he states that there are two non treaty children in attendance at the Muscowequon's Boarding School who have been reported as belonging to treaty and who have consequently drawn annuity.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary,
The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.
I have the honour to beg to bring to your notice irregularities & misapplication of public money in Muscoweau's Indian Boarding School, Touchwood Hills Agency.

There are maintained at that school two non-treaty children to whom fictitious names & treaty numbers have been given on the returns, so that the rent grant for Indian children has been drawn this year for non-treaty children. This can be verified now, if promptly investigated; and leakage of public funds stopped.

The irregularities consist in marking children present in class or in maintenance at the school, who were out of the classroom on the days certified to, or absent altogether from the school for periods more or less long. I know certainly several such cases exist; but refrain from estimating the number you may be able to verify, as a lot would depend on the testimony of the children or their parents—an unreliable factor.

I refrain from specifying names & dates, for the time being—but if further light is desirable on the subject, and you decide to investigate, I can help the Department to testimony both documentary & verbal sufficient to substantiate my statements.

I ought to be well acquainted with the facts as I opened Muscoweau's School in '86 (among the Indian topics) & only left it in '97, at the request of the Oblate Fathers, who got it removed from Govt (Ind. Reserve) land to their own adjoining private property, the Ind. Department, whose servant I had always considered myself, being unable to interfere.
As to my reliability, I am probably known to most of the Western officials from the Commissioners & Inspectors down & could also refer you to our local member Mr. McDonald M.P., but I am unknown to the Hon. Mr. Douglas M.P.

Private considerations, as well as zeal for the purity of the public service, impell me to address you this letter, after due & serious consideration.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Fred. W. Dennehy

The Honorable

Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, No. II6,733/1, of the 10th instant, and enclosure, being a letter from Mr. F.W. Denehy drawing the attention of the Department to irregularities and misappropriation of public money in Muscowequan's Indian Boarding School, Touchwood Mills Agency.

The charges made are - 1st. That there are maintained at that school two non-treaty children to whom fictitious names and treaty numbers have been given on the Returns so that the Government Grant for Indian children has been drawn this year for non-treaty children. 2nd. That children are marked as being present in class and in maintenance at the school who are out of the class room on the day marked, or absent altogether for periods more or less long.

In regard to the first charge: There is one non-treaty pupil at the Muscowequan School and his admission thereto was duly authorized whilst Mr. Denehy himself was in charge of the school. In this connection I may add that non-treaty children are to be found in nearly all the Industrial and Boarding Schools and their admission has been authorized pursuant to a letter from the Department to Rev. Father LaCombe, No. II7,657/8, dated the 18th of September 1895, a copy of which

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
which was transmitted for the guidance of this office under cover of official letter of even date and number.

Regarding the second charge: I do not see how Mr. Denehy could have preferred it unless he was personally aware of the absences of the pupils coupled with a knowledge of the contents of the returns. He may, of course, have noticed from time to time a pupil absent from school but it is exceedingly unlikely that Mr. Denehy could have seen the Returns either at the Agency or at the School. At the Agency it would have been a breach of confidence, and the relation in which Mr. Denehy stands towards the School makes it impossible for him to have obtained this information there. This charge has therefore all the appearance of having been made at random and without any specific information on the part of Mr. Denehy, and solely with the view of harassing the authorities of the school from pure personal spite, for it must not be forgotten that Mr. Denehy after being in charge of that school for several years (and I must say with considerable credit to himself for a time) was dismissed for what was fast becoming habitual drunkenness. Since his dismissal he has entertained no light feeling of rancor against the authorities of the school. This sentiment, I fear, is more likely to have moved him in the present instance than a feeling of interest in the purity of the public service.

The Returns, as the Department is aware, are certified by the head teacher and the Agent, and it is not likely the latter especially would attach his signature to a certificate unless reasonably certain that the statements contained therein were correct.

Taking all into consideration I do not think that in the absence of particulars the department would be justified in causing an enquiry into this general charge.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Commissioner.
Department of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa, 30 May 1892

Accountant:

I do not know why this matter was dealt with in your Branch in the first instance; but the course having been followed, I think I had better not take up the matter now.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your favour of the 1st instant, No. 116,733/1, sent to me here from Kutawa, enclosing copy of letter from Mr. Dennehy, dated 27th April.

I expect to be in Touchwood at the Treaty Payments, in July, when I shall see Mr. Dennehy, and give him full opportunity of making his statements, and furnishing proof, and will report results without any delay.

In the meantime I would remark that I inspected Muscoweuan's School on 21st April last. Thirty-one pupils were present, including two non-treaty, which I noted on my report. The Principal informed me that he had authority to include these two pupils and this I verified by the letter of the Commissioner giving such authority, so that there was no concealment of the matter and no fictitious names were necessary. On a second visit, 12th May, there were thirty-five pupils present, including the two non-treaty, and only thirty paid for, this being the limit.

I compared the attendance during the year with the visits made from time to time by the Agents and found them to agree with the roll. The Agents enter the number present on their diaries each visit, and I do not believe that any attempt was made to deceive, or charge for more pupils than the actual attendance warranted.

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-1, part 1)
Mr. Dennehy knew I was at the Agency from 12th April to 21st May, and if he was so "actuated with a zeal for the purity of the public service" as he says he was, it would have been easy for him to have given me the information necessary and to have any abuses corrected.

As a matter of fact I called on Mr. Dennehy on 12th May before making my second visit. I was passing near his school and merely called, and if he had wanted his charges "promptly investigated" surely this was a favourable time, when I was on the spot, but he never said one word of any irregularity.

It is well known that Mr. Dennehy was relieved of his situation early in 1897 for very good reasons and one of which was noticed in my report of the previous year. Mr. Dennehy feels sore at being dismissed, and I am afraid his feelings have got the better of him and he has allowed other motives than the "purity of the service" to actuate him in making the charges he has. The transfer of the property is another vexed question, as this will deprive his school of a good portion of the revenue from taxable property.

However, I will give him a full chance to prove his charges. Muscowequan's School, to my mind, is one of the best conducted in the Territories. Everything was in apple pie order, the staff most efficient, and the Rev. Sister Valade an accomplished teacher, and the pupils showed careful training.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Dear Sir,

The Revd. Father Perreault who is presently in charge of the Muscowequan's Boarding School, informs me that he has not received the authorization of taking more than thirty children at his school, and that he has now this number about complete.

May I ask you to be kind enough to recommend that the authorization of receiving a greater number of children be granted by the Department. As you know, there are, in the District of Touchwood Hills, and particularly at Nut Lake, quite a number of children who attend no school at all. We would like to do all in our possible to bring their parents to send them to school, and we would like to be sure to be able to receive them whenever they consent.

The Muscowequan's School is the only boarding school we have presently in the whole district of Assiniboia, and if the authorization asked for were granted it would be a good opening and the only one we have to receive some of the younger children of other reserves when the

parents
parents could not very well send to Qu'Appelle Industrial School on account of their young age and on account of this last school having its number completed.

An augmentation in the number of children at Muscowequan's School would only cause an expense comparatively small and only for the board and tuition of children. As you know, our school building is certainly large enough to receive easily forty children; we have the teachers and other employees required, we have also the furniture required.

As we had been given to hope that the authorized number of pupils would be augmented after the 1st. of July we have provided for it in advance. Last May I have purchased ten new iron beds which I have forwarded to the School last week. So the School would be ready to receive easily forty children if we had the authorization.

You have been kind enough to inform us that Mr. Inspector McGibbon has found the school very satisfactory; you know that the Rev. Father Perreault and the Rev. Sisters spare no trouble to make the school successful in every respect, it would greatly encourage them and promote the work of education if the authorization asked for were granted.

I beg therefore to ask you to be kind enough to recommend that the authorization

authorization required to receive forty children instead of thirty be granted by the Department for the Muscowequan's Boarding School, and to see that the necessary funds for that are put in the estimates of present fiscal year.

I have the honour &c.&c.

J.F.Magnan.

TOUCHWOOD AGENCY.

Muscowequan Boarding School,
Touchwood Hills, Assa.
December 16th, 1902.

To Honorable Clifford Sifton
Minister of the Interior
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to request of the Indian Department to authorize us to receive ten more boarders for the ensuing year, for the following reasons:

1. The Indians in our vicinity feel more inclined to send their children to school, and I think it would be very easy to find that additional number for our school.

2. Our school house can easily accommodate at least fifty children; an increase of ten boarders would make the number forty, which would enable us to use the whole building, which was erected at a heavy cost, never yet covered by school revenue.

3. An increase of ten would place education within the reach of more Indians, without increasing the staff, and would help us to meet, or approximately, the running expenses of the school, which cannot be done with a grant for thirty children only.

Hoping to have the present request granted,

I remain

Yours truly,

J.E.H. Thibaudet
Principal

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 7th January, 1906

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Martineau forwards an application from the Rev. J.R.S. Thibodeau, Principal of Muscowequan's Boarding school for an increase of 10 in the number of pupils provided for there. The Department now pays for 30.

This boarding school was started in 1895 and is not situated on a reserve, although the Department contributed $1800.00 towards the building and made provision for 30 pupils at $72.00 per annum. Both the Agent and our Inspector report the school to be well conducted and doing good work.

The Census Return for last year shows the population of the Touchwood Hills Agency to be 850 with a school population of 156. The Roman Catholics have 105 adherents, while the Church of England have 130, the remaining 615 Indians being pagans.

The Church of England have a boarding school in this Agency on Geo. Gordon's reserve with provision for 30 children, the same number as is allowed Muscowequan's, and there is also a Ch. of England day school on Day Star's reserve with about 15 pupils.

The Department has treated both these boarding schools alike and any increase made to the one would entail a similar application from the other. These two school I consider make ample boarding school.

Mr. Mc Donald's letter sent to Mr. Bishop with this memorandum —
On Saturday the 28th ult. I visited the Boarding School at Micmacogami where I found a mild outbreak of Scarlet Fever which has been no deaths. I think there is no danger of any. Little Valada has treated them excellently. I have quarantined the premises until all danger of infection seems past. I found two cases in the reserve.

Next I visited Providence Day School reserve, where they were in fairly good shape, no infectious diseases.

This morning I came to find that there had been a few mild cases of diphtheria. I found no infectious diseases. The health of the school children is good, with the exception of one child who will soon be well.

The basement of the school has been flooded with water; there is water even just under the floor. The cellar floor has more than a few inches of water. This condition cannot but be detrimental to the health comfort of the occupants. There is no way to remedy this except by making a ditch to run low around about a hundred yards away.

C. J. Cartier M.D.
I hereby certify that the doctor H. Montague has performed his duties efficiently and satisfactorily to me.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

You will see from Dr Cathew's report on the Muscowequan boarding school, that he considers the basement in a most unsanitary condition owing to its being flooded by water and states that it should be remedied at once. The Commissioner, who called the attention of the Church authorities to this matter, reports that they claim it to be the Department's duty to make the drain.

The Department is in no way responsible for the lack of drainage, as the school was put up by the Church authorities on a site selected by them and after their own plans. It has already contributed $1800.00 towards the buildings.

I would recommend that the Commissioner be authorized to have the work done, if the Church still refuses to attend to it and have the cost charged against their grant.

Sir,

I regret to report to you a case of housebreaking and theft, committed by three pupils of Muscovequan's Boarding School, on the night of Sunday the 25th, August.

And I beg to state that these boys:- Francis Desjarlais, No. 60, J. B. Desjarlais, No. 71, and a young lad named Daniel Pelletier, aged 9 years, not as yet on school register, were missing from the school premises this particular afternoon, and were not discovered until the following day (Monday), when it was known that the Hudson's Bay Co., store, Touchwood, had been robbed the night previous, and on search, the above named lads were found in a bush in the vicinity with the money and articles missing in their possession, cash amounting to $12.85 and $65.00 worth in goods, with exception of a blanket, a hat and pair of gloves, the stuff taken by them was pop-corn, mouth-organs, ribbon and such trash. The boys were arrested and taken before the local Justice of the Peace, found guilty and the two older ones, as the leaders, were sentenced to two months in Regina gaol, and the little fellow sent back to school to be summarily punished, by order of the Court.

I have since written the Principals of the schools here, warning them that they are responsible and should be most careful and prompt to ascertain the whereabouts of their pupils when missing from the school premises, and to have their staff to strictly comply with their orders.

The Hon. David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,

Winnipeg.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obt. servant,
(signed) H. Martineau,
Indian Agent.

OTTAWA, 15th November, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With regard to the application from Rev. Father Magman, Principal of Muscowequan's boarding school for provision for an increased number of pupils, I beg to say that 30 children are all that are at present provided for. He has accommodation for fully 40 pupils and the staff.

The Gordon's Boarding school conducted by the Church of England is also in the Touchwood Hills Agency, and it has provision for the same number of pupils.

In addition to these two boarding schools there is also one day school in this Agency.

Out of 847 Indians as shown by the last census as belonging to this Agency, 628 are pagans and there are about 150 children of school age and there would be no difficulty in obtaining the additional number asked for by Father Magman, if the necessary funds were provided.

Upon referring to Mr Inspector Graham's report on this school, dated the 5th July last, I beg to say that this would appear to be the most satisfactorily managed boarding school in the Territories. Mr Graham states that the Principal has started a farm in connection with the school which was a model of neatness. The grain was well put in and well advanced.
The school property consists of 160 acres belonging to the Oblates Father, 78 of which were under crop. They had 52 head of cattle with 7 horses and other live stock, which were all well cared for and successfully wintered. Mr Graham further states that the boys received a thorough training in farming and the care of stock and that the girls, although small, are efficient housekeepers, making all the butter and bread used in the institution.

Although this school is said to be so well managed, the financial statement furnished by the Principal for the year ended 30th June last, shows a deficit of $1076.60. Supplies of all kinds are expensive in this locality and with the small number of pupils provided for, it would appear to be impossible to make ends meet. I think that if the Department could see its way to increase the number of pupils for next year, it would only be a fair recognition of the good work done at the school.
Mr. Benson -

Last summer, I had the honour to receive from you a congratulating letter on the work done at our school. Indeed, we have always endeavoured to make it a success, a credit to the Indian Department. Agent, Mr. W. Burron, inspected the School. He seemed to be highly pleased with what he heard and saw; at least, he said so. He greatly approved my present request and promised me his support. I did, Honorable Sir, grounded on your so kind and encouraging letter of the 15th of July last, on the report of our so just Inspector, the recommendation of him so devoted Agent, that I pray for a furnace. OTTAWA, 20th April, 1935

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Rev. J.A. Magnam, Principal of Muscowequan's boarding school applies for a grant for a new furnace for his school to replace the present heating arrangement by stoves. He says that he has installed a water system throughout the school and without a furnace it will be useless in the winter as it would freeze and break the pipes.

He gives no idea of the cost and there is no provision for this work. The Department has already contributed $1800.00 towards the building of this school which belongs to the Church and was built by them after their plans. If we accede to his request it will most likely form a precedent for other boarding schools to make similar demands.

Father Magnam gives as a reason for asking for this grant the encouragement held out to him in a letter of the 16th July last. No such letter was written from the Department, and he most likely refers to one he received from the Assistant Commissioner, written after the receipt of Mr Inspector Graham's report on this school, as Mr McKenna states in a marginal note on this report that "So excellent a 'sowing calls for special commendation and I have written the Principal accordingly'. I think it is a great mistake for officials of the Department to write such commendatory letters, as in this case the..."
Principal is using Mr McKenna's letter as a lever to raise funds.

Honourable Sir,

Just few months ago, the doctor in charge of this school was paid a monthly or as a visit to the school. But since the change, since he had orders to come on special calls only, we are in a bad fix as far as admission of children is concerned. They must be examined by the doctor, and whom will pay the expense of the trip? The Indian Department cannot accept that school who cannot meet the two ends, console. Ottawa, 16th October, 1905.

Reverend Sir:-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., reporting that on account of the periodical visits of the Doctor to your School having been discontinued it is impossible for you to have pupils medically examined before admission in all cases, and that, owing to this, you are sometimes deprived of the grant for a considerable period.

In view of the circumstances the Department will consent to pay for new pupils taken in to fill vacancies from the date of their admission until they are examined by the Doctor, but should such examination prove unsatisfactory they will have to be removed.

The Department, however, will expect you to exercise great care in the selection of pupils who are to receive this privilege.

The Indian Commissioner will be advised of this concession.

Your obedient servant,

E. STEWART
Asst. Secretary.

Sir:-

A letter has been received from the Principal of the Muscowequan's Boarding School in which he claims that owing to the discontinuance of the periodical visits of the medical officer he is sometimes obliged to wait four or five months before he can have pupils examined who are required to fill vacancies, thus losing the per capita grant for that time.

In view of this state of affairs the Department has informed the Principal that he will be permitted to fill vacancies temporarily pending the examination by the regular medical man and that the grant will be allowed for the time they are enrolled, but, if they fail to pass the necessary medical examination, they are to be discharged. He has also been instructed to use the greatest care in selecting pupils to fill any vacancies that may occur.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Honourable Sir,

I am very sorry indeed to have to report to you that our Boarding School suffered a great loss recently. Some months ago a few of our horses got sick and fearing slander, I wrote to the Government in Regina about it. They sent down an inspector to investigate, resulting in shooting five horses. Previous to the inspector coming four died making a total loss of nine. So we have not a horse left even to drive or do any kind of work. We had quite a few acres of land ready for crop and were just starting to seed where the inspector arrived. As we have got no horses nor money to purchase any we shall not be able to put in a crop of any kind. Since two years I had bought

bought seven mares and expected to have seven colts this spring. Now all hope are gone.

Morrison can inform you, our boys were becoming excellent farmers and were certainly a credit to the School and to the Indian Department. I could also state here as the Agent can tell you that whatever we were making out of the farm was entirely spent for the benefit of the School as I considered I would be failing in any duty as Principal if I should not endeavour to the best of my ability to encourage the boys in every respect and to teach them an idea of self-respect and self-support so that when they would leave the School that they would make successful and prosperous farmers, be an example and an incentive to the other Indians.

If I had at least a promise of some help I could even at this late date buy some horses and put in good many of oats, but everything seems to foil me unless the Indian Department would be kind and generous enough to consider my sad case and help me out so that I might be able to buy two teams and do some work. Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that five of the farm horses belonging to the Muscowequan Boarding School have been slaughtered for glanders. This makes nine head which they have lost since January and they are now in a bad shape for power to work their farm.

The farm at the school is a large one and the loss of their work horses is a heavy blow to them.

The Principal of this school has worked hard to get together an efficient equipment of power and machinery with which to work the land and has incurred considerable liabilities.

He has asked me to place this matter before you and would be very grateful to the Department if they should see fit to give him some assistance towards replacing his working stock.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant

Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
A.J. Adamson Esq., M.P.,
Winnipeg.

Dear Mr. Adamson,

I am very sorry to inform you of our heavy and great loss of late. Some months ago, some of the school horses took sick and thinking that it might be flu, which I am now convinced that it was. I informed the Govt. at Regina they sent down an inspector to investigate, resulting in the inspector shooting five of our horses making a total loss of nine from the disease. We were just starting to seed and now we have not a single horse to work with or even to drive even if we wanted to go anywhere. We shall not be able to put in a bushel of grain this year because we have not a horse left and we have no money to buy any and cannot hire any in this busy and cold season. If the school depends largely on

A.J. Adamson Esq., M.P.,
Winnipeg.
Largely on the crops disposed of we shall be in a sorrowful condition this year.

I am writing to the Indian Department at Ottawa, asking them if they could help us out a little to enable us to buy a couple of teams. I thought I would consult you of my intentions if you should be good enough to use your influence with the Dept in our behalf. Now, Mr. Adamson, if you should be kind as to do so, besides considering it a personal favor to myself it would also be a gracious and most charitable act to our poor Indian Boarding School.

Respectfully yours,

J.J. Mayron,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I regret that I have to report to you that our school has suffered a great loss recently. Some months ago some of our horses fell sick and fearing slander I notified the Dept. to come and investigate. Previous to the inspector coming four of our horses died and when he did arrive he examined and tested the remaining, resulting in shooting five and placing the four remaining under quarantine.

I have not got now a single horse to put in my crop and as I have no money to pay any I cannot put in crop of any kind this year.

Though the season is rather late yet we had quite a few acres ready and had just started seeding when the inspector came. I thought of writing to the Indian Dept., Ottawa, asking...

Dear Sir,

We very much regret the inability of the Department to assist us in the matter of the heating apparatus for our new school, inasmuch as we shall not at present be able to put the existing structure into such thorough repair as we had anticipated owing to the additional expense; however, we will do all in our power to provide for the health and comfort of our Indian children.

Now that we have, or shall have in a few weeks' time more and better accommodation for our pupils, will not the Department allow us to take a few more children? There are fifteen more children on the Reserve whom the parents are desirous of placing in the school, and they have as much right to the assistance of the Department as their neighbors, some of whom to the present
their children have not received any education whatever, still running about half naked and wild.

We feel sure you have as much at heart the welfare of the Indians, as we ourselves, and cannot but admit the reasonability of our request.

It is most true that we are totally unable, with the small number of children we are to present allotted, to even defray expenses for board and clothing, in the present grant. In addition to this we have some to great expense of erecting new buildings in order to comply more with the ideas of the Department. So, will not the Department allow us to utilize our buildings, time and labour to assist them in the important step of civilizing the Indians, and grant us the permission to admit these fifteen children into the school? We may add the our Sunday grant is only for forty, and we shall have good and ample accommodation for fifty-five.

Looking forward to a favorable reply.

Honoured Sir,

[Signature]

To the Department of Indian Affairs

Mr. McLean Secretary

Dear Sir,

I again take the liberty of asking the Department for an increase of ten (from forty to fifty) in the pupilage of the Muscowequan's Boarding School. I see no reason for refusal now that the old objection—the lack of room—is removed.

Since our new buildings are completed we have ample and good accommodation. If our refusal, besides depriving us of the help of which we are in urgent need is at the same time a great disadvantage and drawback, I may not say an injustice to those children not able to receive admittance.
The request for the heating apparatus for the said school has been refused by the Department. The same Department has also refused the request for an increase of stipend (Ref. 186721-1 Oct 20th/91) on the grounds that the appropriation for Indian education placed at the disposal of the Indian Dept. for the current year were insufficient to permit of an increase.

Though Mr. Morrison, Indian Agent has already forwarded his estimates for the coming year, I understand there is still time for you to provide for the administration of the more funds for April 1st 1910. And such a request can not be refused at this time of the year.

With my best wishes of happiness and success to all the members of the Department, I remain

Yours truly,

J.H.T. Gibbendran.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Father Guy, at the request of the authorities of the Muscowequan Boarding School, has applied for an increase in the pupilage.

A grant is, at present, provided for 50 pupils and it requested that an increase of 10 be added to this number. The school can provide accommodation for this increase.

In letter of 19th of February, last, you informed Father Guy that this amount would receive consideration when the supplementary estimates were being prepared.

As this school can provide the accommodation and can also easily secure the extra number of pupils, I consider that the increase asked for should be granted. Our appropriation for Indian Education will, no doubt, be able to stand the expenditure required.

I shall be pleased to have your decision regrading this request.

Sir:

I enclose herewith Nurse LeDrew's report on the Muscowequan Boarding School, and I am of the opinion that the Department should take some action in regard to the supervision that is given the children at this institution.

This is not the first time that I have had it reported that the school is dirty and that the children are neglected. Doctor Phillips has found fault in this connection.

I would also draw your attention to what Nurse LeDrew says regarding the dining room. There is no excuse for this. As you know, this building belongs to the Church and it is their business to see that screens are supplied and that the flies are kept out of the school. We know very well that it is difficult to keep all the flies out but still much could be done that is not done. I consider the condition at this school very unsatisfactory and one that the Department should not pass up lightly.

We have schools on the Reserve that are a credit to the Department and in the fly season you see very few flies for the simple reason that precautionary measures are taken, and then you go to another school and find things such as they are reported here.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham.

EXTRACTS FROM NURSE LE DREW'S REPORT ON MUSCOWEQUAN (R.C.) BOARDING SCHOOL. DATED AUG. 18, 1922.

1. Found the health of the girls on the whole better than the boys. They get better care and supervision from the Sisters. The boys are very dirty and neglected. Spoke to the Principal about this. He says he has great difficulty in getting competent help for the boys' side. Result is the boys' health suffers.

2. Visited the play-room of boys and found it very dirty. Floor was thick with mud, could hardly tell it from the ground outside. Spoke to Principal about this, also to the man who was in charge of boys. The room had not been cleaned up before I left school.

3. Also noticed that quite a number of the boys could not spell their own name when I asked them to do so. Girls were altogether different in this respect.

Ottawa, Oct. 20, 1922.

Reverend Sir:

It has been drawn to the attention of the Department that the conditions on the boys' side of the Muscowequan Indian Boarding School are not very satisfactory. I am urging you to bend every effort to obtain a suitable supervisor for boys' activities and a strong teacher for their classroom. This Department is concerned about the health of our wards and deeply interested in their training for future citizenship. I am sorry that one of our field officers has complained about dirty conditions among the boys and the type of education they are receiving, and I regret the necessity of directing this communication to you.

Our officer reports that the work among the girls is in splendid order, and I trust that by this time conditions on the other side of the house have been improved.

I would further suggest that early next spring screens be supplied for the dining room, in an effort to do away with the large number of flies that bothered the children in this part of the building during the summer.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Very Rev. Fr J.B. Beys O.M.I., Provincial of the Oblate Missionaries for Southern Manitoba and Saskatchewan, has requested me to propose officially to the Department of Indian Affairs, the purchase of Muscowequan Indian Boarding School, at Lestock, Sask.

This present proposal may be also considered as the answer to the Department's letter, dated February 20th, 1923, to Most Rev. Archbishop Mathieu requesting complete particulars in the matter.

At the request of Very Rev. Father Beys the following are respectfully submitted to your appreciation:

1o-It is the opinion of Very Rev. Fr Beys and his Administrative Board that $35,000.00 is a very moderate estimate of the value of all the buildings of the Muscowequan School.

The annexed diagram gives the exact disposition and dimensions of the buildings with their respective valuation. Kindly note that this valuation was made before the war and therefore based on pre-war prices, far below the present ones. We do not doubt that in spite of the necessary depreciation since said valuation was made the buildings are worth today more than in 1914.

2o-Very Rev. Fr Beys and Administrative Board find that the sum of $6,000.00 mentioned in last year's valuation of Lestock's School (Statement annexed to letter of Very Rev. Fr Beys to Mr. Scott, February 17th, 1923) and intended for cattle, machinery and furniture, is a very fair valuation for the above.

3o-It is also the opinion of Very Rev. Fr Beys and Board that a complete section of land would be required for the School. In fact, it was with this view that the Oblate Administration bought Section 14 of Township 27, Range 15, West of 2nd Meridian, on which the school is presently erected. The price of $20.00 an acre (or $12,800.00 for the whole section) is very moderate and should appeal to the Department. Moreover the accompanying plan of Township 27, Range 15-W.2nd M., shows that Section 14 is entirely enclosed in the Muscowequan Reserve and should, therefore, as a matter of good policy and to regularize the plan of the Reserve, be purchased by the Department.

To sum up the amounts above proposed viz:

Main building and outbuildings $35,000.00
Cattle, machinery, furniture $6,000.00
Land: Section 14-Tp 27-R 15-W.2 M. $12,800.00

we reach a total of $53,800.00
and offer the School building and outbuildings, the cattle, machinery, furniture, and the land as described for said sum or better for $55,000.00 as indicated last year.

You will note on the enclosed plan of Township 27 that, besides Section 14, the Oblate Missionaries own the whole of Section 25, W.½ of Section 23, legal subdivision N.½ of legal subdivision 2 and legal subdivision 7 and 8 of Section 22. All those lands are used for the benefit of the school and could be sold to the Department but as the outlay (1099 acres at $18.00; $16,485.00) would be a substantial addition to the amount above proposed we do not think proper, for the present, to suggest the purchase of land outside of Section 14.

I understand that the sum of $35,000.00 has been placed in the Main Estimates in view of buying a R.C. Indian Boarding School. That amount falls short by $20,000.00 from the sum presently asked. I am confident that you will be in a position to enclose this balance in the Supplementary Estimates or that the appropriations in the Main Estimates will allow your securing the amount from the general vote.

I take the liberty to propose, in the name of Very Rev. Fr. Boys O.M.I., Inspector Murison as Government valuator for this School. Mr. Murison has been, for a long time Indian Agent on the Reserve and he is perfectly conversant with the situation and all other circumstances. Moreover, he can be relied upon as a fair and impartial valuator.

Kindly consider this present letter as the official request from the Oblate Administration for the purchase of Muscoweguan Indian Boarding School.

Hoping that you will give this matter the same effective attention as that given to the purchase of Kenora Indian Boarding School in 1922, I remain,

Very truly yours,

Joseph [signature]

CANADA
May 29th, 1923.

MEMO, FOR FILE:

I have examined the Auditor General's reports and the correspondence on file and I find we have made payments other than the regular per capita grants, etc., to the Muscowequan Indian Boarding School, of:

- 1895-96 - $1800 - Buildings,
- 1907-08 - $600 - Stock,
- 1922-23 - $400 - Well.

It is also proposed to expend the sum of $1400 this fiscal year for a gas engine and other equipment.

Sup't. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, May 30, 1923.

Dear Father Guy:

I have your letter of the 7th ultimo, relative to the purchase of the Muscowequan Indian Boarding School, at Lestock, Sask. I have noted your suggestions - made on behalf of His Grace Archbishop Mathieu and Very Rev. Father Pey. The valuation of $55,800.00 can be verified in the near future by giving a commission of appraisal to an independent valuator.

There was provided by Parliamentary Appropriation the sum of $35,000.00 for the purchase this fiscal year of Indian residential school property from the Roman Catholic Church. My suggestion is that we proceed with the transfer of the Muscowequan School, and when you give us title to the property in question - Sec. 14, T.27, R.16, W. 2nd Md., on which the school buildings are situated - the Department, with the approval of His Excellency in Council, will make a payment of $35,000.00, and will direct an official letter agreeing to give the Oblate Fathers the balance of the purchase price as soon as funds are provided for the purpose.

It is not the present intention of the Honourable The Minister to ask for a supplementary appropriation for Indian Education this fiscal year, and I regret to state it is unlikely that sufficient funds could be found in our current Vote to complete the purchase price for this property.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa, Ont.
MEMO FOR FILE:

In connection with the purchase of a residential school the following steps should be taken, after funds have been provided:

1. Get a description of the property.
2. Secure the name of a valuator from the Minister.
3. Give the commission of appraisal.
4. Get the Dept. of Justice to have their agent search the title and submit a draft transfer. (Mr. Williams).
5. After the title is searched, arrange for an Order in Council for the authority to purchase (Mr. Moffat).
6. Get Receiver General's cheque, payable to the Dept. of Justice's agent and the vendor, jointly. (Mr. Paget.)
7. Send cheque to the Dept. of Justice.

June 23, 1923.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Pursuant to our policy to acquire modern Indian residential schools, the Department has been negotiating with the Oblate Order in connection with the proposed purchase of the Moscowquah (R.C.) Indian Boarding School at Lestock, Sask. The Church authorities have valued the property at $55,000.00, and I think we should secure the services of a highly competent man as valuator. The school, its barns and outbuildings and the farm should be appraised with much care, and I should be pleased if you would give me the name and address of a gentleman in Saskatoon, to whom we can give the commission.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart.

Pursuant to our policy to acquire modern Indian residential schools, the Department has been negotiating with the Oblate Order in connection with the proposed purchase of the Macowegan (R.C.) Indian Boarding School at Lestock, Sask. The Church authorities have valued the property at $55,000.00, and I think we should secure the services of a highly competent man as valuator. The school, its barns and outbuildings and the farm should be appraised with much care, and I should be pleased if you would give me the name and address of a gentleman in Saskatoon, to whom we can give the commission.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, July 5, 1923.

Dear Mr. Caswell:

This Department is considering the purchase of the Muscowequan Indian Boarding School, at Lestock, Sask. The property is owned by the Oblate Fathers, with whom we have been negotiating. The Church authorities own nearly three sections of land at Lestock, but it is our intention to purchase only Sec. 14, Tp. 27, R. 15, W. 2., on the northwest quarter of which the school is situated.

Before final arrangements can be made with the owners, I wish to have a valuation of the property by an independent valuator, and I should be pleased if you would undertake the commission of appraisal for the Department. The valuation should show the actual present value of the property, i.e., 640 acres in Sec. 14, the main and other buildings, furniture, stock and machinery. It is the Department's wish that the transfer be completed in the near future, and I shall be pleased if you will undertake this work at your earliest convenience. Please advise me if you will act for us in this connection, and indicate the probable date of your valuation.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

R. W. Caswell, Esq.,
Saskatoon,
Sask.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF TRAVELLING NURSE I. M. LUCAS,
Dated Punnichy Sask., Aug. 11, 1923.
Addressed to Comm. Graham.

I have the honor to submit the following report
on the Muscowequans Indian Boarding School, Touchwood Agency:

The School was clean, the old part, poorly ventilated,
the dormitory, too low and not enough air space and ventilation
for number of children sleeping in room. The laundry is
poorly fitted and ventilated - too cold for girls to work in
in winter.

The children do not get the proper nourishing food,
or enough. They get no milk and no vegetables except potatoes
and very small portion.

(Sgd.) I. M. Lucas,
Travelling Nurse.

Mr. Commissioner Graham's note, dated Aug. 23, 1923.

Has the Department bought this old building?
Apparently unfit for school purposes, according to the Nurse.

Saskatoon, Sask.,
September 7, 1923.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
OTTAWA.

Sir:

In accordance with my former letter, I have made a valuation of the farm, buildings, stock, implements, etc., a full itemized statement of which is enclosed herewith. I have gone into the whole matter fully.

In submitting the value of the buildings I have taken measurements and detail as fully as possible, not having specifications to work on.

In preparing value I have taken material prices as at Saskatoon, which I found was practically the same as at Lestock, any difference being made up by haulage from Lestock to the farm, figuring on the same basis as I did when contracting and building.

You will notice I have added 10 per cent. to material for contractor's profits, and deducted 15 per cent. depreciation from the total on all buildings. While this may not appear to be a fair depreciation, I decided, owing to the good condition of the Girls' Building, that if I made it 15 per cent. all round, the amount would be reasonable.

I might mention that with the exception of the Implement Shed and Granary, all the buildings were well constructed and
in good condition; the outside of all buildings need re-painting and the floor and shingles of Chapel and floor of Boys' Building are in a poor condition.

There is an item of $6,500.00 at the bottom of statement of Girls' Building, which covers steam-heating, plumbing, etc., as per the attached note which I received from Rev. Father Guy. This is the only specification I have been able to secure and I think covers cost of septic tank.

In valuing the Implements and Household Furniture I took cash prices from International Harvester's price-list and T.Eaton's catalogue, and have taken off 25% per cent. for depreciation.

The Live Stock is of very good quality, and I have valued same, not at what it would bring on the market today (except the steers), but at what I consider it worth for operating the farm and as breeding stock.

Farm Lands. I find there is about 560 acres of good quality land; the balance, 80 acres, being largely slough, with poor land surrounding it. These lands adjoin those owned by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company which sell at $15.00 per acre. I have therefore considered the cultivation of the land, and would place a valuation of $20.00 per acre - 640 acres at $20.00, $12,800.00; making a total value of $78,756.35

Hoping you will find this report in order, I am,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-1, part 1)
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

I have examined the Auditor General's reports for the last 20 years and the late files, with reference to departmental expenditure at the Muscovequan Indian Residential School, other than per capita grant. And I find that our expenditure for equipment and plant is inconsiderable. Horses (1907-08) $600, and well (1922-23) $400. I propose making enquiries relative to the land, owned by the Oblates, with a view to ascertaining if the Crown or the Indian Band released any of it for a nominal consideration.

With reference to Mr. Caswell's valuation, in the literary matter he refers to the value of the land (640 acres) as $12,500, ($20 per acre). In his recapitulation of values, "Farm Lands" reads $17,800. His page 18 contains "Bedding," totalling $601, and "Other Linens," totalling $168. These items could hardly be allowed. I am also in doubt as to whether or not the Department supplied either or both of the two typewriters, valued at $350. "Children's clothing, totalling $5592," cannot be allowed.

In Mr. Caswell's recapitulation he did not include the chapel, which he values at $2158. I have checked the additions and deductions and found them correct in some cases.

R.F.A.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, Sept. 19, 1923.

Dear Mr. Caswell:

I wish to acknowledge, with thanks, your letter of the 7th instant, covering your valuation in detail of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School property. I have noted the care which you have exercised in the matter of appraisal and I am pleased to have your explanation of some of the items.

In your letter you have mentioned that the value of the farm is $12,800 - 640 acres at $20; in the recapitulation farm lands are valued at $17,800. I should be pleased if you would throw light on this apparent oversight. On page 12, covering the building known as the chapel, I find a valuation of $2,158 which does not appear in your recapitulation. Please indicate whether or not the chapel was intentionally omitted. I am returning the second copy of the valuation, so that you can make any changes that may arise out of the subject matter of this communication. I also draw your attention to apparent inaccuracies in addition on pages 1 (the recapitulation), 6, 10 and 19.

In your covering letter of the 7th instant your opening words are: "In accordance with my former letter." I regret that the Department has no record of having received this communication from you and I should be pleased if you would send me a copy so that our files will be complete.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

R. W. Caswell, Esq.,
Saskatoon,
Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, Sept. 21, 1923.

Sir:

Travelling Nurse I. M. Lucas, in a report on her visit to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, in August, last, states that the children at this school do not get the proper nourishing food, or enough. They get no milk and no vegetables, except potatoes, and very small portions.

I have to request that you will draw this matter to the attention of the principal. You should point out to him that it is expected that the children will receive a sufficient quantity of nourishing food, also that an ample supply of milk will be furnished for the use of the younger children, especially. I shall be pleased if you will obtain a daily diet sheet, showing the food supplied the children for a period of one week, and forward the same for the information of the Department.

The travelling nurse further drew attention to the poor ventilation in the dormitory, in the old part of the building, for the number of children sleeping in the room. You should draw this matter to the attention of the principal and it may be possible that, by utilizing the windows, more air can be obtained.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. B. Hardinge, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF COMMISSIONER GRAHAM,
HIS NO. 312-11, dated Sept. 15, 1923.

Original on File 121-5-6.

I understand the Department are negotiating for the purchase of this school and I hope no deal will be put through without first having a report from a competent inspector as to the suitability of the building for school purposes. It would be too bad to spend a lot of money on a building not adapted to our work and I think perhaps this building comes under this class to a certain extent. One thing I am sure and that is if the school is to be made modern it will take a lot of money to do it. This added to what is likely to be paid for the school and property would go a long way towards building an up-to-date institution.

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

OFFICE OF THE
DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL
OTTAWA

Ottawa, Sept. 19, 1923.

Dear Mr. Caswell:

I wish to acknowledge, with thanks, your letter of the 7th instant, covering your valuation in detail of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School property. I have noted the care which you have exercised in the matter of appraisal and I am pleased to have your explanation of some of the items.

In your letter you have mentioned that the value of the farm is $12,800 - 640 acres at $20; in the recapitulation farm lands are valued at $17,800. I should be pleased if you would throw light on this apparent oversight. On page 12, covering the building known as the chapel, I find a valuation of $2,158 which does not appear in your recapitulation. Please indicate whether or not the chapel was intentionally omitted. I am returning the second copy of the valuation, so that you can make any changes that may arise out of the subject matter of this communication. I also draw your attention to apparent inaccuracies in addition on pages 1 (the recapitulation), 6, 10 and 19.

In your covering letter of the 7th instant your opening words are: "In accordance with my former letter." I regret that the Department has no record of having received this communication from you and I should be pleased if you would send me a copy so that our files will be complete.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

R. W. Caswell, Esq.,
Saskatoon,
Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-1, part 1)
Cereso Cal Oct 18 1923

Duncan & Scott
Deputy Super General
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

I greatly regret the delay in answering your letter of Sept 19th. I left Saskatoon Sept 25th for California travelling by auto and find your letter here. I hope it has not caused any inconvenience.

I have checked over the statements and corrected the errors.

The error in the value of the land was made by typing a 7 instead of a 2 and in looking it over I missed the error. Any letters in stating the value of the land at twenty dollars per acre was correct.

When writing me again address Campbell Cal.

Yours Truly,
Pitt Carwell
Ottawa, Oct 23/1923

Mr.

Please report on attached letter and return it to the office of the Deputy Superintendent General.

[Signature]

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
October 23, 1923.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have examined Mr. Caswell's amended valuation of the Muscovequan Indian Residential School, and I find that he has omitted the chapel valued $2,156. Adding this to his total of $71,205.85 gives a valuation of $73,363.85. Miscellaneous equipment, totalling $2,537, should have deducted a total of $735.20, the value of the bedding at the institution; the item for children's clothes of $5,606 cannot be allowed, making a total deduction of $6,334.20. Therefore Mr. Caswell's valuation of the property that we should pay for, if we purchase the school in its entirety, is $67,024.15.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, Oct. 25, 1923.

Dear Sir:

This Department proposes purchasing, from the Oblate Fathers of the Immaculate Conception, the property of what is known as the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, consisting of land, school and farm buildings and all other structures on the said land, together with all equipment, furniture, furnishings, machinery, implements, miscellaneous articles and live stock, now in use in connection with the institution. The land, 640 acres more or less, is described as Sec. 14, Tp. 27, R. 15, W. 2 M.; and is situated near Lestock, Sask. I am enclosing three duplicate certificates of title (Numbers 205 N.U., 206 N.U. and 241 M.Z.), which refer in part to the section in question. I am also enclosing lists of the equipment, furniture, furnishings, machinery and live stock, included in this purchase. The prospective vendors' Superior is the Very Rev. Father Beys, of Humboldt.

It is desired that you have your agent at Humboldt search the title to the property in question and submit a draft transfer of the same and a draft bill of sale of the personal property, chattels, etc., to "His Majesty as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs" with his report to you in this matter. The purchase price of the entire property is $55,000; the consideration for the property - 640 acres and buildings - is $41,000, and the consideration for the bill of sale, $14,000.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

The Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Justice,
Ottawa, Ont.

WEEK'S MENU FOR CHILDREN.

As served with milk at each meal.

Every morning sweetened porridge for breakfast, butter, grease, or syrup on bread.

MONDAY—LUNCH for Girls Who Wash—Greased bread or syrup on bread. Cocoa with milk and sugar.

MONDAY—DINNER—Boiled dinner with vegetables. Stewed evaporated apples. Supper—Vegetable soup, fried potatoes, syrup.

TUESDAY—DINNER—Meat pie and potatoes. Ginger or plain cake. SUPPER—Boiled rice with raisins, sugar and milk. Syrup.

WEDNESDAY—DINNER—Roast beef and potatoes. Tapioca. SUPPER—Hashed meat and potatoes. Stewed apples.

THURSDAY—DINNER—Hashed meat with pie crust. Cabbage, potatoes, cocoa. SUPPER—White Beans, butter, syrup.

FRIDAY—DINNER—Salmon with gravy. Turnips, cornstarch. SUPPER—Rice and apricots.

SATURDAY—DINNER—Boiled dinner or beef with brown gravy, carrots, cornstarch. SUPPER—Gravy and potatoes, biscuits.

SUNDAY—DINNER—Baked beans, apple pie. SUPPER—Meat, tapioca, with milk and raisins, syrup.

On Friday fish is served in the morning for breakfast (sardines).

Meat is served at supper for all the big boys.

At 4 P.M. Lunch is served for all the children. Greased bread or bread with syrup.
Sir,

In reply to your letter # 121-5-1 dated September 21st 1923 I have the honour to inform you that I have interviewed the Principal of the Muscowequan School and have informed him of the contents of your letter.

He states that they are a little short of milk at the present time but a further supply will be obtained for the younger children. I drew his attention to that part of your letter regarding the poor ventilation of the dormitory in the old part of the building and he stated that he would see that the windows were more frequently used.

I am attaching a daily diet sheet showing the food supplied the children for a period of one week.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your Obedient Servant

The Secretary
Dept of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Clerk in charge

Memorandum:

Mr. Moffat,

Will you please prepare a memorandum to Council, requesting authority to acquire the Muscovequan Indian Residential School from the Roman Catholic Church. Arrangements for the purchase of the property, including buildings, other improvements, live stock, chattels and effects, have been completed by the Department of Justice, whose local agents have found satisfactory title to the land in question, 640 acres - Section 14, Tp. 27, Rge. 15, West of the 2nd.

The Muscovequan Indian Residential School is modern, well equipped and adequate for the purposes of Indian education. An independent appraiser has fixed the value of the property at $67,024.15.

The Department has arranged with the Church Authorities that the consideration for the entire school property be $55,000 and funds for the purpose were provided in the Main Estimates, 1923-24, Vote No. 879. It is proposed to issue a cheque for the said sum of $55,000, payable jointly to the Oblate Fathers of the Immaculate Conception and the agent of the Department of Justice.

Ottawa, January 4, 1924.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report that, in pursuance of its policy of acquiring, from the various religious denominations, modern Indian residential schools, the Department of Indians Affairs has come to an arrangement, through the Department of Justice of Canada, for the purchase from the Roman Catholic Church of the property of the Muscowequan Indian residential school consisting of the six hundred and forty acres comprising Section 14, township 27, range 15, west of the 2nd meridian, together with the buildings, other improvements, live-stock, chattels and effects connected with the school. The agents of the Department of Justice have found satisfactory title to the land to be acquired by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The Muscowequan Indian residential school is modern, well-equipped and adequate for the purposes of Indian education. According to arrangement with the church authorities, the consideration to be paid by the Department for the property amounts to $55,000.00. The valuation made by an independent appraiser amounts to $67,000.00.

The undersigned would accordingly recommend that Your Excellency in Council be pleased to approve of the issue by the Department of Indian Affairs of a cheque in favour of La Corporation des Reverende Peres Oblats.....

The following is a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by his Excellency the Governor General on the 9TH JANUARY 1924.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 4th January, 1924, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, stating that, in pursuance of its policy of acquiring, from the various religious denominations, modern Indian residential schools, the Department of Indian Affairs has come to an arrangement, through the Department of Justice of Canada, for the purchase from the Roman Catholic Church of the property of the Muscowequan Indian residential school consisting of the six hundred and forty acres comprising Section 14, township 27, range 15, west of the 2nd meridian, together with the buildings, other improvements, live-stock, chattels and effects connected with the school. The agents of the Department of Justice have found satisfactory title to the land to be acquired by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The Muscowequan Indian residential school is modern, well-equipped and adequate for the purposes of Indian education. According to arrangement with the church authorities, the consideration to be paid by the Department for the property amounts to $58,000.00. The valuation made by an independent appraiser amounts to $67,000.00.

The Honourable

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The Minister therefore recommends approval of the issue by the Department of Indian Affairs of a cheque in favour of La Corporation des Reverends Peres Oblats de Marie Immaculée du Nord-Ouest and the Agent of the Department of Justice of Canada jointly for $55,000.00 in full payment for the property of the Muscowequan Indian residential school above referred to, the same to be charged to the Vote for Indian Education No.279, which is in a position to bear the expenditure.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

[Signature]

Clerk of the Privy Council.
January 15, 1924.

MEMORANDUM

I wish to refer you to letter of the Department of Justice dated the 2nd instant. I have examined the draft transfer and I find that there is included a second parcel of land (E.S.E. of Sec. 22, T.27, R.15, W.2nd) which this Department and the vendors had not taken into consideration. I should be pleased if you would draw the Department of Justice's attention to our communication of the 25th of October, in which they were given a description of the land which we proposed to purchase, viz: All of Sec. 14, T.27, R.15, W. 2. You will note that this section is that described in the draft transfer as the first parcel.

The Department of Justice should, I believe, ascertain from their Agent why the second parcel was included, and, in the meantime, their Agent should retain the cheque representing the purchase price until this matter has been settled.

CRIME REPORT.

Re:- Delia, Fred and Emile Malboeuf,
Yorkton, Sask.,
Indian Act.

The Indian Agent at Punnichy telephoned this Detachment on the 24th., inst., that William Malboeuf a half breed residing in Yorkton and the father of the above mentioned children had neglected to send these children back to school at the Muscowequan Reserve after a vacation that had recently been allowed them, and requested this Detachment to have Malboeuf send them back to the school.

Malboeuf was interviewed and declined to do so; he says that he made an arrangement with Father Carriere of Erskine Lake that these children were to remain in school until now, the arrangement being made in 1918, and that they were to be handed over to him at this date. The children themselves are averse to returning, the girl Delia, aged 16 years, complains that improper proposals were made to her by Father Poulette of the school referred to, when she was working in his office at the school, the boys Fred and Emile aged 14 and 15 years respectively say they have received no education in the past six years, being unable to read or write at all, and were employed wholly at farm work at the school.

In view of the foregoing and the fact that Malboeuf and his wife are half-breed immigrant Indians from the U.S.A., arriving in this country in 1897, I thought it advisable seeing that they are not treaty Indians, to report these circumstances before taking any action in the way of detaining and escorting of these children back to the school.

Malboeuf and his wife are very respectable people of their kind, and the children are being well taken care of in the meanwhile.

(Signed) Sergeant,
(T.W. Kempston.) Reg.No.3107.
I.C.Yorkton Detachment.

The Officer Commanding,
South. Sask. District,
R.C.M.Police,
Regina, Sask.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR CHRISTIANSON,
DATED MARCH 6th, 1925, ON THE TOUCHWOOD AGENCY.

MUSCOGEQUAN SCHOOL.

I noted a great change in this school since Father Poulet has taken charge there. He has done a lot of changing around in the building and everything now is in first-class order. There is also a great improvement in the appearance of the children. They are evidently well cared for, and are receiving a much better training than they were when I first visited this institution.
WE, the undersigned Indians belonging to the Poorman Band, plead for higher education for our children. We find that our school officers do not take our children on to the higher grades, but as soon as they are fit to go to a higher grade the child has to set out to work until of age to leave the school. We regret to find that the officials of the Indian Department do not allow an Indian child to have any more than a very poor education. We know that if an Indian child can be trained and given a good education there is no reason why he should not succeed in any profession or business. We would like to say with regard to a boarding school to which our children go that they do not get any education higher than grade 5, and some of them do not go higher than grade 3, and when they come out of school they know nothing to start to make a living with. We do not want our children to go to school to learn to work, but to get an education. We can teach them to work on the Reserve outside of school work, and we do not think our children get good teaching at the school, and we would like the Department to look into the matter.

I beg to submit the following report on
the schools of the Touchwood Agency, inspected during
my stay there between April 27th and May 15th, 1931.

MUSCOGEQUAN R.C., INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The new school is now being used, although
a quantity of furniture and fixtures have not yet
arrived.

The classroom work is carried on in the
senior room under the supervision of Sister Valade, and
the grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade |  |
|-------|---|
| 3     | 8 |
| 4     | 12|
| 5     | 16|
| 6     | 7 |
| 7     | 4 |

Total 47

The children speak out well, and appeared to be well
along in their grades. Their books are well kept, and
all work neatly set down.

The classroom was well aired and tidy.
The children were clean and all well
dressed. The girls were all dressed alike, and they
looked exceptionally well.

The junior room is in charge of Sister
