Sir:

On the 4th of November I wrote you with reference to the matter of supplying mattresses for the Indian Boarding School on the Muscowequan Reserve. I have your letter of the 11th ultimo 1925 acknowledging mine, and saying that after much thought the Department is giving a trial to mattress casings only, and that you regret you are unable to authorize the purchase of mattresses at the present time.

The contents of your letter were conveyed to the Rev. Principal and he now asks me to have mattresses made with the proper filling and asks that the Department make the deduction from the invoices of the cost of material used for the casings, and the school will pay for the filling.

My opinion is that the Department's attitude in regard to the matter of not supplying mattresses for these institutions is most impractical and unreasonable. I have a letter from Father Delmas of Duck Lake, asking if I could buy him some mattresses. This system may be the means of having the Principals buy their own mattresses, but as for economy and efficiency there is neither.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

G. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, December 16, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 312-11A of the 9th instant, with reference to the supplying of mattresses at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. The general question you raise is receiving consideration. I note that the Rev. Principal is desirous of securing mattresses, that he wishes the Department to pay for casings and he will meet the cost of the filling. I regret that the Department cannot give favourable consideration, as it is our practice to supply whatever mattresses, casings or bedding are to be allowed only when a school is securing initial equipment. All ordinary replacements should be met by the school management. I realize that the Department has lately given a few beds to this institution, but the school itself should supply whatever pillows, mattresses, etc., are needed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

With reference to the matter of supplying mattresses for the Muscowequan Residential School I do not understand your letter #121-5-5 of the 16th instant, in which you refer to the practice of the Department to supply mattresses etc., only when schools are securing initial equipment, in view of the Department's letter of the 9th October last requesting me to buy for this school twelve additional cots and mattress covers. In my letter of the 9th instant I merely asked if the Department would allow the mattresses to be purchased complete, on the understanding that the Principal of the school would pay the difference in cost between the complete mattresses and the mattress covers only.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 31, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 312-11A of the 26th instant, with reference to the supplying of mattresses for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. When I wrote on the 16th instant, I overlooked the fact that mattress casings had been authorized. You may purchase twelve institutional beds and mattresses for this school; but the management should pay the difference in cost between the complete mattresses and the mattress covers.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, #121-5-5, with reference to supplying mattresses to the Muscowequan Boarding School. In accordance with your instructions the cost of the filling and making of the mattresses will be paid by the Principal of the School and the cost of the covering by the Department. The whole matter in my opinion is trifling, unbusinesslike and unsatisfactory, and I quite agree with the Principal of the Duck Lake School when he was authorized to use casing not to use them but to undergo the expense of either buying mattresses himself or using the old ones.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School in the Touchwood Agency, in which he informs me that he has been advised that the Department do not propose going on with the work of adding an addition to his school during the coming year, and in view of this he makes a request that a building, now used as an employee's residence, be moved to a point close to the main school and be used as a hospital, which would relieve the situation somewhat. Last year I hoped to be able to do this from the funds that were allowed for painting, but the painting used up the full appropriation. The cost of doing this small amount of work would be about $150.00, and I think it would be well spent if the Department have the funds available. I would, therefore, recommend that $150.00 be authorized.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, February 2nd, 1926.

Sir:

I have your No. 312-11A of the 25th ultimo relative to the request of the Principal that a building now used as an employees' residence be moved to a point close to the main school to be used as a hospital.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of this arrangement being carried out, and will provide an expenditure not exceeding $150 towards the cost of this work.

You should forward vouchers in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred in the moving of the building which should not exceed the above authorized amount.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:

The Principal of the Muscowequan's Indian Residential School in the Touchwood Agency informs me that the galvanized water tanks providing storage supply for the school are leaking badly and might be cut off any moment on that account. He states he has had an expert in who reports that they are not even fit for repairing. Two new reinforced galvanized iron tanks of 500 gallons each are necessary. The estimated cost of these tanks would be approximately $100.00 for the two.

He also reports that the pig sty requires new flooring as it is sinking and breaking through every day. This floor should be replaced and the pig sty put in good shape before the winter sets in. The estimated cost for this expenditure would amount to about $125.00.

I would ask the Department if funds can be provided for this expenditure. It is evidently very urgent and should be dealt with at once.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Ontario.
Ottawa, October 2, 1926.

Sir:

I have your 312-11A of the 27th ultimo, with reference to improvements at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. In view of your explanation and recommendation, you are authorized to purchase two reinforced galvanized iron tanks, 500 gallons each, at an approximate cost of $100.00, as well as $125 worth of new flooring for the hogpen at the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, Canada, October 6, 1926

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

ATTENTION: MR. R.T. FERRIER

Dear Sir:

Reverend Father J. Poulet, O.M.I., Principal of Muscowequan Indian Residential School, has requested me to place before you a couple of items of great importance:

1 - The galvanized Water Tanks providing supply for the School are leaking badly and might be cut off any moment now on that account. An expert reports to me that they are not even fit for repairing. Two new tanks of 500 gals each are necessary.

This, I presume, is an emergency case and would ask you kindly to rush requisition. I have no idea of how two galvanized-reinforced tanks would cost.

2 - The pigstye needs new flooring altogether. It is sinking and breaking through every day. A prompt action should be taken before the winter in this connection. Provision must be made to take care of the stock on hand. The expenditure for same would amount to about $125.00 the total surface being 44 X 48.

Commissioner W. M. Graham has been advised of these requests by letter of September 22nd. I hope that he has taken up this question with the Department.

My only purpose in the present instance is to expose the pressing need of the above mentioned request in case Commissioner has not already written.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. Jos. Guy,
University of Ottawa,
OTTAWA.
Sir:

I beg to inform you that I received a long distance telephone call from the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Boarding School, informing me that the steam pipe on the return line of the heating boiler in the school had burst in several places and he could not get a plumber nearer than Saskatoon, and wanted immediate assistance as he had all the children in the institution and the weather is cold enough to necessitate the building being heated. I sent a plumber from Regina to fix the job up, and he has returned after fixing the pipe, but informs me that there is considerable more work than what he has done which should be undertaken at the school, and a low estimate for this would be $250.00. He points out that two of the closet bowls are broken and cannot be used; these must be attended to. He also adds that the two range basins are in a most unsanitary condition and unfit for further use. There are eight basins in the boys' dormitory and nine in the girls'. These basins have no taps and the connection from the basin to the waste pipe is made with a piece of rubber tubing, which of course is a very poor affair and allows the smell to ooze out and the dormitories are reeking with this odor. Why work of this kind was ever done the plumber cannot understand. He says that this work should be attended to without delay. I would, therefore, recommend that you advise me by wire if I may undertake the expenditure, as the weather has now moderated considerably and we might get the job finished, or at least well under way, before the winter sets in.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, November 9, 1926.

W. M. GRAHAM,
Indian Commissioner, Regina, Sask.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith Regina Voucher No. 4307 in favour of Messrs. Paulin & Swayze for $712.06, representing work and material in connection with the repairing of plumbing at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

Certain repairs to the plumbing were authorized by the Department, and I instructed Mr. Paulin, the nearest plumber I could get, to go and do the work and supply the material, after having sent a man who was at Touchwood at the time to make a survey as to what was absolutely necessary. While at the school the plumber found that there was a lot more work necessary, and the Rev. Principal took it upon himself to have it done. This is rather a heavy account, but there is no doubt that the plumbing was in very bad shape, and the work which was authorized by the Department was just something that had to be done at the time in order to enable the school to carry on.

I may say that when this building was taken over by the Government the plumbing was in bad shape. I suppose the Department will be prepared to pay this account.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
MUSCOGEEQUAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school was not inspected when I made my last inspection in December, as it was quarantined for Smallpox.

This school is old, and too small to accommodate all the children who wish to attend.

The children in both class rooms appeared well along in their grades, although only work up to grade V is carried on. The reading was quite loud and clear, and read as though understood. The spelling and arithmetic was also good. It would appear that more advanced work might reasonably
Muscowequan Indian Residential School (Cont'd)

might reasonably be expected on the part of some of the older boys and girls. The class rooms were both clean and well ventilated, although the junior room is very small and cramped. The children were exceptionally clean, and their clothing was good.

The work in the sewing room was well done, and everything kept neat and tidy. In fact, the work in all departments was good, and the order and discipline splendid.

The furnace will need a new set of grates before another winter as the ones installed last winter have already burned out.

The boys' playroom is very small, and if a new building is not provided, more playroom accommodation could be made by removing a partition and taking in the dining room now occupied by the Rev. Father. He would like very much to have this done if a new building is not provided before another winter. Several other repairs are needed in connection with floors, and yet if a new school is under consideration, it hardly seems worth while to make these repairs.

Both the dormitories were clean and the beds were nicely made. All the bedding appeared fresh and clean. Both dormitories are small, especially the boys', and the floors are badly sunk. Individual towels and tooth brushes are supplied to the children in each dormitory.

The outbuildings are in fairly good shape. However, the floors, both in the cow barn and horse barn, are badly worn and will need renewing. Cement would give far better results, being easier to keep clean and would last indefinitely.

The horses were in splendid condition and

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)
Muscoweguan Indian Residential School (Cont'd)

work on the land was well under way. About 70 head of cattle are kept at the school, 10 to 12 being milked for school purposes.

The Farming Instructor, Mr. Dahl, is an exceptionally good man. He understands farming, and apparently is able to get results from the boys. The work was well up to the mark, and the yards were neat and tidy.

The children appeared well fed and well clothed. They did not appear overworked, although the work in each department was kept up to the mark. There was no sickness and the children appeared quite happy.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the schools in the Touchwood agency, which were inspected by Mr Inspector Hamilton last week.

Muscowpetung School

I understand it is not the intention of the Department to proceed with the addition to this school at the present time.

I do not know that the Department should be called upon to supply new furnace grates. It seems to me that this should be a matter for the school to look after.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, May 28th, 1927.

Sir,-

The Department has received the enclosed account covering the cost of the inspection of the boiler and for cleaning chimneys, etc., at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. In this connection, I beg to say that the Department can only be responsible for payment for the actual cost of the boiler inspection and for the sixty joints of pipe supplied. The school authorities should be responsible for the payment for the cleaning of the chimneys. You should prepare and forward new vouchers, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the charge made for the inspection of the boiler and for the pipe.

I enclose a copy of a communication from the boiler inspector. You will note the recommendations made by him regarding the chimney from the ceiling of the boys' dormitory, the renewing of the grates in the furnace and lining for range in the kitchen. In connection with the Inspector's recommendations, I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having the work, as mentioned by him, carried out. When we have this information, consideration will be given to authorizing the work being performed. Your early attention to this matter will oblige.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S.S. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

The rebuilding of the chimney would cost $25.00.

Ottawa, July 6th, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of rebuilding the chimney at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that you may have this work carried out and the cost should not exceed your estimate of approximately $25.

When you obtain a price for the supplying of the grates and fire box required, you should furnish this information for the consideration of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. S. Moore, Esq.,

Punnichy, Sask.
Sir:-

Further to my letter of the 27th ultimo I beg to report that I have now received a quotation of $11.39 for firebox linings for the range at the Muscowequan Boarding School. The Western Foundry Co., of Wingham, Ontario, are the manufacturers of this range and it was from them that I received this figure. As regards the new grates for the furnace I have not been able to locate the makers, but I am advised by the Ashdown Company of Winnipeg that it would be just as satisfactory if $\frac{1}{4}$ inch boiler plate were placed on top of the old grates, that is two plates set $\frac{1}{2}$ inch apart so as to allow for draught. The cost would be approximately $12.00.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 13th, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, relative to the fire box lining required for the range at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. You may arrange for the supplying of the lining required. It is noted that the estimate received by you for supplying same is $11.39.

If you consider it would be satisfactory, you may arrange to have 1/4" boiler plate supplied and placed on top of the old grates in the furnace. We note that the cost will be approximately $12.

Please arrange for the supplying of the above equipment at an early date, and forward certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report that, yesterday, whilst at the Muscowequan Residential School my attention was drawn to the condition of the beds used by the pupils. There are a number of them which are quite used up and are really unfit for the children to sleep on, both the mattresses and cots being worn out or broken. I would recommend that 12 new institutional beds with mattresses be supplied this school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 19, 1927.

Sir:

I have your lla of the 12th instant, with reference to beds and mattresses required at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. The Department will grant the 12 beds necessary; but I have to ask you to inform the Rev. Principal that he should be responsible for the mattresses.

You may place the order for 12 No. 4000 W. E. Beds, 2'6" x 5'6" with Simmons Limited, of Regina. Please give them shipping directions and ask for their best price to a government department. If the Rev. Principal wants 6 ft. beds or 5 ft. beds, you should change the specifications accordingly. When the beds have arrived, you should certify to the account, in duplicate, and forward it direct to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to report that the electric lighting plant at the Muscowequan Residential School is in immediate need of either repair or replacement with new storage cells. I have already had an expert at the school to look the plant over, and his firm, Messrs. Motherwell & Swan quote the following prices on two different new sets and also a price on a re-building job:

1 Complete set 16 cell 12 plate 300 amp.hour battery installed for $325.55
1 Complete set, as above 240 Amp.hour battery installed for $277.50

To repair the set now in use and replace all Positive plates, wood separators and acid, making a complete job for $151.00.

Of the three I would recommend the last, as the negative plates and jars of the old battery are in very good shape and with new positive plates, separators and acid, the plant should be as good as new.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa.

Sir:

In connection with the attached voucher for $156.00 for repairs to the lighting plant at the Muscowequan School, I beg to explain that your authority called for only an expenditure of $151.00, but it was found when the repair work started that five of the glass jars were broken and had to be replaced, and the expert who was doing the work advised moving the switchboard further away from the storage batteries as in his opinion there was too much danger where it was.

In view of this I took the liberty of authorising the extra work, and trust that my action will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Sir:-

I would like to bring to your attention the advisability of providing punch clocks in our Residential Schools, in order that the night watchmen may be checked up closely and that we may be assured that they are performing their duties carefully. We have such a system at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, and I would recommend that punch clocks be purchased for the Muscowequan Boarding School at once. The Principal of the latter school was in to see me today, and informs me that he has a night watchman, but has no means of checking him up, although he has no reason to believe that he is not doing his duty.

The question of having night watchmen at all our schools is, to my mind, a very important one, and I would urge the Department to give consideration to the matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 18, 1927.

Sir:

I have your 100-11A of the 12th instant, with reference to punch clocks for a check on night watchmen at Indian residential schools. If this special equipment is required at the Muscowequan School, I believe the management should be responsible for the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

**PUBLIC ARCHIVES**

**ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES**

**CANADA**
Sir:

I enclose a voucher in favour of the Magneto Service Station Ltd., Regina, amounting to $17.35, representing repairs to the generator in use at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School in the Touchwood Agency. The Reverend Principal called at my office on or about the 12th of October and advised me that it was out of order and needed repairing and I authorized this expenditure.

After the generator had been returned to the school and put into use again, it was found that it was not giving satisfactory service and did not properly charge the batteries. I yesterday received a telephone call from the Principal explaining the situation and advising me that an expert, who had visited the school, recommends that a new one be purchased and installed. The present one is of 900 watt capacity. The one recommended to replace it will be of 1½ K.W. capacity, and I have ascertained will cost approximately $160.00. I have not yet been able to ascertain whether the old generator will be taken over in part payment, but whatever arrangements can be made along these lines will be made. The lighting service now at the school is very unsatisfactory, and the Principal has asked that authority may be given by telegram to purchase the larger unit.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
OTTAWA - December 5, 1927.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

May arrange purchase and installation new generator Muscowequan School.

J.D. McLean,

CHG. DEPT. I.A.
Ottawa, December 5, 1927.

Sir:

I have your No. 312-11A R.C. of the 29th ultimo, enclosing an account covering the cost of repairs to the generator in use at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. This account will be paid in due course.

It is noted that after the repairs were made and the generator returned it did not give satisfactory service and that an expert who visited the school recommends that a new one be purchased and installed. In this connection I have to confirm our night lettergram to you of today's date:

"May arrange purchase and installation new generator Muscowequan School."

It is noted that the one required will be of 1½ K.W. capacity, and will cost $160. If you can arrange to have the old generator taken in part payment, a credit should be allowed for same on the cost of the new generator.

After the new generator has been installed, please forward an account, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:

In his recent report on the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Inspector Hamilton suggests that the laundry floor should be re-cemented; that the floors and plaster are in need of repair, at a cost of about $50.00, and that the horse barn needs re-flooring, at a cost of about $150.00 for material. The Reverend Principal is prepared to furnish the labour, and I shall be glad if the Department will authorize the necessary expenditure for the purchase of cement, etc.

Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
MUSCOGEQUAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on March 12th, and found everything in its usual good condition. The school throughout was spotless, and the work in all departments good.

The classroom work is carried on in the junior room by Sister Valade, and in the senior room by Sister Mary of the Cross. The children appeared well up in their grades, and the discipline was excellent.

I found the fire escapes in good condition. The fire extinguishers had been re-filled and were in prominent places. The fire hose are in poor condition, and I found one bracket in the main hall without any. This one should be replaced and, in addition, two others, all to be 50 ft. in length.

Some of the floors are badly in need of repair as they are worn through in places. These should be repaired, as well as some patch work on the plaster. No money was estimated for this school as the Rev. Principal expected a new wing to be built this year as well as the old one remodeled.

I found
I found the laundry one of the poorest, and with the least equipment of any school I have inspected. The floor is cement, which is badly broken and rough. The water is heated in "feed cookers" and no power machinery is used.

The outbuildings are in fair repair, with the exception of the horse barn, which needs re-flooring. The old floor is of plank and is worn through in places. This is dangerous for the horses as the floor is off the ground nearly a foot. This place should be filled with gravel and a cement floor put in, which would make a permanent fixture.

Some very fine horses are kept at this school, as well as a large number of cattle. At present they are milking 10 head, all of which freshened within the last six weeks. I believe there is never any shortage of milk.

A large flock of hens is also kept, and at the time of my inspection they were receiving 80 to 90 eggs a day. Father Poulet informed me the children were given eggs two to three times a week.

There appeared a shortage of large girls at this school and the Rev. Father Poulet considered that washing by hand and the mixing of all bread, along with the other work required, made too much for the girls, and asked that he be provided with a bread mixer. This, of course, could be moved if at any time a new wing was built.

In this
MUSCOGEEQUAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

In this school there is an excellent staff and I believe the boys are receiving the best of instruction with regards to farming.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Regina, Sask., March 30th, 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report of an inspection of the various schools in the Touchwood Agency which was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton.

You will notice that the laundry at the Muscowequan School is in very poor shape. This school is, I understand, one that the Church expects the Department to make an addition to. In that case the question of the laundry and other repairs could be gone into.

W. M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, April 10, 1928.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 312-11 of the 30th ultimo, enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Hamilton on his inspection of the various schools in the Touchwood Agency.

Relative to the Muscowequan School, it is noted from the Inspector's report that the fire hose are in poor condition. You may arrange for the purchase and replacement of the quantity of fire hose which you consider necessary for the use of this school. The cost for the purpose should be kept as low as possible.

The Department is arranging for the supplying of a dough mixer.

Relative to the resementing of the laundry floor and the reflooring of the horse barn, I beg to refer you to your letter of the 28th ultimo and the Department's reply thereto of the 2nd instant, authorizing you to incur an expenditure not exceeding approximately $200 in the purchase of the cement, etc., the labour to be provided by the school staff.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir:

Replying to your May 1st favor would say we regret we overlooked giving you the information requested in your previous letter.

We would recommend a 3 h.p. gasoline engine for the purpose of driving a one barrel type "M" Mixer. While a 2 h.p. electric motor is ample for this work, we have found on several occasions that a 2 h.p. gasoline engine is hardly strong enough and in order to secure 100% efficiency from this machine we believe it would be necessary to use a 3 h.p. gasoline engine.

We are sending under separate cover a copy of our bakers machinery catalogue which gives details of our bake-shop equipment and assure you it will be a pleasure to give you further details at any time.

Rev. Sir:

Referring to previous correspondence regarding your application to be supplied with a dough mixer for the use of the Muscovequan Indian Residential School, I have to inform you that the Pendrith Machinery Co. Ltd., Toronto, state that they can supply a 1 bbl. type "M" belt drive dough mixer, F.O.B. Lestock, Sask., for the sum of $315.00. Canopy top for this machine would be $25.00 additional. Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 10th ultimo No. 121-5-5, in which you authorized an expenditure of $200.00 to purchase material for repairs to the stable and laundry at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I am informed that $200.00 will not begin to purchase the necessary material, as it has been found since the old floor in the stable has been taken up that the beams & the stalls have all rotted away and will have to be renewed, and that the pillars holding the loft floor have also rotted and must be renewed, and while the Principal has given the time of two of his men, it is impossible for him to do all the work, especially the laying of the cement and the carpentry work, which require an expert. There is about 500 feet of flooring to be repaired, in addition to some plastering, and it will take at least $450.00 to complete the work. I should be glad to see this amount authorized, as I feel sure the Principal is doing all he possibly can in the way of furnishing labour, and it would be hardly fair to expect to encroach on the time of men who are working in the fields. There will be no slack time from now on for the men who are working on the land. When seeding is completed they will have summerfallowing to do and after that comes haying. This school is doing good work and I should like to see it encouraged.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Mr. Scott:

I have had a visit from Father Poulet, Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, who made a special trip in to see me regarding his lighting plant, which is out of order. The school is practically without light at the present time, and this, of course, must be remedied without delay.

It appears that Mr. Moore, our Agent at Punnichy, made a report to the Department, recommending that the work of repairing the batteries be placed in the hands of Messrs. Motherwell & Swan, of Punnichy. These people undertook to do the work, but from the information I gather from Inspector Hamilton and the Principal, instead of improving the condition of the plant they have made it worse. When Mr. Hamilton paid a recent visit to this school, the Principal brought the matter to his attention, and he called upon Messrs. Motherwell & Swan to again overhaul the batteries and put them in proper working condition. This they attempted to do, but Father Poulet tells me today that the batteries are absolutely useless, and asks that immediate action be taken.

I think perhaps it would be advisable when matters of this kind come up, to advise this office. I would never have agreed to have local men fix these batteries, as it takes real experts to put batteries in repair in most cases, especially when they have been in a run-down condition, as these were. We have had a lot of experience with run-down and worn-out batteries, and nine times out of ten we find that

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
it is not advisable to spend money on them in the way of repairing, but that the better plan is to renew them entirely. I do not know the exact amount of money that was given to Messrs. Motherwell & Swan, but whatever amount it was I consider that it is just money lost, and in future I should be glad if in the matter of repairs to lighting plants you would see that the instructions come to me. I would be able then to deal with the firms in the City who are in that business. In the meantime I would ask that I be granted authority to purchase a complete set of new batteries for the Muscowequan School, at a cost of about $420.00. This is the price quoted for the best batteries; we can buy cheaper ones, but this would not be economy. I may point out that when I made enquiries regarding the batteries I was told by experts here that unless they are placed in the hands of men who thoroughly understand the business and who have proper instruments they are more often destroyed than repaired.

I should be glad to have a wire from you authorizing this purchase, as you will understand that the situation is critical.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Send the following message, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to

June 25, 1926.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Approve purchase new batteries
Muscowequan School.

Duncan C. Scott.

November 30, 1928.

My dear Father Guy:

As I have for the last week or two been giving serious consideration to the estimates for the approaching fiscal year, 1929-30, I thought I should write you in connection with two items which you very strongly urged upon my attention; namely, an appropriation for a new school building at Restock (Muscowequan) and for an addition to the Malteek Residential School.

From your long association with this phase of our work, you will understand that I have to give attention to claims of this nature from all parts of the country, and it has been the policy to endeavour to so apportion the grants to be allowed by Parliament, that the most deserving cases should be dealt with first. I find that my difficulty in dealing immediately and favourably with the above demands is that necessities of the work conducted by your Church in other parts of the country are more pressing and must be given the earliest attention.

It would not be proper for me to make any definite promises on behalf of the Honourable the Superintendent General or to forecast what Parliament may appropriate in future; but, so far as I am concerned, I am hopeful of being able to give more favourable consideration to these representations a year from now.

With kindest regards,

I am,
Yours faithfully,

Duncan C. Scott

Rev. Jos. Guy, O. M. I.,
Ottawa University,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Would you be so kind as to send a special requisition to the Department for a new Bakery oven - ours being far too small to meet the present requirements. With the Dow mixer on hand we bake two sacks of flour at one time - and our oven is only a family style one - with a capacity of ½ sack - Thereby, the bread is spoiled through the long waiting in the pans - We have tried different ways to make it work - but so far we could not succeed.

I am hopeful that the Department will understand the existing conditions and approve my requisition for a much larger size oven.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) J. Poulet,
Principal.

N.B. One oven was bought from J. J. Daoust Ltd. about 12 years ago.
Sir:-

I enclose copy of a letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School in the Touchwood Agency. You will note that he is asking the Department to supply them with a two-sack bake oven. Two of a similar capacity were purchased last summer for the Lebret school at a cost of $400.00 each, and I shall be glad to know if the Department will authorize this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I have your 312-11A R.C. of the 23rd instant, and in reply have to inform you that there is an item provided in our Estimates of $600 for the purpose of carrying out the repairs, viz., renewing some of the floors and stairways in the school building and putting in a cement floor in the cow barn, at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

You may arrange to have the repairs in the school building carried out and the floor in the cow barn installed. In carrying out this work, the Department will be pleased if you can effect a saving in the amount provided. I found some of the floors and stairways in the old building badly worn and if the building is to continue being used, these floors and stairways should be replaced.

xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

The outbuildings were in good repair with the exception of the floor in the cattle barn. This floor should be replaced before winter as it is constantly breaking through and giving trouble. Last year the Department floored the horse barn with cement, which has given splendid satisfaction, and if it were possible, I would like to have a cement floor put down in the cow barn which would then put this building in first class condition.

Sir:-

I beg to advise you that Father Poulet called at my office today to inform me that the gasoline engine which he uses to supply power to drive the dough mixer, and other things at the school exploded last night, and is a complete wreck. They are badly in need of an engine. I called up the Fairbanks-Morse Company and they tell me they can supply a 3 h.p. engine for $155.00, less 20%, which would be a net cost of about $124.00. I should be glad to have your authority to make this purchase without delay. In the meantime they will have to get along the best they can until this authority is received.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

M. Graham,
Canadian Commissioner.

Sir,

I recently visited the Indian Boarding School on the Muscowequan Reserve and found the toilets on both the boys and girls sides of the building in a deplorable condition. The fixtures are broken down and the woodwork rotted beyond repair. I believe that complete new sets for both sides of the building could be installed for about $300.00 and I shall be glad to receive authority to proceed with this most necessary work.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

Sir:

I have your 312-11A R.C. of the 14th instant, with reference to improvements at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. If funds are provided by Parliament at the coming session, the Department hopes to make some major improvements at this institution, and I hesitate to authorize an expenditure of $300 for repairs at the present time. Perhaps, with a much smaller outlay, some temporary improvements can be made. You are authorized to do whatever is really necessary for the next year or two.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Dear Mr. Swan,

You will remember when we were at the Muskowekwan School I promised the Rev. Principal that I would prepare a rough sketch of a layout for a new School. I am sending you today, under separate cover, two blue print copies of a rough sketch plan, and I would ask you to please show this to the Principal and return one copy to me on which you might indicate any changes that the Principal desires in the layout. The building is planned to accommodate 100 pupils. You will note that I have carried out his suggestion in placing the baths on the floors adjacent to the dormitories. When the building is erected it is the intention to demolish all of the old building with the exception of the frame building, which I have shown connected to the new building by a passage. It will be my intention to locate the laundry in the basement of the existing frame building, also the electric lighting plant. I would be glad to have these plans back as soon as possible.

I would like to express my sincere thanks to you for your kindness to me while at Punnichy, and I hope to be able to visit Punnichy when the Gordon's School is completed.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Re: Muskowequan Indian School.

Your letter of the 22nd. to hand yesterday and the blueprints today. I have just returned from a visit to the Rev. Father Paulett who went over the sketches with me and was much pleased with them. There are one or two minor changes such as sizes of some of the staff rooms, that he suggests, but he wishes to take the blueprints into Winnipeg tomorrow, to show his church authorities, so I am delaying the return of a copy for a few days until I hear finally from him.

I understand from the Rev. Principal that he had a letter from Ottawa a short time ago which assured him that his school would be going ahead next year.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Muscoweyan Indian Residential School
Lestock Sask., Dec. 2, 1929

Dear Sir,

Mr. Swan of Punnichy has handed over to me your rough sketch of the layout of our new school. May I be permitted, first of all, to express you my deep gratitude for your earnest cooperation and kind support in this connection. I personally feel that your ambition is to make the schools of our Indian schools, and accordingly, to prepare such plans as may meet with the approval of all parties concerned. In this instance your sketch will certainly please and bring about this consoling result.

Now, with your kind permission, I beg to submit a few suggestions of minor importance which may help you in the final drawing of the plans.

1st Location of the New School - so as to protect operation of school activities during the time of the construction:

I beg to inclose two blue prints which I prepared for your consideration in this connection. The first map will show you the exact location of each building on the school grounds - as also that of the well, the preservation of which is of vital importance to this institution. We have dug nine different wells around here at great cost - and all but that one has proven any good. It is all cemented from top to bottom and may provide easily from 5 to 6 thousand gallons of water a day.

Then, the second map is a tentative proposition for the location of the New School - so as to preserve both, a) the operation of the school activities during the time of the construction, b) Preservation of the Well.

N.B. The dotted part is the existing Church and could be demolished at the earliest convenience.

2nd Re-minor alterations for Basement Plan:

Adjoining both recreation halls there is one room for coats. To help discipline I would suggest that these rooms opened directly on the recreation halls, thus avoiding access and crowding in the corridors.

b) In your sketch there is no Bakery Room in close connection with the Kitchen. Would it be possible to make allowance for that? The Bakery is operated and supervised by the head cook.

c) The Father's dining room could be made three feet longer and the store room adjoining smaller accordingly, with the door on same opening on the Father's dining room rather than on the corridor.

N.B. This dining room is also the Visitor's dining room and consequently, I presume, that a larger space should be allowed.

3rd Re-minor alterations on the Ground Floor Plan:

a) I would suggest that no door should connect the Senior Boys Study with the Male Staff sitting room. This door could be placed to greater advantage as a second entrance to the Senior Boys Study.

b) In connection with the Chapel gallery layout may I be permitted to ask for an outside entrance at the rear, same to serve as a special entrance to outside Indians wishing to attend the services of the Church, thus avoiding the free access and crowding of the corridor leading thereto.

c) May we also hope for the erection or a gallery in the chapel which would prove a great convenience indeed for the singing choir.

4th Re-minor alterations for first floor Plan:

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
4th. Re-minor alterations for First Floor Plan:

a) It is most important that a glaze wall be erected at each end of the corridor to isolate the Sister's Department.

b) Would it be possible to have the Bath Rooms adjoining each of the four dormitories connected directly with same, thus avoiding the passing of bathers in the corridor?

c) Would it be possible also to add one more toilet in each of the four dormitories, same to serve as a private convenience for the guardians? These extra toilets could open on the guardians' rooms.

In conclusion, may I ask you, as a special favour, that all doors leading on the corridors of the school be supplied with a Transom? to provide better light for same? The remark has been passed to me that the corridors in existing schools of this type were rather dark.

Dear Sir, I now leave it to you to decide in all matters concerning the above suggestions. I really feel that our cause is in good hands and will be generously protected.

Yours very sincerely,

Joseph Butler
Principal.

(2) Where there are special circumstances which in the judgment of the Minister of Labour make it expedient that he should do so, he may decide what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages for overtime, and what is the proper classification of any work for the purposes of wages and hours. Immediately upon receipt of notice of any decision of the Minister of Labour hereunder, the contractor shall adjust the wages and hours and classification thereof so as to give effect to such decision. In case the contractor shall fail so to do, or fail at any time to pay to any employee or employees for any services performed or for any hours of labour wages according to the rates set forth in the schedule or fixed thereafter by the Minister of Labour hereunder regarding overtime and classification, the Minister of Labour may authorize and direct the Minister to pay such wages or the rates so fixed and to deduct the amount thereof from any moneys owing by the Government to the contractor and any such payment shall for all purposes as between the contractor and the Government be deemed and taken to be payment to the contractor, and the contractor shall be bound in every particular by any such authority, direction and order so directed. The provisions of this subsection shall not be exercised as to any employee or employees where it is established to his satisfaction that an agreement in writing exists and is in effect between the Contractor and the class of employees to which such employee or employees belong or the authorized representatives of such class of employees fixing rates of wages, overtime conditions and hours of labour.

A1
(3) The Contractor shall post and keep posted in a conspicuous place on the premises where the contract is being executed, occupied or frequented by the workmen, the Fair Wages Clause or Schedule inserted in his contract for the protection of the workmen employed, also any decision of the Minister of Labour under the preceding paragraph.

(4) The Contractor shall keep proper books and records showing the names, trades, and addresses of all workmen in his employ and the wages paid to and time worked by such workmen, and the books or documents containing such record shall be open for inspection by the Fair Wage Officers of the Government at any time it may be expedient to the Minister of Labour to have the same inspected.

(5) The Contractor shall not be entitled to payment of any money which would otherwise be payable under the terms of the contract in respect of work and labour performed in the execution of the contract unless and until he shall have filed with the Minister in support of his claim for payment a statement attested by statutory declaration showing (1) the rates of wages and hours of labour of the various classes of workmen employed and the extent of the contract; (2) whether any wages in respect of the said work and labour remain in arrears; (3) that all the labour conditions of the contract have been duly complied with; nor, in the event of notice from the Minister of Labour of claims for wages, until the same are adjusted. The Contractor shall also from time to time furnish the Minister such further detailed information and evidence as the Minister may deem necessary in order to satisfy him that the conditions herein contained to secure the payment of fair wages have been complied with, and that the workmen so employed as aforesaid upon the portion of the work in respect of which payment is demanded have been paid in full.

(6) In the event of defaults being made in payment of any money owing in respect of wages of any workmen employed on the said work and if a claim in default of the said wages is made to the Minister and proof thereof satisfactory to the Minister is furnished, the said Minister may pay such claim out of the moneys at any time payable by His Majesty under said contract and the amounts so paid shall be deemed payments to the Contractor.

(7) These conditions shall extend and apply to moneys payable for the use or hire of horses or teams, and the persons entitled to payments for the use or hire of horses or teams shall have the like rights in respect of moneys so owing them as if such moneys were payable to them in respect of wages.

(8) With a view to the avoidance of any abuses which might arise from the sub-letting of contracts it shall be understood that sub-letting, other than such as may be necessary for the true completion, is prohibited except the approval of the Minister is obtained; sub-contractors shall be bound in all cases to conform to the conditions of the main contract, and the main contractor shall be held responsible for strict adherence to all contract conditions on the part of sub-contractor; the contract shall not, nor shall any portion thereof be transferred without the written permission of the Minister; no portion of the work to be performed shall be done at the homes of the workmen.

(9) All workmen employed upon the work comprised in and to be executed under the said contract shall be residents of Canada, unless the Minister is of opinion that Canadian labour is not available or that other special circumstances exist which render it contrary to the public interest to enforce this provision.

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. Inspector Hamilton on his inspection of the MUSCOGEEQUAN Indian Residential School.

Original on File 121-5-6.

The barn is greatly improved by the work carried out last summer in cementing the floors and re-arranging the interior. The root cellar has caved in. This cellar is under the barn floor and is unsatisfactory. As a large garden is always grown, a new cellar should be provided.

The present hen house is high and unsuitable for the purpose. The Rev. Principal makes a special effort along this line and would appreciate a good log chicken house. The present building is more like a dwelling and he would like to have it moved and used to accommodate Indian parents who come from a distance to visit their children.

The present granary is very old and the floors are in poor condition, allowing the rats and mice to get in and destroy quantities of feed and seed. The building is not on a proper foundation and the sills have rotted in several places. Before repairing this building, it might be well to move it further away from the school or, at least, in line with the barn buildings.

The old school residence is in need of some repair, but as the Rev. Father Poulet expects a new school this year, it would be useless to incur any further expense.

EXTRACT from Letter of Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham, forwarding Mr. Inspector Hamilton's Report on his inspection of the MUSCOGEEQUAN Indian Residential School.

Original on File 121-5-6.

I cannot see why the Principal, with the assistance of members of his staff and the bigger boys, could not fix up the root cellar. I do not think the Department should be called upon to do this, nor should we be called upon to do anything about the henhouse. Of course, if we are expected to do everything it is a different matter, but my understanding is that we are not. The same remarks will apply to the granary.
Ottawa, May 16, 1930.

Sir:

Referring to Mr. Inspector Hamilton's report on the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, forwarded under cover of your No. 312-11 of the 8th instant, in which he draws attention to the condition of the root cellar, hen house and granary, I have to say that the department has no funds available to carry out the suggestions of the Principal regarding the roofing of the present hen house and fitting it up to accommodate Indian parents, or in making repairs to the granary and root cellar. I would suggest that the school authorities carry out these alterations and repairs themselves; the staff and older boys performing the labour required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

R.

H. Guernsey Orr, Esq., R.A.I.O.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

re: Muscowequan Indian School.

On checking over the plans and specifications for the above school we find that certain discrepancies exist upon which we desire your ruling.

For instance, on page 80 of the Specifications, in the paragraph headed Hot Water Storage Heater, a Type K, Whitlock Darling hot water storage heater is asked for, same to be equipped with a steam coil and connected to steam header on boiler, but on page 87, in the paragraph headed Domestic hot water heater, a plain storage tank is asked for, together with a #9, Type R Whitlock Darling submerged hot water heater which is to be connected to the boilers below the water line. Please advise which of these paragraphs will apply to the work in question.

Also on page 87, under the heading Laundry Boiler a 10 H.P. vertical steam boiler is asked for, and the heating contractor is instructed to install this, and also to connect up Laundry Machinery, which it is stated, is specified under another heading. We can find no mention at all in either the plans or the specifications of a laundry building or machinery, and we would ask that you advise us if this equipment is to be installed and if so, where?

Your early reply will be greatly appreciated.

Very truly yours,

VAGG, WILSON & CO.,

Per [Signature]

A. B. Imbrie

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)
June 5, 1930.

Vagg Wilson & Co.,
Regina, Sask.

Reference your letter second instant one tank only to be installed as specified on page eighty-seven. Laundry machinery will be installed in basement of existing school building.

Chg. Dia.

R. Gurney Orr.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., June 5th, 1930

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have a copy of the plans for the new Muscowequan Indian Residential School, in the Touchwood Agency.

Might I suggest that the door leading from the balcony on the second floor be made wide enough so that a cot or bed can be passed out through it to the sun parlour. The door that is shown on the plan is too narrow for this purpose. I found this feature also at the new Brandon School.

I would also suggest that the walls of the playrooms be wainscoted with v-joint. I note that the plaster comes right down to the base-board, which means that it will be broken off within a year. Wainscoting should be put on at the Brandon school as well.

It is noticed that the two bedrooms at the Brandon School leading off the main hallways, have cement floors. I think this was meant to be terazzo, because the two storerooms upstairs have terazzo flooring. The contractor should have called the Principal's attention to this before proceeding with the work, as I am sure it was never the intention to put terazzo floors in the storerooms and cement in the bedrooms. This change should also be made on the Muscowequan School plans.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan J. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, June 12, 1930.

Saskatoon, Sask.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott.

Plans and specifications have been prepared and tenders invited for the proposed new Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Lestock, Sask., and the following have been received.

Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd., Regina, Sask. $130,853.00
Poole Construction Co. Ltd., Regina, " $139,285.00
P. W. Graham & Sons Ltd., Moosejaw, " $139,950.00
Claydon Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. $141,635.00
Wilson & Wilson Ltd., Regina, Sask. $141,750.00
Shannon Bros., Saskatoon, Sask. $143,500.00
Bird, Woodall & Simpson Ltd., Moosejaw, $145,413.00
J. H. Simmons, Winnipeg, Man. $146,942.00
Carter-Halls-Aldinger Co. Ltd., Winnipeg. $147,729.00
A. W. Cassidy & Co. Ltd., Saskatoon, Sask. $149,800.00

As the tender of Smith Bros. and Wilson is the lowest and a fair and reasonable price for the work, I beg to recommend that it be accepted.

ARCHITECT.
Ottawa, June 16th. 1930.

P. W. Graham & Sons, Ltd.,
Moose Jaw, Sask.

AT YOUR REQUEST INFORM YOU YOUR TENDER NOT SUCCESSFUL

Charge I. A. Duncan C. Scott
Ottawa, June 17, 1930.

121-5-18

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that the same being necessary, tenders were called for the construction of the proposed new Muscowequan Indian Residential School, near Lestock, in the province of Saskatchewan; and that the following tenders were received:

Smith Bros. and Wilson Ltd., Regina...........$138,653.00
Foote Construction Co., Ltd., Regina..........$139,285.00
P.J. Graham and Sons, Ltd., Moose Jaw........$139,950.00
Clydon Co., Ltd., Winnipeg.....................$141,500.00
Wilson and Wilson Ltd., Regina...............$142,750.00
Shonk Bros., Saskatoon.........................$143,500.00
Bird, Woodall and Simpson, Ltd., Moose Jaw..$145,413.00
J.H. Simmons, Winnipeg.........................$146,942.00
Carter-Haftz-Aldinger Co., Ltd., Winnipeg....$147,729.00
A.W. Cassidy and Co., Ltd., Saskatoon........$149,800.00

The Architect of the Department reports that the lowest of these tenders, namely that of Smith Bros. and Wilson Ltd., is fair and reasonable; and the undersigned has the honour to recommend that it be accepted pursuant to the requirements of Sub-section 2 of Section 36 of the Public Works Act. Funds are provided in the Vote for Indian Education.

Acting Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

Dear Mr.Orr;

Re.Muskowequan School.

When the above job is let do you think the Department will require my services as supervisor? You of course know the distance from Punnichy; about eleven miles, twenty minutes by car on the highway.

I could do a daily trip there as I am doing at Gordons and give the same services. Gordons will be substantially through before any concrete is poured on this.

I have seen the plans and must say that Father Paulet is very much tickled over the fact that you gave him clear space in the classrooms and recreation rooms.

Yours sincerely,

TENDER FORM

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
OTTAWA, CANADA

Building: Muscowequan Indian Residential School
Location: Near Lestock, Saskatchewan.

I, (we) J. L. Guay Construction Co., Ltd., hereby offer to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, to furnish all the necessary tools, implements, materials and labour, and to execute and complete in a satisfactory and workmanlike manner, all the works required in completing the aforesaid building, according to drawings, specifications and form of contract exhibited to me, us, and prepared under instructions of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, for the sum named as under.

Tender for the whole of the work as shown on drawings and described on the specifications (Amount of tender to be written): One Hundred and Thirty Nine Thousand, Four Hundred and Ninety Five Dollars.

($39,495.00)

I, (we) herewith agree to complete the work within a period of six months from the date of notification of acceptance of tender, and hold myself (ourselves) ready to enter into a contract for the due execution of the work.

(a) I, (we) herewith enclose an accepted cheque for $14,000.00 on a chartered bank, payable to the order of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, equal to ten (10) per cent of the amount of the tender, as per terms of the advertisement and specifications for this work.

(b) Attached hereto is a letter from the Manager of the Bank of certifying that War Bonds of the Dominion of Canada or bonds of the Canadian National Railway Company to the value of have been deposited in the Bank of subject to the order of the Deputy Superintendent General, Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, Ont.

War Loan Bonds of the Dominion or bonds of the Canadian National Railway Company will be accepted as security, or Bonds and cheque, if required to make up an odd amount.

Envelopes containing this tender are to be endorsed "TENDER FOR Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Near Lestock, Saskatchewan" and addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, Ont.

"Tenders must be in the hands of Deputy Superintendent General by 12 O'CLOCK NOON of date fixed for their reception. Care should therefore be taken to mail same in proper time."

The signatures of persons tendering must be in their respective handwritings.

In the case of firms, the signature, post office address and occupation of each member of the firm must be given.

SIGNATURES, OCCUPATIONS AND POST OFFICE ADDRESSES OF PERSONS TENDERING:

J. L. Guay Construction Co., Ltd.

Date: Winnipeg, Man., this Fourteenth day of June, 1932.

NOTE.—This security cheque or Bonds will be forfeited if the person or persons tendering refuse to enter into a contract when called upon to do so, or fail to complete the work contracted for. The Department does not bind itself to accept the lowest or any tender. No conditional tender which is not in accordance with the above will be considered.

NOTE.—Amount of deposit security should be indicated in space provided above.

June 23, 1930.

Sir,

As advised by telegram of the 21st your tender of $138,653.00 is accepted for the new Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Lestock, Sask., and I am enclosing herewith contract forms in duplicate which I would ask you to please sign and return to the Department, and when executed by the Deputy Superintendent General a copy will be sent you.

I am today requesting that plans and specifications from the following offices be sent you:

Post Master, Saskatoon - 2 copies,
John R. Dunn, Winnipeg - 2 copies,
W. M. Graham, Regina - 2 copies.

Kindly advise me if you have received these plans. If more are required they will be sent to you. Mr. William Swan of Punnichy, will act as Inspector of Construction, and you should get into communication with him before starting the work. All correspondence relating to this contract should be forwarded to the Department through Mr. Swan and he will also issue the necessary progress certificates for payment on the contract.

Your obedient servant,

Smith Bros. & Wilson,
CONTRACTORS,
REGINA, Sask.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting, Aest. Deputy & Secretary.
June 23, 1930.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that you have been appointed Inspector of Construction for the new Muscowequan Indian Residential School, near Lestock, Sask., and you will be paid for your services at the same rate as at the Gordon's School.

The contract for the building has been awarded to Smith Bros. and Wilson of Regina at their tendered price of $138,653.00 and they have been instructed to get into communication with you before commencing work.

A copy of the plans and specifications are being sent you today, under separate cover. If you require further certificate forms please advise and they will be forwarded to you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir:

The specifications for the above building call for a smooth buff brick for the stair walls. We understand that some difficulty may be encountered in securing such a brick in western Canada, and we have had enquiries for quotations on our grey face brick as a possible substitute for the buff brick. Should representations be made to you asking that our grey brick be allowed as a substitute for the buff brick, we would appreciate it very much if you would give it your favorable consideration.

Thanking you, we are,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I understand that your department is building a school at Lestock, Sask., and I would therefore like to know if you have appointed a Clerk of Works for that job. I am at present employed as Clerk of Works for the Post Office Building at Melville, but will be finished about the 15th of July and I am only about 60 miles away and as I am only on temporary with the Civil Service and I also understand that it will only be a temporary job, I am an Architect and a returned man and well able to work at the same.

Hope to hear soon if I will have to make a new application with the Civil Service.

Yours Truly,

The Gordon's School is nearly completed.

Dear Sir,

The Plans & Specifications for our new school have arrived in the latter part of May, and after a careful study, I feel in duty bound to express you my most sincere thanks and congratulation. You certainly have done a wonderful work which completely meets my expectation -

Now, I hope that you will soon come to turn out the first soil and give me an opportunity to prove you my deep respect and gratitude.

Yours very sincerely,

J. Poulet

Dear Sir:

We wired you today and confirmation of the message is enclosed herewith.

The brick we are offering is a first quality product and we believe considerably larger than our competitors; it is burned to over 2200 degrees Fahr and will make a very attractive exterior effect.

We have had considerable correspondence with your Department upon the subject of face brick, but never the pleasure of a specification and sincerely hope you will see your way clear to give us a chance on this occasion.

Business is quiet and an order such as this will assist us in keeping our crew intact which we are anxious to do particularly on account of the unemployment situation.

Thanking you in anticipation, we are,

Yours very truly,

TENDERS WANTED

Sealed tenders addressed to the undersigned and endorsed on the envelope "Tender for the construction of an Indian Residential School near Lester, Saskatchewan," must be received in his office by noon of the 16th day of June, 1939, daylight saving time, for the erection of the above mentioned building.

Copies of specifications may be seen at the office of the Indians Commissioner at Regina; Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg; Superintendent of Indian Affairs at Saskatoon, and the Department of Finance, Ottawa.

Each tender must be accompanied by an unconditional acceptance of the Dominion of Canada for ten per cent of the amount of the tender, payable on demand, in the form of assigned (War Bonds of the Dominion or Canadian National Railways bonds) will also be accepted as security for the balance thereof if required to make up an odd amount.

Persons tendering decline to enter into any contract which they fail to perform, or fail to complete the work contracted for, will be treated as defaulters and necessarily rejected.

DUNCAIN C. SHAW,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, May 15, 1939.
Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 3rd July 1930.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 17th June, 1930, from the Right Honourable the Prime Minister, for the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, representing that the same being necessary, tenders were called for the construction of the proposed new Muscowequan Indian Residential School, near Lestock, in the Province of Saskatchewan, and that the following tenders were received:

- Smith Bros. and Wilson, Ltd., Regina...........$126,852.00
- Poole Construction Co., Ltd., Regina............$129,285.00
- P.W. Graham and Sons, Ltd., Moose Jaw........$129,950.00
- Clydor Co., Ltd., Winnipeg.....................$141,535.00
- Wilson and Wilson, Ltd., Regina...............$141,750.00
- Shannon Bros., Saskatoon......................$143,500.00
- Bird, Woodall and Simpson, Ltd., Moose Jaw...$145,412.00
- J.H. Simmons, Winnipeg.......................$146,942.00
- Carter-Halls-Aldinger Co., Ltd., Winnipeg.....$147,729.00
- A.W. Cassidy and Co., Ltd., Saskatoon.........$149,800.00

The Architect of the Department reports that the lowest of these tenders, namely that of Smith Bros. and Wilson Ltd., is fair and reasonable.

The Minister recommends that it be accepted pursuant to the requirements of sub-section 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act. Funds are provided in the Vote for Indian Education.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

The Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Dear sir:

Re. Muscowquan Indian Residential School.

I wish to thank you for my appointment as Inspector of Construction on the above school.

I have been onto the site with the contractors and arranged the levels and staked the building.

Owing to the nature of the soil I thought it advisable to arrange for two 5/8 rods at the bottom of the concrete walls and two at the grade line. These can be put in at 7¢.

The demolishing of the old chapel and the excavating are now under way.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.
July 9th 1930.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School.

In going over the plans and specifications with the Rev. Principal he calls my attention to the fact that there is no provision for them to save the rainwater from the roof. Can he have a soft water tank somewhere near the Laundry?

He also states that a root cellar is a necessity before the cold weather sets in, as the present one will be out of use as soon as they move from the old stone building.

Could you give me any information at this date as to the arrangements for the Septic Tank, Water Supply System, and the Electric Light plant?

Is there a time limit on this contract?

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

PROPOSAL NO. 1

Two only VULCAN Return Tube Firebox Boilers, No. RF-50, 48" x 11'-6" long. Having 534 sq.ft. of heating surface (heating surface of tubes alone is 456 sq.ft.), 15.8 sq.ft. of grate area. Height from floor to waterline 78". Overall height of boiler approximately 7'-5". 6" Steam, 4" return, 5" inlet for cold water supply, 1" outlet for drain connection.

General appearance of Boiler is as shown on our drawing No. B-407 herewith. Boiler is constructed of Flange quality plate having a tensile strength of 55,000 to 65,000 lbs. per sq. in. All seams and staybolts are electrically welded. It is to be noted that while the Canadian Inter-Provincial Regulations only allows 15 lbs. working pressure on welded boilers, our boilers are designed for 50 lbs. working pressure, and tested to 60 lbs. in our shops.

Boilers are supplied complete with Bases, in which the grates are held, making a unit separate from the boiler. All castings such as Firedoors, Ashpit Doors and Smokebox doors are of good quality gray iron, and of heavy construction.

PROPOSAL NO. 2

Two only VULCAN Combination Boilers, No. CIOA, 54" x 8'-8" long, having 535 sq.ft. of heating surface, 18 sq.ft. of grate area. Height from floor to waterline 78", overall height of boiler 91".

General appearance of boiler is as shown on our drawing No. 178, herewith.

The balance of this Specification, as regards quality of material, etc., is the same as the balance of Proposal No. 1 covering the Return Tube Firebox Boilers.
VULCAN IRON WORKS LIMITED
WINNIPEG, MAN.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask.

On July 3rd, I was out to the Muscowequan School with the Contractors and Father Paulet, and arranged for levels and staked the new building. Owing to the nature of the ground I thought it advisable to have four 5/8" rods in the basement walls, and arranged with the contractors for these.

The excavation has now been completed and the footings are all in. The carpenters have just started work on the forms for basement walls. The Chapel has been demolished.

Crushed rock, sand, tile and lumber are being delivered on the site. The contractors have good equipment and a very capable foreman on the job.

I have had a set of the steel plans submitted by the Winnipeg Bridge Co., Ltd., and the work is now under way.

We have changed the verandah to the opposite end of the building, and also changed over the Boys' dormitory.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Inspector of Construction.
Sir,

Your file number: 121-5-15.

This request has been referred to the Commissioner of Irrigation at Calgary, and he has been asked to have plans and specifications prepared accordingly. I presume that plans of the school building can be obtained from the Inspector of Construction.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir -

RE LESTOCK INDIAN SCHOOL

Your letter dated July 22nd reached us Saturday noon. We do not know the cause of this late delivery.

Complying with your request regarding our steel we beg to advise that 80% of this steel is fabricated by us in Winnipeg and all detail plans were made by us. The remaining 20%, which consists of the light column sections, is being made in the United States. These sections require the operation of a milling machine to face the splice seats. The milling machine is a very large affair that a number of small structural shops in Canada do not have. We offered this part of the work to Combined Dominion Bridge and Manitoba Bridge, but they refused to do it for us unless they could do the whole job at a price $800, above what we are charging for the contract.

We are a Canadian Company, composed of Canadians, working in opposition to all other Canadian Bridge Companies. We have been going ahead with the steel for the above building fully confident that our methods were in accordance with the meaning of the specifications, as structural steel of the class required for this job is a foreign material, not obtained in Canada. Therefore we firmly believe that the small proportion of the material - approximately 20% - that we are having fabricated outside of Canada in order that we might enjoy a small share of Canadian business, would quite agree to the specifications, on this class of material.
According to our method, the cost of material, both plain and fabricated, with freight paid to Winnipeg, is $4,550.00.

Total material direct from Mill - no work done, with freight paid to Winnipeg would be $4,000.00.

Difference - $550.00

Our price for material F.O.B. Lestock - $6,800.00

We will be able to show invoices later to prove that these figures are approximately correct.

Work on the columns is advancing.

We have endeavored to make our position clear to you, which we trust to your consideration.

Yours truly,

WINNIPEG BRIDGE CO., LTD.

Per [signature]
Aug. 2nd, 1930.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock. Report No. 2.

Since my report of July 19th, the above job has gone on well. Material is being delivered on the job in good time and well up to standard called for. The only delay is with the steel columns which I have had no word of yet, apart from the fact that they were under way and that about 20% of the fabrication was being done in the United States. With further reference to my letter of yesterday's date I am now enclosing the letter received from the Winnipeg Bridge Co., so that you may fully understand my position in this matter. If I live up to the specifications I must refuse to allow these columns to go into the job. Will you return this letter for my files?

Owing to the fact that the heating plans call for a 30" chimney I have instructed the contractors to increase the size to this; the cost will be about $90.00 extra.

I have found that the screen doors cannot be put in place on the rear entrances of Gordon School on account of the Yale door closers, so would suggest that you allow me to have the rear entrance doors on this job made with the upper section glazed in small panes; this to be interchangeable with screens for summer use.

Father Pauliet would like to have full screens on all windows in class rooms, dormitories, and playrooms. Also to have a skylight about 2'.0" x 6'.0" over the end of Kitchen furthest from windows. I thought it might be just as well to arrange for inside heavy screens for playrooms now.

The concrete walls are now in and the basement frames set on the front portion, and the brickwork started today.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
