R.Gurney Orr Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Re: Muscovequan School.

I enclose herewith copy of my telegram to Mr. Duncan C. Scott today; after a lengthy talk with Smith Bros. & Wilson Ltd. It would appear that the Winnipeg Bridge Co., are a new firm who at the present not able to do a certain amount of the column fabrication in Winnipeg, although I am informed that they will be doing so next year. As outlined in their letter to me, which I forwarded to the Deputy Minister, they were unable to get the Dominion Bridge or Manitoba Bridge (both the same now) to do this work, so they proceeded to have it done in Minneapolis. The total cost of this fabrication I am told is about $550.00.

In view of the fact that the job would be closed down for three or four weeks anyway if steel had to be reordered, and that we are right now waiting for these columns I feel that they should be allowed to go in. It would certainly be unfortunate if the brickwork were delayed into the cold weather; by the time you get this the brickwork will be up to column height on the main building, and some of the masons will be laid off.

1.
Would you object to having the upper panel of the stair entrances made removable so that a screen panel could be put in instead of using a screen door which cannot go on because of the arm of the Yale closer. It might be better to have such panels in the vestibule doors and arranged to hook the entrance doors back. With the small amount of light that gets to the bottom of the stairs I believe a glazed panel, fairly high up, would be best for the entrance doors.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Scott:

I wish to draw your attention to the fact that we are now using power supplied by the Calgary Hydro Electric Co. in our school at Edmonton, which means that there is an up-to-date plant at this institution which could be used to advantage at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, thereby saving the Department a few thousand dollars. There is no necessity for keeping it at this institution as a stand-by (emergency) plant.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott.

The Indian Residential School at Edmonton is now connected up with the Calgary Hydro Electric Co. When this building was erected there was installed an up-to-date electric lighting plant, which is now available for use at some other school. I would recommend that this plant be shipped for use at the new Muscowequan Indian Residential School, which is being erected this summer. Before the plant is shipped it should be completely overhauled by the manufacturers to be sure that it is in perfect working order.

ARCHITECT.
August 19, 1930.

Sir,

Recently the Indian Residential School at Edmonton has been connected up with the power lines of the Calgary Hydro Electric Co. There is at this school an excellent Lister lighting plant, and Commissioner Graham of Regina is being instructed to have this plant completely overhauled by the Lister Co. and shipped for use at the new Muscowequan School. He has been instructed also to have the Lister Co. communicate with you regarding the location of the lighting plant in the new schools. Will you please give the necessary instructions.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of the 18th ultimo and to your 40762-W of the 22nd idem, concerning water supply at the Muscovequan Indian Residential School, near Lestock, Sask., I have now to inform you that Mr. Swan, Inspector of Construction for the new building, telegraphs the Department as follows:-

"Mr. French, of Water Power and Reclamation at Calgary, is investigating water supply at Muscovequan. He finds existing well only good for one hundred twenty five gallons per hour and suggests drilling another so that supply may be six hundred. Understand that Commissioner Graham has sent drilling outfit to Punnichy for other work. Could we have authority to drill while this is in district? Cost is reasonable. Mr. French advised his chief at Calgary to recommend you drilling another well."

The Department replied, by telegram of yesterday's date, as follows:-

"Reference your night letter, you may drill another well at Muscovequan School."

Regina, Sask., August 15th, 1930.

Wm. Swan, Esq.,
Architect,
PUNNICHY, Sask.

Dear Sir,

Re: Lestock Indian School.

With reference to concrete cisterns for rain water, we quote you to put in a concrete cistern 16' diameter, round tank, 7'6" from finished floor to the under side of slab, the sum of $1,050.00.

We further quote you for concrete tank 24' diameter, round tank, and 8'6" from finished floor to the underside of slab, the sum of $1,840.00.

The 16' tank has a capacity of a little over 8,000 gallons when 12" from the top. The 24" one has a capacity of about 11,000 gallons when 12" from the top.

These quotations are for tanks similar in design to those furnished at Duck Lake and Cardston for the Indian Department and the quotations do not include any piping. The arrangement for piping should be considered in the price for septic tank work and the outside sewage and rain water disposal.

Please bear in mind that one year's rainfall on these roofs would be about 80,000 gallons.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.
per

General Superintendent.

J.Y.
August 16th 1930.

J.B. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock. Report No. 3.

The above job has just been making fair progress since my last report, although materials are arriving in large quantities with the exception of the steel. It is on this account that the work is being held back, but I understand now that there is every chance of the Winnipeg Bridge making a working agreement with the Dominion Bridge to fabricate the columns in Winnipeg. The contention of the contractors is that the fabrication of the columns in Minneapolis is quite in accord with the specifications as it is merely Canadian materials that is called for and not Canadian fabrication. In any event much of the steel sections will be rolled in the United States even if the Dominion Bridge do supply them.

There seems to be a general feeling up here that the combined Dominion Bridge and Manitoba Bridge Companies are trying to squeeze out any competition, and that the Winnipeg Bridge Co. is the only company in Western Canada from which contractors can get a real competitive figure on structural steel.

I trust that by Monday we will have definite word that things are settled, and that there will be no more serious delay. If there is to be more than a weeks delay the contractors will shut down as the building is up to ground floor joist level on the main structure now, and only four bricklayers are working.

I am enclosing a price on a rainwater tank received from the contractors, and it would be as well if this could be decided upon at an early date.

I am meeting a Mr. French from Calgary on the job on Wednesday to go into the matter of the water supply and the sewage disposal with him.

Would it not be as well to decide soon on which rooms you intend to cover with linoleum?

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Sir,

Your file number: 121-5-15.

I have received your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to the water supply at the Muscovequan Indian residential school near Lestock, Saskatchewan, containing a copy of the Inspector's telegram regarding the drilling of a new well and note that the department has authorized that this well should be drilled. A telegram on the same subject has been received from the Commissioner of Irrigation and I have acquainted him with the decision of your department.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Per

T.R.L. MacInnes, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Aug. 29th 1930.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re. Muscowequan Indian Residential School. Report No.4.

Since my report of Aug. 16th this job has been making good progress. The question of the steel has been settled by the Winnipeg Bridge Co., making arrangements to have the columns fabricated by the Dominion Bridge Co. These columns are now all in place on the works and steel joists are being put on. See photographs enclosed.

The brickwork is up to ground floor level on main portion of building, and the bricklayers are now working on the rear wing and interior walls.

The cut stone is mostly all on the ground and the setting of that on the front entrance has been started.

Yesterday the concrete floors in boiler room and coal room were put in place, so that the boilers could be set as soon as they arrive.

Mr. French of the Water Power and Reclamation Dept. at Calgary was down from Aug 20th to Aug. 23rd, and we went over the question of water supply and sewage disposal. The latter is settled, but the water question will not be settled until the well drillers have been on the job, which I expect will be early next week. I drove Mr. French to Nokomis to interview a well driller, but eventually arrangements were made with a Regina firm who had instructions from Commissioner Graham to do some drilling on the Poor Man Reserve; Mr. Graham kindly giving them instructions to divert the outfit to Muscowequan first.

In discussing the matter with Mr. French it was decided to recommend that the electric plant be housed in the same building as the water pumping machinery, and thus leave only the laundry to be placed in the old school building. I think this would be a great advantage in case of fire in the old wooden building. Mr. French will be submitting a layout to you.

We are having good building weather and with the ground floor slab being run early next week there will be more bricklayers put on, and the job should go rapidly.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction

Sept. 8th 1930.

R. Gurney Orr Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Orr;

Re: Muscovequan Indian School.

I have not yet had word as to where you intend to put linoleum in the above job. Father Paulet is expecting that it will be in the same rooms as at Gordons which of course is the chapel, classrooms, dormitories, principal's office, and corridors. This undoubtedly does make a real job for a school building.

The work is going along well, although it has not been rushed so far; but now that the steel question is cleared up things will move quicker. Herewith a snap of the front I took the other day, and although I carelessly had my camera at quite an angle it gives you some idea that we are getting a real good job on the brickwork.

I hope that you will be able to come West again this fall and look all the work over.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Sept. 13th 1930.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School. Report No. 5.

This job has been going on well during the past two weeks; the ground floor slab is all on except for a portion over the Boiler Room which we have had to leave until the boilers are in place; they being at Lestock today. There are now ten bricklayers at work and the walls of the Ground Floor are going up; see photographs enclosed. The plumbers and electricians are on the job, and most of the underground work has been done.

After a little delay the well driller got started yesterday, and today he was down to forty feet with water showing; we intend to go another ten or fifteen feet before putting a test on which we hope to do on Monday.

The steel erector is keeping well ahead with the steel and it is going up without trouble.

The work is going along well and smoothly and I think that there will be little danger of the building not being closed in before cold weather. I think it would be as well to arrange to have the passage from rear of building connected up with the old building at an early date. This of course comes out at a level some four feet below grade and should continue to connect up with present basement of old building where the laundry machinery will be installed. This will require excavating, concrete, and brickwork, with possibly a concrete slab roof.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Sept. 27th, 1930.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock.

Report No. 6.

Since my last report we have obtained a good supply of water in the new well at a depth of 146 feet. It is very soft and quite nice to drink. I have samples in at the Provincial Analyst and within the course of a day or so should have a full report, although we are quite satisfied that it will be O.K. The water is within thirty feet of the top of casing and by boiling at the rate of 400 gallons per hour it can be taken down to ninety feet from the top but at that rate stays at that level. I have given Mr. French at Calgary a full report of this and have a letter from him this morning in which he states that the plans for the pump house and septic tank have been drawn up, but have not yet been traced. I would urge that every effort be made to get this work in hand right away as we are now having frost at night, and can expect real cold weather within a week or so. I really believe that it will be unnecessary to save the rainwater now that we have a good supply of soft water. If the electrical plant is housed in the same building as the pumps and pressure tanks I think it will be much more satisfactory than to put the plant in the old wooden building with all the risk of having the building without light and water should a fire occur in the old building.

The contractors are still keeping things moving smoothly, there being two slabs poured and steel joists on one wing ready for the third. The boilers are now installed and the floor over is poured and ready for the Chapel brickwork. The Plumbers and Steamfitters are making good progress all underground work being in, and the concrete floors being run. All steel is erected with the exception of beams running into brickwork. The plasterer arrived on the job yesterday to see if the lathing could be started; I find that he did not figure on metal angle beads as they were not definitely specified, but I notified the contractors that these would have to be used on all external angles.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Regina, Sask.

Form No. 101
Commissioner of Irrigation,
Calgary, Alta.

Sir,

I beg to submit herewith plans for sewage disposal works to be constructed for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Lestock, Sask.

Introductory:

This school is one of the modern standard fireproof structures similar in design and size to those at Gleichen and St. Paul, Alta., or Punnichy, Sask. The number of pupils and staff will probably not exceed 150 people. The sewage requirements will therefore be similar to those at the other schools and the volume should be less than 1,000,000 gal. or two acre-feet per year.

The school is located upon a high elevation of ground having considerable slope towards the east and south. It was considered sufficient to build a standard septic tank and turn the effluent into a ditch upon the side of the hill about 400 feet east of the school. The liquid would largely seep away into the cultivated soil. The drainage would be in the direction of a large shallow slough about one half of a mile northeast of the school. This is the same system recommended for the Blue Quill school near St. Paul, Alta.

Works:

The sanitary sewage and drainage from boiler room will be kept separate until past the septic tank. The drainage from the laundry room located in the old frame structure will be through the existing sewer drain.

The sanitary sewage and drainage from the boiler room will be conducted to a manhole chamber located 50 feet north of the east wing of the school. From thence the liquids will be conducted in two separate pipes laid in a single trench as far as the septic tank 250 feet east of the school. The sanitary sewage will empty into the septic tank and the drainage from the boiler room will be bypassed. The grade of the sanitary sewer from the school to the septic tank is set at 1/4 inch per foot, the minimum slope permitted by law.

The septic tank recommended is of similar design to that constructed at the MacIntosh Indian School in Ontario. It will be deeper to allow for greater storage of sludge. The top will be a reinforced concrete slab, as recommended by Mr. Swan, the local architect and inspector. In other respects there is no change in design from that for the above mentioned school.

The effluent will be discharged intermittently by Anthes Syphons into a six inch sewer pipe emptying upon the
ground close to the edge of a cultivated field as aforementioned.

Remarks:

Since the school will be ready for occupancy before spring it is advisable to have these works under construction within sixty days before the commencement of freezing weather.

Your obedient servant,

(signed) Merritt H. French.

P.S. A complete bound report for record purposes can be prepared at the completion of the works.

F.
Sir,

Your file number: 121-5-15.

I shall be glad to be advised if the scheme proposed is satisfactory, and if so, whether it is intended to begin construction of the works before the close of the season, in which case specifications and tenders will be prepared.

Your obedient servant,

Oct. 7th 1930.

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

I enclose herewith third certificate of payment on the above job. This is in duplicate with copies of progress estimate as submitted by the contractors.

I would point out to you the necessity of having the pump and power house started without delay as the weather is now uncertain. I have sent a telegram to Mr. French of the Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Dept. at Calgary Alta., reading thus;-"Can you rush plans for power and pump house. Bricklayers will be away from job in two weeks and weather is uncertain."

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Funnichy, Saskatchewan
Oct. 12th 1930.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock. Report No.7.

With the exception of parapet wall on main building and walls of Chapel, the brickwork of the building is complete, so far as the exterior work is concerned. Only the bearing walls inside have been built as these have been the only inside brickwork necessary; every effort having been made to get all exterior work done before cold weather set in. All concrete roof and floor slabs, with the exception of Chapel roof, have been run, and the framing of wooden portion of roof started. Most of the waterproofing on inside of exterior walls is on, and lathers are at work on walls and ceilings. The plasterers have commenced work on the boiler Room and Kitchen etc., and have the first coat on this wing. They have also completed the plastering on the side and rear entrances so that there would be no danger from frost by leaving until rest of work was ready. They are supply and putting in place the metal corner bead at the price of 8¢ a foot.

Since my last report the last of the steel has been erected, by the placing of the large beams over Chapel.

The analyst's report on the water from the new well shows that it is only two thirds as hard as the present water in use. The bacteriological report states that quite a large number of bacteria are present, presumably from human or animal origin, as the well is one hundred and forty six feet deep, and with two strata of blue clay between the surface and the water we have assumed that this test results from the metal casing being left round in the yard, where cattle were running, before being placed in position. The Rev. Principal is having the well pumped for some time so that a cleaner test can be made.

May I again urge that the work on the water and electric plant building be put in hand at the earliest possible moment as the weather may be turning cold at any time now; in fact we have several inches of snow on the ground today. May I instruct the steamfitter to provide for the heating of the portion of the old building that is to remain, from the new plant?

Photographs of the work taken a few days ago are enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Oct. 25th 1930

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask. Report No.8.

Since my report of Oct. 12th last we have had some very severe weather, and owing to the non-arrival of the storm sash the job was at a standstill for two days. The weather was so bad that six men were killed by carbon monoxide poisoning while spending a night in a car less than four miles from the city of Regina, the roads being drifted so badly that the car could not be driven in. I regret to say that one of these was from the job, and that another one of the plumbers is only just out of hospital as a result of being in the stalled car.

The bricklayers have been out on strike for a few days, but are back on the work again now. The strike was nothing to do with this job, but all of our men were called out.

All outside brickwork is now finished with the exception of the chimneys. The roofer is now at work, and today has the two wings tarred and gravelled, the wood work of the centre roof and chapel will be finished by Wednesday next.

The interior partitions are going up and the plasters are at work on the two first coats. The firescapes are up, and the heating is well ahead.

The steel stairs have been delivered at the job, and will be erected during the next two weeks.

The contractors have salamanders on the job and I am watching the plastering for frost.

I have heard nothing from you as to the pump house and septic tank yet. It is getting quite late for outside concrete and brickwork unless we go to the trouble of protecting same as it is placed.

The excavation for passage between old and new building has been done.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott.

The Dominion Water Power Branch have forwarded a report from the Commissioner of Irrigation of Calgary with reference to the proposed sewage disposal system for the new Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Lestock, Sask. It will be necessary to build a septic tank and make the necessary connections to and from the tank. The cost will be approximately $2,000.00.

Smith Bros. and Wilson of Regina are the contractors for the school. Will you please advise me if this work can be given to them on a cost plus 10% basis or give me the name of a firm who may be employed to carry out the work.

Owing to the lateness of the season it is advisable that the work be commenced as early as possible.

ARCHITECT.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)
September 15, 1930.

The Commissioner of Irrigation,
Department of the Interior,
Calgary.

Sir,-

I beg to attach water supply plans for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School now under construction near Lestock, Sask.

Introductory.

The school is one of the modern standard fireproof structures similar in design and size to those at Gleichen and St Paul, Alta., and Punnichy, Sask. The number of pupils and staff will probably not exceed 150 people. The water requirements therefore should be somewhat similar to those at the other schools and not exceed one canita allowance of 30 gallons or a total of 4500 gallons per day. It is presumed that any reasonable reserve supply of water provided for domestic requirements will also be sufficient to quench any fire that may occur in the contents of the building and any ordinary blaze that may arise in the frame structure nearby used for laundry purposes etc. In the latter building complete chemical fire equipment should be installed.

Water Supply.

The water supply will come from one old proven well and one new well to be drilled. The existing well was given two thorough tests and can be relied upon to give 125 Imp. gals. per hour under continuous pumping. This well is 55 feet deep and was dug by hand and lined with concrete. An attempt should be made to lower this well a few feet to provide a greater depth of water in the well. Normally about two feet of water stands in the well but this depth decreases as water is pumped out until the depth is only two inches when 140 Imp. gals. per hour are being pumped.

Provision has been made to drill another well to a lower stratum in order to provide a more certain and more ample water supply. It is considered that the combined capacity of the wells should equal 600 Imp. gals. per hour.

Works.

The pump house structure will be placed just west of the school close to the existing well. It will consist of one room buried two feet underground for frost protection. The major portion of the room will be taken up by two 1500 Imp. gal. pressure tanks made by the Dominion Bridge Co. The remainder of the floor space will be reserved for two pumps, a stairway and probably a small stove. The superstructure above ground to house the stairway will be of red brick to harmonize with the school.
The floors, walls and part of the top will be of concrete while that part over the pressure tanks will be made of creosoted timber so that the tanks can be readily removed and replaced when in an unserviceable condition.

For the existing well a shallow well pump with a capacity of 125 Imp. gals. per hour will be required. This pump will deliver water directly from the ground into the pressure tanks. Just what machinery is needed for the other well will depend upon the nature of the water supply.

All water for laundry purposes will be obtained from rainfall and stored in a large concrete cistern which has probably already been constructed.

Pipeline to School.

The delivery pipe from the pressure tanks to the school should be three inches in diameter, to carry 100 Imp. gals. per minute for fire protection.

Remarks.

Since it is anticipated that the school will be occupied before next spring it is advisable that the construction of the works commence within the next sixty days before freezing weather sets in.

The existing well is sufficient for the operation of the school with the most rigid economy in the use of the water. Hence the pressure system and the pump for the existing well could be installed immediately. The second well could be connected when it is drilled.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) M. H. French

Sir,

Your file number: 121-5-15.

Re Muscowequan Indian School.

I enclose herewith a report received from Mr. Tempest, Commissioner of Irrigation, dealing with the proposed water supply system for the Muscowequan school. The Commissioner reports that there is some uncertainty as to the source of power required to drive the pumps so an allowance has been made which should cover the cost of either electrically driven pumps or those of another type.

A blue print is also enclosed showing details of the proposed works. The general lay-out is as shown on the blue-line print enclosed with my letter of October 8th regarding proposed sewage disposal system.

An estimate of the cost is also enclosed herewith amounting to $5516.00; also for the sewage disposal system amounting to $2930.80.

Regarding your letter of August 23rd last in which authority was given to drill an additional well at this school, I am advised by Mr. Tempest that this well has now been drilled to one hundred and forty-six feet. The water stands in it at thirty feet from grade and lowers to ninety feet from grade when pumping at the rate of four hundred gallons per hour. The water has been analyzed and appears satisfactory for domestic purposes, but I am awaiting further details in regard to this from the Commissioner.

I shall be glad to have your instructions regarding this project.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Per

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Oct. 25th 1930.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re. Well at Muscowequan Indian School, Sask.

The enclosed accounts were sent to Mr. Graham at Regina, but he has forwarded them to me to be O.K.'d and sent direct to you. The charges are based on the same rates that McPherson & Thom Co. are charging for the other wells being drilled under instructions from Mr. Graham.

The bill from the Muscowequan School is on account of moving the outfit and providing Mr. Dempsey, the driller, with board and lodging while at work. This arrangement was made with McPherson & Thom and is allowed for in their price; and I asked Father Paulet to provide this service for them.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

REGINA, Nov. 4th, 1930.

Mr. R. Gerring-Crr,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

It has been brought to the notice of the Department that a new Indian School is being erected at Lestock, Sask., and while the plumbing installation has been satisfactorily installed by Messrs Vagg, Wilson and Company of Regina, the Department is unable to secure any information regarding the type of sewage disposal system which is being constructed in connection with this building.

I have been informed through Mr. Swan the resident architect at Punnichy that plans for the sewage disposal plant and for the necessary drains outside the school building are prepared in your office and that information regarding this matter might be obtained from you.

As you are no doubt aware all plumbing and drainage work within this Province is subject to the provisions of the enclosed Plumbing and Drainage Regulations and the Department is frequently called upon to give engineering advice regarding the alterations or reconstruction of existing systems, particularly in connection with buildings of this nature.

I would, therefore, appreciate it if you would be good enough to let me have a blue print showing the intentions of your Department in the matter of the drainage of this school and I am authorized to say that the Provincial Department of Public Health will be glad to co-operate at any time in the matter of securing efficient water supply and drainage for any buildings constructed in this Province by the Department of Indian Affairs.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

R. H. Murray,
Director,
Division of Sanitation.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)
Nov. 12, 1930.

Dear Sirs,

Replying to your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the new Muscowequan Indian School near Lestock, I beg to say that the plans for the sewage disposal system are being prepared by the Engineers of the Dominion Water Power Branch in Calgary. If you will communicate with them no doubt they will be glad to furnish you with a copy of the plans.

Yours very truly,

H. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

R. H. Murray, Esq.,
Director, Div. of Sanitation,
Dept. of Health,
Regina, Sask.
The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., Report No.9.

I am pleased to say that during the past two weeks the weather has been very fine, and the work has gone along very well. All the tar and gravel work with the exception of the roof over the passage to Chapel, is finished, and the tinsmith is now putting the flashing in place. The brickwork of chimneys has been carried up and another day will see the stone cap on. All inside partitions are up and the brick lining of stairwells is complete.

The lathing is practically finished and the plasterers have much of the first coats on. The glazed brick lining of kitchen and scullery has been done.

The steamfitters will have heat on by Monday next.

The storm sash have been put in place and the job closed in for work during cold weather. The steel stairs are in place, and the millwork is being delivered.

Mr. Orr was here during the weekend of Nov. 2nd, and visits were made to both Gordon's School and Muscowequan. Many points were cleared up and arrangements made to rush the pump house etc., as well as arranging for the cold storage equipment.

Mr. French of the Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service is to be on the job next Tuesday and have a forty-eight hour test on the new well before commencing the pump and powerhouse.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Lestock, Sask.

November 17th, 1930

Sir,

I enclose herewith voucher No. 396 for $58.72 in favour of Father J. Poulet, Principal of the Muscowequan Indian School. This represents the amount paid by the reverend Principal in repairing damage done to the school windows during the hailstorm on July 26th last.

The storm in question, which was the heaviest experience in many years, smashed about 160 panes of glass at the school as well as completely demolishing the crop. I recommend that this account be paid.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
We will supply and install a heating system in the proposed new pump house, connect water mains supplying building to pressure tanks, and install one floor drain, according to the following specifications.

Radiators will consist of two ceiling type, containing in all a total of 125 sq. ft. The present steam main in Boys Toilet will be enlarged and a branch taken from it to supply these radiators. A separate return will be taken back to the nearest main return. Branch steam main will be dripped through a float and thermostatic trap and radiators will be provided with packless valves and return traps. Steam main and branches will be covered with air cell covering and controlling gate valves will be installed. Water pipes will be connected to pressure tanks after they are installed, as we have not provided for any work connected with the installation of the pump and tanks nor for any connections between them, or between them and the well. Our price is also based on the assumption that the pump house will be built immediately adjoining the Main Building.

We will perform all of the work outlined above in a sound and workmanlike manner for the sum of $780.00.

We trust that these prices are satisfactory, and hope to be favoured with your valued order, which will receive our usual careful attention.

Very truly yours,

VAGG WILSON COMPANY LTD.

Per A.E.Knibb

A.E.Knibb. T.
VAGG, WILSON CO. LTD.
SANITARY, HEATING AND VENTILATING ENGINEERS
SHEET METAL WORKERS AND ROOFERS

Regina, Sask.

November 15, 1930.

Messrs Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd.
104-5 Donahue Building,
Regina, Sask.

Gentlemen,

Re: Lestock Indian School.

In reply to your letter of November 5th, we give you herewith the following quotations.

We will connect up the existing radiators in the old building to the new system, using present steam mains, but installing new return mains and connecting same to new boilers. We will arrange each radiator to receive the return connection, and fit each one with a thermostatic trap. Drips on the ends of mains will be provided with float and thermostatic traps. Main header on new boilers will be tapped to accommodate new steam main, and necessary gate valves will be provided and installed. Steam mains and branches will be covered. We have not provided for any work in connection with the removal of the old boiler and pipes connected therewith.

We will perform all of the work outlined above in a sound and workmanlike manner for the sum of $6149.00.

We will connect the High Pressure steam and make the necessary water connections to the Laundry Machinery and fixtures in the old building. The steam connections will consist of an 1½" main from the H.P Boiler to the Washer and the Tumbler, each machine being provided with necessary globe valve, and all fittings being extra-heavy cast iron. Necessary drip traps required will be supplied of Armstrong manufacture, and each provided with a globe valve. Steam main and branches will be covered with 85% Magnesia Covering. It is contemplated that condensate will be discharged to sewer or soft water tank, as we have not provided for a pump or return trap to deliver it back to the boiler. We have also provided for the installation of one floor drain in the Laundry.

We will perform all of the work outlined above in a sound and workmanlike manner for the sum of $770.00
R.Gurney Orr Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr.Orr;

Re:Muscoweguan School.

Since your visit I have gone into the matter of the water supply,and the heating of the pump house etc., with the result that I am recommending that the pump and electric plant house be made part of the main building. I enclose you a sketch of this copy of which has been approved by the Dominion Water Power Dept. This will simplify our heating problem which cannot be overcome without the use of some form of pump on the wet return and an overhead steam pipe to supply radiation. I really believe this will be a much better job, and am arranging to have the contractors go ahead.

Mr.French was down to put on a test, and after running a pump for the best part of a day at 500 gals per hr., the sand came up the casing about eighteen feet, and he had to stop and arrange to have the driller come back and clean this out and put in a screen. As soon as this can be done he will be back again to finish the test. There appears to be a good supply of water.

I have discussed the matter of an electrically driven pump with the Lister people and they have given a figure on one of their pumps that can be run from their plant that is going in. They would put in one of their anti-freezing deep well pumps with all equipment to automatically deliver 480 gals per hr. run from the plant to be installed, for the sum of $447.85. I think Mr.French will be recommending this.

I have had the Kelvinator man on the job and a complete plant for that size room will run to $260.00 installed. I have received figures from Smith Bros. & Wilson which have been submitted by the heating contractors, and I am enclosing them for your perusal. Will you return these to me with instructions? Have this work go ahead?

Are you calling for tenders on the septic tank etc.?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
The painters have started work on the job, and during some of the fine weather of the past two weeks have managed some of the outside work.

The carpenters are now fitting windows and screens, and putting trim in shape for painters to work on.

The plasterers have started on the finished coat now that the steamfitters have temporary heat on.

The tinsmith has put flashing, and ventilators in place, and has hung the metal clad doors to stairwells.

A start has been made during the last two days on the cement base and the concrete floors.

On Nov. 12th Mr. French of the Dominion Water Power Dept., came down to start a forty-eight hour test on the new well, but after one day he found that the sand and gravel had come up the casing about eighteen feet. This necessitated having the drilling machine ordered back on the job and a screen put in the bottom of the well. This has not yet been done as the machine was at work until a day or so ago on Poor Man's Reserve, but I understand that it will be down in a day or so.

The contractors are making a start on the pump & electric plant house just as soon as Mr. French finds his test satisfactory.

We have been taking up the matter of an electrically operated pump for the well, with the R.A. Lister people who are putting in the plant, and we are assured that they could put in a pump to work from their plant satisfactorily, and covered by their guarantee. Mr. French is going into this matter fully.

May I urge that steps be taken to have the work started on the septic tank and the drains running thereto. Every week's delay makes the matter of excavating more costly, and it will be but a short time before the plumbers will be ready to put the fixtures in place.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Dec. 2, 1930.

Dear Mr. Swan,

I regret the delay in giving you the name of the party who is to install the septic tank and drainage at the Muscowequan Indian School. As soon as I get the name of the firm, however, I will immediately wire you.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

Wm. Swan, Esq.,
Punnichy, Sask.

Dear Sir,

(Your file 4882),

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of No. 18th and we are sending a sample of the sand which was left with us by Mr. French, to the Manufacturers of the screens, so that they may decide for themselves, as to just what screen would give the best results, with instructions to ship one of these screens, immediately, by express.

Just as soon as this screen arrives, we will arrange to have it forwarded to Lestock, and will immediately notify you accordingly.

The details of the proposition, as set out in your letter, confirms the conversation which was had by the writer, and your Mr. French, and we will be very pleased to loan the pump jack, the cylinder, the pump head, and the sucker rods, as per your request.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
November 18, 1930.

Sirs,

With regard to the new well recently drilled by you at the Muscowequan Indian School at Lestock, Saskatchewan, Mr. French our inspecting engineer reports that sand has risen twenty feet in the well and that it will be necessary to clean the sand out and probably set a well screen at the bottom of the casing.

I understand Mr. French interviewed your Mr. Thom concerning this matter and that you have a rig at Quinton that you could readily divert to this work within the course of a few days.

Mr. French informs me that the rig could be moved at the present time by teams as there is very little snow, and there is a well graded road from Quinton to the school.

If you are prepared to undertake the work please move your rig to Lestock, clean out the well and install a five-foot length of screen in the casing which is 5-5/8" internal diameter, the screen to be slotted to suit the sand submitted as a sample. The screen should be delivered at Lestock before the work or cleaning the well is completed in order to avoid unnecessary delay.

It is understood that your teams for hire of the rig and operators are $20 per day, the department to pay the cost of moving. The screen will be paid for in the usual way.

Will you please write me by return if you are prepared to carry out the work on these terms.

Our engineer will be making a pump test after the well is cleaned out and would like to have the use of the pump, jack, cylinder, pump-head and sucker-rods which were used before, if this is agreeable to you, and we would pay a fair charge for use of this equipment.

If you decide to do this work please wire date of arrival of the rig at Lestock and our engineer will arrange to be on the ground at the time.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) J. S. Tempest,
Commissioner of Irrigation.

Messrs. McPherson, Thom & Co.,
Regina,
Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 1)
Sir,

Re Muscowequan School.

I am advised by the Commissioner of Irrigation that the deep well at the Muscowequan school is choked with sand which has arisen in the casing about twenty feet, and arrangements have been made to clean out the well and place a sand screen at the bottom of the casing, the work to be done by Messrs. McPherson and Thoms of Regina.

It was necessary to arrange for this matter while a rig was available in the district and our inspecting engineer, Mr. French, advised immediate action. Copies of correspondence relative thereto are enclosed for your information.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Dec. 6th 1930.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., Report No. 11.

Since my last report the bricklayers have finished the two chimneys, and the passage way from rear of building to old building. The plasterers are making good progress with the finish coat and the cement base. Several of the cement floors are now down, and the linoleum has been delivered on the job. The carpenters are putting on trim as fast as the plastering is dry. I regret to say that I have had to refuse some of the hardware; Ashdowns having shipped all plain hinges instead of ball bearing as specified.

The painters are steadily working away, and the electrician is now pulling the wires.

Baths, basins, and other fixtures are being shipped and delivered on the job.

The Lister plant has arrived from Edmonton and is being stored until we have the powerhouse up.

The Kelvinator people have the cold storage plant in hand and this will be delivered in a short time. The insulating of the cold storage room has been finished with the exception of putting on the finish coat of cement plaster over the cork.

Father Paulet has asked that a mastic flooring be put down in the recreation rooms and dining room in basement, and that a cement plaster dado be put on in the recreation rooms and adjoining wash rooms. I understand that he is writing direct regarding these matters, but in order that you may have more information on the matter I have secured a price from the contractors of the difference between finishing in cement and with the plain mastic; this is $3 per square foot if a minimum of 4500 sq. feet are put down. You will of course understand that if this change is to be made I must know immediately. The first coat of plaster is on the walls and this will have to be torn off.

In accordance with your telegraphic instructions this morning I have instructed the contractors to proceed with the sewage disposal system.

Mr. French will be on the job again on Tuesday when the test of the well will be again started.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Regina, Sask.

Dec. 20th 1930.

Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., Report No. 12.

The finish coat of plaster is now on in most of the building except the basement, and the carpenters are placing trim as fast as the plastering is drying. Doors are not being hung yet as the butts only arrived today after being changed. The cement floors are going down, and the cement base is being put in place. The electrician has most of the wires pulled and switches in place. The fixtures are on the job.

We have had no satisfaction with the well test as yet; and the driller is now going down another fifty feet if necessary. Mr. French left on Thursday and will return as soon as the well is in shape for another test. I have asked that his Department recommend to you that we install the tank and the small pump to the present well at once so that there will be water on as soon as the plumbers have the fixtures installed, which I expect will be sometime early in January. The pump and powerhouse is ready to have the plant put in place, and the Lister company are sending a man up after Christmas.

The chief trouble with the new well seems to be that the sand chokes the supply of water after pumping for ten or twelve hours, and the rate drops to about two hundred gals. per hour. As soon as pumping stops the water immediately rises to the old level of thirty feet from top of well.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dec. 18, 1930

Commissioner of Irrigation,
Dept. of the Interior,
Calgary, Alta.

Sir,

I beg to state that from Dec. 8th to Dec. 17th I was engaged in making a pumping test of a well for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School at Lestock, Sask.

By referring to previous correspondence on file you will note that a pumping test made in this well the middle of November raised sand and gravel twenty feet in the casing and choked the pump cylinder. Arrangements were then made with Messrs. Macpherson & Co., local representatives of the Ontario Wind Engine & Pump Co. at Regina, for them to move their drilling outfit back to the well and clean out this sand and gravel. They were also instructed to order and have on hand a suitable screen for the well.

The drilling outfit left Quinton on Monday Dec. 8th and arrived at Lestock the following night. The well was cleaned out, the screen inserted and a pumping test commenced by Thursday afternoon. The test continued all night and by morning the discharge had decreased from 350 gal. to 90 gal per hour.

The screen was drawn out and examined. The narrow slits in the top two feet and bottom foot of the screen were clean while the middle two feet of the slits were partly clogged with sand. This confirmed the driller's report that the water vein was shallow and indicated that the most of the screen had been clogged with clay.

A test of the well was then made with the screen removed. Three feet of screened gravel were first placed in the bottom of the casing to hold down the sand. After pumping for fifteen hours the flow had decreased to 210 gallons per hour. This was more satisfactory than with the screen but yet insufficient for the school requirements. Also a sounding of the well showed that the gravel had risen one foot.

It was then decided to widen the 2700 slits in the screen with a back saw. A charge of five sticks of dynamite was also exploded in the stratum of clay below the sand and gravel with the hope that the resulting cavity would be filled with sand and gravel from above. This would increase the depth of the porous material around the screen and also its capacity.

After the screen was again inserted another pumping test was made. After fifteen hours the discharge had again decreased to 100 gal. per hour. This was not only...
disappointing but seemed to indicate that the casing had penetrated a pocket of water instead of a strong water-bearing vein.

It seemed useless to make any further attempt to develop a satisfactory well at that depth. It had been noted that a moderate flow of water had been obtained at a depth of 35 feet, a stronger flow at 90 feet and a still larger one at 146 feet. After a consultation between Mr. Swann, Inspector of Construction for the School, Mr. J. Dempsey the driller, and myself, it was decided that it was advisable to drill the same well fifty to one hundred feet deeper before trying some other location. It was hoped that a stronger flow would be encountered at a greater depth.

Mr. Swann said that Mr. Dempsey should make preparation to commence drilling and that he himself would take the matter up with his department at Ottawa. Mr. Dempsey telephoned his company in Regina, Messrs. Macpherson and Thom, for well casing and will probably commence drilling Monday Dec. 22nd.

Upon my return to Calgary I had time for a short interview with Mr. Thom of Macpherson & Thom and suggested that he submit to our office a statement for material and services rendered in connection with this last pumping test.

In conclusion it might be mentioned that it would appear reasonable to desire a well with a tested flow of about 400 gal. per hour without any indications of future trouble from sand and gravel. This would permit us to install a pump of 350 Imp. gals. per hour capacity which in 12 hours would deliver 4,200 gals. A test recently made of the existing well at the school gave a capacity of 320 Imp. gals per hour after six hours pumping. This well will provide a very excellent auxiliary supply to use in emergency and in watering the garden, lawn and stock if so desired.

Mr. Swan and I consider it advisable to have a pressure tank and a pumping unit from the existing well now installed. The sewage disposal works and power plant will be in operation early in January and the school will then be ready for occupancy when completed and furnished. With regard to economy in the use of water, the existing well will enable them to operate the school in the new building. There need then be no delay in moving into the new building because of a lack of water supply, and there is no way of determining when an ample supply of water will be procured from another well.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) Merritt H. French.
Vulcan Iron Works Limited
Winnipeg, Canada

Dear Sirs:

Replying to your letter of Jan. 8th, File No. 4862 in connection with tank quoted you in our letter of Dec. 30th.

The tank we quoted on would have 3/8" shell, double riveted butt joint, and 1/2" dished heads. We based our estimate according to Section III of the Canadian Inter-Provincial Regulations for unfired pressure vessels.

If this were estimated according to Section I for boilers with double riveted butt joints, shell would be 7/16" and dished heads 5/8". Both heads could be dished similar to enclosed blue print and inlet and outlet flanges would be threaded flanges instead of flanged necks, as shown on this print. Connections for water gauge would be made by means of couplings welded in the head.

This construction is similar to tank furnished to the Experimental Farm at Scott, Sask., in 1924.

We are of the opinion that a tank of this design would give better service than one having a flat head with diagonal braces, if that is what you mean by rounded end, and the braced flat head would cost considerably more than dished end.
Dominion Government - Cont'd.

To make a tank with 7/16" shell and 5/8" dished heads would increase our price to $870.00, F.O.B. Lestock.

If you prefer tank with one flat head, we can quote you, using a standard 1/2" boiler head. In this case, the manhole would be in the head.

Trusting to hear from you further in this connection, we are,

Yours very truly,

Per: Engineer.
Sir:

Re: Muscowequan Indian School.

I enclose herewith a report received from the Commissioner of Irrigation with reference to a test of the deep well at Muscowequan Indian School.

In my letter of December 2nd I mentioned that this well had choked through sand rising in the casing and that arrangements had been made to clean it out and install a screen. This work has now been done but the results expected have not been realized and the well is now being deepened in an attempt to secure a stronger flow at a lower level.

Mr. French, who made the report herewith, points out the advisability of proceeding with the installation of the shallow well pump for the old well and also a pressure tank so that some water will be available when the school is ready for occupancy, and the Commissioner states that the purchasing of this equipment will be proceeded with.

You will note that the sewage disposal system and the power plant will be finished early in January and that there need then be no delay in moving into the new building on account of the water supply.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston
Director

December 30, 1930.

Memorandum re Statement from the McPherson & Thom Co. of Regina, Sask., for material and services rendered in connection with the testing of a well at Lestock, Saskatchewan, for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

This statement appears to be perfectly in order and is in accordance with the agreement for charges accepted by this office.

The 5-5/8" well strainer was damaged somewhat during the testing operations, but it can be used, if necessary, in this well when deepened.

The charge of $4.80 for wood rods with 5/8" forged couplings is for one 20-foot sucker rod twisted into two pieces while removing it from the well. Part of this rod can be used again if repaired.

The two charges for $26 are for moving the drilling outfit from Quinton to Lestock and return, a distance of 26 miles each way, at $1 per mile.

The charge of $135 is for the driller and drilling machine at $20 per day during the time consumed in moving from Quinton to Lestock and during operations at the well. The actual number of hours for each day were noted and divided by eight in order that the time might be reduced to a day basis. Time was not charged to the machine while it was idle. While the drilling machine was idle the driller was paid at the rate of $1 per hour for his assistance in making the actual pumping tests. This latter charge was paid by myself before leaving Lestock.

In the above charge of $135 for 6½ days time for the machine the company has omitted to include 1½ days for the time which will be taken for the return of the machine to Quinton at the conclusion of the work at Lestock. Since the company has further drilling to do at the Lestock school it would appear reasonable for them to move the machine back to Quinton upon their own time at our expense ($26) if the extra drilling amounts to somewhere near the minimum amount usually guaranteed to drillers for new jobs.

The work in connection with the cleaning out and testing of the well was concluded Dec. 17th. Instructions were given to the driller by Mr. Swan to drill the well deeper.

(Sgd) Merritt H. French.

EXAMINATION BY LISTER EXPERT OF PLANT SHIPPED FROM EDMONTON TO MUSCOWEQUAN SHOWS CYLINDERS CRACKED AND GENERAL POOR CONDITION
COST TO PUT IN RUNNING CONDITION $1800.00 COST OF NEW PLANT
$5500.00 LISTERS WOULD ALLOW $1200.00 ON PURCHASE OF NEW PLANT DO YOU THINK ADVISABLE TO CONSIDER A NEW PLANT

January 3rd, 1931.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., Report No.18.

During the past two weeks the carpenters have been hanging doors and putting on window and door trim; most of the doors on upper floors being now in place.

The cement floors and cement base are steadily going down. Yesterday the cement floors in the basement were started as I had heard nothing from you with regard to putting down mastic floors as asked for by the Principal and outlined in my report of Dec.6th.last. Personally I think the cement floor will be quite satisfactory.

The plasterer has gone on with the finish coat on the walls of the recreation rooms, and these are now finished.

We now have the excavating done for the sewage disposal system, and are laying the tile drains. Fortunately the weather has been very favourable for this work.

Up to this date we have not yet had satisfactory results from the well. When a ten hour run at four hundred gallons per hour caused a drop to about two hundred we decided to go down deeper, and are at present down to one hundred and eighty eight feet with no water. In view of the fact that we have water at ninety five feet and at one hundred and forty six I am writing the Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau asking them to consider the sinking of another well at the one hundred and forty six feet level, and pulling the casing back to that level on the present one and using two wells should we not get water at two hundred and fifty feet or less. Of course Mr. French of the Water Power Dept., has this thing in hand and will no doubt arrive at a satisfactory solution to the problem.

The plumbers are back on the job again, and have started to put some of the fixtures in place.

The painters are steadily working away and are well up with their end of things.

Generally speaking the job is progressing very satisfactorily.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
Sir,

Your file number: 121-5-15.

This decision has been communicated to the Commissioner of Irrigation.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

January 14, 1931.

Mr. R.G. Orr,
Department of Indian Affairs,
165 Sparks St.,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We have received a letter from our Western Branch from which we understand that you are contemplating replacing with new equipment, the electric lighting plant at the Missowequan Indian School.

A quotation has, I understand, already been submitted upon the Lister-Bruston automatic plant operating upon gasoline, but as we think you might be interested in the alternative proposition of having these plants equipped with the Lister Diesel Engine in place of the Lister Gasoline Engine, the writer proposes to call upon you, if convenient, on Friday of this week so that he may give you any information you may desire upon the relative merits of the two models. Should it not be convenient for you to see him on Friday, the 16th, perhaps you would be good enough to telegraph us on Thursday, at our expense, suggesting a date that will be convenient to you.

Yours very truly,

R.A. LISTER & COMPANY (CANADA) LIMITED,

[Signature]
General Manager.

V.S. Callard/DJ

Jan. 13th 1931.

To Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re: Muscovequan Indian School, Lestock.

Since receiving your letter of the 5th inst., in which you stated that the Department had approved the installation of pressure tank and pump for the old well, I have had a talk with Mr. French of the Dominion Water Power Branch who is now on the job testing our new well again. He states that his Department had figures from three firms for the pressure tank, but he did not know whether an order had been placed. If this has not been done might I urge that steps be taken to have this on the site as soon as possible? I am afraid that this may hold the job up if an order is not placed right away.

Mr. French has a test of the new well going on now and the pump has been working for thirty-six hours throwing a stream of three hundred & sixty to seventy gallons per hour. This water appears to be somewhat hard, and this brings up the matter of going ahead with the rainwater tank at this time.

I should also like to have instructions regarding the laundry machinery that you intend to install in the old building. We have a room there 40' x 13'6" in the basement which can be used as a laundry if the old wooden floor is replaced with concrete, and the walls strapped and plastered with cement mortar.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6318, file 657-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Commissioner of Irrigation,
Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Calgary, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

We have your inquiry of the 28th ultimo and are pleased to submit the following quotation.

We shall be able to deliver F.O.B. cars, Lestock, Saskatchewan, one pressure tank 5 1/2' in diameter by 17 1/2' in length for the lump sum price of ELEVEN HUNDRED DOLLARS ($1100.00). This tank we have designed for a 100 pound working pressure, using 7/16" plate for the shell, 1/2" and 5/8" metal for the heads. The longitudinal joints will be of double weld type while the circumferential seams will be of the lap type. We further include in our proposal, manhole, handhole, pressure gauge, water glass and flanges to receive piping.

The work will be in accordance with the requirements of the Canadian Fire Underwriters for hydro pneumatic pressure tanks.

We wish to thank you kindly for the opportunity to tender.

Yours very truly,

HORTON STEEL WORKS, LIMITED.

By: [Signature]
Contracting Engineer.

January 17th, 1931.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock. Report No.14.

The plasterers are now through with the exception of one man who is patching up, cleaning base etc. The cement floors and base are all finished, although we have one or two of the landings and stair treads to run yet.

The electrician has all the wires pulled, and a large number of the fixtures installed.

The R.A.Lister people have their men on the job putting the plant into shape, and we hope by next Saturday to be able to start up for a test.

The plumbers are installing the fixtures, and the steamfitters have the radiators all in place and are covering the boilers.

We have the upper floors cleaned out and left to the painters, who are putting on the last coat of varnish on top floor.

The contractors went to proceed with the laying of linoleum, but I have decided to wait ten days as there is still a lot of moisture in the building and the concrete floors may yet be somewhat damp although showing a fairly dry test.

We are proceeding with the septic tank forming, and expect to run concrete for this during the next week if weather is favourable.

I have the whole tank closed in and heated so that there will be no danger when once concrete is in place. The whole drainage system is complete, and earth filled in as far as the tank.

The new well has tested from 250 gals. to 400 gals. per hour for a run of forty-eight hours, and it is Mr. French's intention to recommend that this will be satisfactory seeing that the old well will also be connected up. You will no doubt have the report from the Dominion Water Power Dept., are this. So far as the pit for the pump goes I am having this run in as soon as the men are through with the septic tank, may I refer to my letter of the 13th inst., and ask that the pressure tanks be arranged for right away so that we may get it installed?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

Yours truly,

GENERAL CONTRACTORS

104-5 DONAHUE BLDG.
Regina, Sask.

Sheet #2.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.

The building is now substantially completed, as we stated previously, and is in the position where it should be taken over by the Department, and we are desirous that you take up with the proper authorities at Ottawa this question, and if possible arrange for the Mission or some Official of the Department to take over the building at the earliest possible date and provide for the heating and attendance necessary. We would like to point out that we have been doing a considerable amount of extra work during which period we have furnished the temporary heating and attendance, and we believe the Department should now take complete charge of the building and relieve us from further expense for heating, attendance, fire insurance and other overhead expenses.

We wrote the Deputy Superintendent General on January 3rd enclosing fire insurance policy No. 14081728 of The London, Liverpool and Globe Insurance Company covering for the sum of $110,000.00 on the above building; and we stated that this was the last policy which would be taken out by us. We did not get a reply to this letter, so we renewed this policy, but we would appreciate a statement from the Department that we can relieve ourselves of this expense.

Kindly give these matters your early attention and oblige.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.,
per

General Superintendent.

J/B.

Copy to Mr. William Swan.
R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re Lestock Indian School.

We have today handed to Mr. William Swan our estimate for the contract and our progress estimate for extra work. We have taken the liberty of referring to our contract estimate as the final estimate, and have shown certain holdbacks which we consider represent a fair estimate of odds and ends yet to be done.

The final cleaning up and grading may have to be held over until Spring, and the grading is somewhat involved in extra work where we have surplus earth from the connecting tunnel, from the pump house and from the pump pit. There will also be a certain amount of grading where the septic tank sewage work has been installed. The painting to finish is mostly on the exterior, which we did not think advisable to do until frost was off of the frames. The other two items are purely trivial matters to do with the electrical work and the plumbing.

The building is substantially complete, but we would prefer to do these small matters in the Spring, as we said before, and we now ask that you consider our application for the final estimate as presented with the exception of the holdbacks mentioned, and we would be prepared to leave on deposit the sum of $15,000.00 as well as the $853.00 held back as our guarantee that the work will be finally completed; and we think you will agree that the conditions would justify the payment to us of the $16,145.00 shown on our final estimate, together with our progress estimate #2 for labor and materials expended on extra work, and we would like to state that our progress estimate #2 for extra work is conservative; in fact it does not represent all the items to date, and we have only endeavoured to gather together the principal items of expenditure in order to be reimbursed for a portion of the monies we have expended.
William Swan,
ARCHITECT

Punnichy, Saskatchewan

CANADA
February 7th 1931.

The Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

Re. Muscowequan Indian School, Ledstock.

Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson, the contractors on the above work desire to finish up their contract and have a final certificate issued; although there is still quite a lot of work to do, such as finishing up Sewage Disposal, Pump and Power house, Water Supply, and work on Laundry etc., which was not included in the contract. They do not wish to continue to heat the building as soon as the painter is through with the inside work. I think that this is a fair request on their part and am preparing to issue them a final certificate as soon as the work called for by the original contract is completed as far as they can go.

The grading up outside, and the outside painting to some extent cannot be finished until Spring, but I can withhold enough, about eight hundred dollars, to cover this. I think that a week or ten days will see the contract work completed, but the water supply cannot be finished until the pressure tank, pumps etc., are on the job.

The contractors are not asking that their deposit be returned at this date, but that the building be taken over and the ten per cent holdback be paid.

I have a price from the contractors on the work required to be done to make part of the old basement into a laundry. This figure of $1,453.00 does not include for painting, steam heating, plumbing, or electrical work, nor the actual installing of the machinery. The machinery will be just the same as that at Gordon's School, except that Father Paulet would like to have an ironer included. Owing to the fact that the machinery will be some distance from the source of power I would advise that each unit is run separately and this do away with any overhead shafting etc.

I have had the contractors scrubbing the cement base for some days now, but the result is by no means good, and I feel that the only finished look will be obtained with two coats of paint. Two coats of paint on this base would cost 7¢ per lineal foot. It would improve the job considerably to have the cement floors above the basement also painted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., Report No. 16.

At this date the original contract is completed with the exception of a few days by the painters in finishing up inside, and the grading up, cleaning down a little of the brickwork, and some outside painting.

The Lister electric plant is now installed and in running condition, but until the various motors are installed it cannot be tested under full load.

The septic tank is completed; forming stripped, and earth back filled; all ready to operate as soon as water is available.

I have had no definite word as to when the tank, and water pumps etc., will be along, but I have the work on the pump pit well under way and trenches dug for supply pipes, so that no time will be wasted as soon as these items come to hand.

The connecting passage to the old building has not been actually put into use yet as we do not wish to disturb the room where we break through the wall until they are ready to move.

The linoleum is going down, and the blinds are hung.

The old bell and belfry have been installed on the roof of corridor to Chapel, and has now only to have a gal. iron covering to roof.

As soon as the painters are through with the inside work the contractors wish to be relieved of the heating of the building as this is not necessary for any of the extra work that they have to do in the pump house or well pit.

Up to date I have had no instructions as to the fixtures for the interior, prices for which were submitted to you on the 3rd inst.

Yours obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Feb. 26th 1931.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., Report No.17.

The building is now complete so far as the original contract goes. The sewage disposal system is also complete, and the lighting plant is complete.

The contractors have vacated the building today and the keys have been temporarily handed over to the Principal, Father Paulet, who is heating the building, and having floors scrubbed etc.

At present there is nothing more that can be done towards completing the school until we can get the pressure tank delivered. I have been in communication with the Dominion Bridge Co., at Calgary who have this in hand; and on the 21st. of February they wrote stating that they anticipated being able to ship within one or two weeks from that date. The delay being caused by new Saskatchewan regulations which require that such tanks be subject to tests by the Boiler Inspector.

Just as soon as the tank is delivered I will have the contractors back on the job and see that proper installation of it is made and that the plumbers connect it up with the pumps, which will be installed by the R.A. Lister Co., as arranged by the Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau.

I have had no instructions from you as to the laundry, but in any event nothing could be done on this until the required rooms in the old building can be vacated. At present we have not cut the doorway to connect the old building with the new, but are leaving this until the school can be moved over.

During the past two weeks we have had splendid weather and the outside painting has been practically completed.

I do not propose to make any more visits to the building until we can get the tank placed and water on.

I have not yet had any instructions from you as to the painting of the cement base or any of the cement floors. Even if it is the intention to leave some of the floors natural cement finish I believe that the base should be painted in order to give a more finished appearance to the building; particularly those rooms used as living and bedrooms.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
March 3, 1931.

Smith Bros. and Wilson,
Regina, Sask.

you may cancel insurance.

A. F. MacKenzie.

March 31st, 1931.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re. Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock, Sask. Report No.18.

Since my last report on Feb. 26th., the two Beatty pumps have been delivered and set up; one in the power house to pump from the old well and the large one in the pump pit over the new well. The pressure tank arrived at Lestock on March 19th from the Dominion Bridge Co. at Calgary. It is now safely installed and the plumbers are busy connecting it up. They expect to be able to turn the water on tomorrow although there may be some adjustments to be made to the pumps. Mr. French of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau has been on the job today.

Since receiving your telegram yesterday I have instructed the contractors that nothing more will be done for the present and that they can move their equipment away as soon as they have the few minor cleaning up items attended to.

I have had them put in the door between the old and new building, and I have had the plumbers run an outside line from the well to the old building, which will supply this with water during the summer months, but will of course be of no use in winter weather.

You will of course appreciate that there is at present no steam pipe connection, either for heating or for laundry purposes, from the new boilers to the old building. That no demolition of the old structure has been done other than the old chapel which was necessary before starting work last July.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Attention: F.H. Paget,
Chief Accountant.

Dear Sir:

RE: Your File 121-5-13 A.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, and we are returning herewith the invoices #3425, in triplicate.

Re $6.10 item, freight and cartage on casing used, to send from Lestock. We might mention that the freight and cartage is a proportionate charge against regular rates against material shipments for several wells, that is, we shipped enough material in each shipment, to take care of perhaps three or four wells, but we were asked to arrange freights so as each well would stand the amount of freight covering the material used in that well.

Re $4.00 item, paid to M.W. Bannister, re extra team, moving outfit. This money was paid direct to Mr. J.W. Webb, the Indian Agent and we are enclosing the original cancelled cheque for $4.00, together with a copy of our letter of January 28th, which was written to Mr. Webb when the $4.00 cheque was sent out.

We are also enclosing receipt, which was O.K.'ed by Mr. W. Swan, re board of $32.35, which was paid to Mrs. L. Lemay, at Lestock, Sask. Fortunately, our well driller Mr. Dempsey came into the office this afternoon, and we had an opportunity of asking him at what rate he was charged for this board. We are advised that the rate is $8.00 per week. On several occasions Mr. Dempsey did not have the noon meal at Mrs. Lemay's, while on two or three occasions, it was necessary for him to have a helper, and the helper took his meals at Mrs. Lemay's.

We trust therefore that this explanation will be quite satisfactory.

Ottawa, April 15, 1931.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing a statement covering the cost of goods which you supplied for the use of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask., during the period from October, 1930, to the end of February, last.

The settlement of this account is a matter which rests in the hands of the school authorities, and the Department is communicating with the Reverend Principal, with the request that he give the settlement of this account his early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Messrs. Burns & Co. Ltd.,
Prince Albert,
Sask.
Ottawa, April 15, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Burns & Co. Limited, Prince Albert, Sask., regarding an account to the amount of $202.21 for the supplying of goods from October last, to the end of February, for the use of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. This firm state that they have drawn this matter to your attention on various occasions, and would like to receive payment of the account. I enclose their statement, and would request that you give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. Poulet, O.M.I.,
Muscowequan Indian Residential School,
Lestock, Sask.
