ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Touchwood, Agency,
Punnichy, Sask.,
Jan. 8th, 1931.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to enclose reports on visits made to Day Star and Muscowequan Schools in December 1930.

The day I was at Muscowequan on inspection a fire was being kept up in the part of a large building used as store house and pig pen. Smoke was coming out of cracks all up the chimney where it had been split by lightning last summer. In order to avoid any chance of burning up the place I told the contractor of the new building to tear out the chimney and put in a new one which was required, it was not a very big job. We discussed trying to repair the old flue but could not see how it could be done at less expense than a new chimney as it was of stone and cement construction badly split and cracked.

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. J. W. Waddy,
Indian Agent.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Office of the Indian Commissioner, Indian Agency,

The Secretary,

Ottawa.

Form No. 101
Dear Sir;-

I have the honor to ask if the Department has under consideration the matter of removal of the old part of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I think this would on Mr. Orr's file.

Just now of course I understand that all construction and expenditures are at a standstill but the Principal is asking about the removal of the old part of the building and I would be obliged if I can be informed what to do in the matter.

The Principal is also asking when he can expect the beds to accommodate the new pupils, he requires them at once.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I enclose herewith Vouchers Nos. 50, amounting to $63.00 in favour of W. Swan Esq., Punnichy, Sask., for services as Inspector of Construction at Muscowequan School.

per ex 1047
June 11/31
May 2nd, 1931.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock. Report No.18.

The contractors have now moved all their equipment away, and the school is in the hands of the Principal, Father Faulet, who is at present carrying on with the furnishings from the old school.

The water supply plant has now been running for three weeks and appears to be satisfactory. The Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau will be giving you their detailed report on this.

The lighting plant and cold storage plant are also running satisfactorily.

The whole building is now O.K., except for some little trouble we are having with parts of the concrete floor in basement. This we have under observation for a short time and I am meeting Mr. Smith and their engineer on the job within a few days now to finally decide what to do.

Enclosed with this you will find the final certificate for payment covering all extra work done on the Sewage Disposal system, the Corridor from new to old building, the Electric Plant house, and the Pump pit. As this was all done on a cost plus 10% basis I have carefully checked all invoices as well as time sheets, and have finally got the figures down to what I consider fair and reasonable. The revised copies of this final statement are enclosed with this.

Most of the items on this list have been the subjects of letters and telegrams from you, and have been discussed with Mr. Gurney Orr during his visit of inspection.

Should there be any items that are not clearly shown or upon which you require fuller explanation I shall be pleased to go into same in detail.

May I ask that in making payment on this final certificate you either retain $800.00, or retain the deposit cheque until the contractors have finally satisfied us with regard to the basement floors.

The guarantee of the building for twelve months as required by the specification is enclosed herewith.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
May 6, 1931.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to the Muscowequan School, I would ask you to please advise me what you consider absolutely necessary at the present time in the way of demolishing the old building and connecting up of the portion which it is intended to use with the new building. I may say that there are very limited funds available at the present time and only that portion of the work that cannot be left over for another year should be given consideration.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
SECRETARY.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

Sir,-

I am also attaching a copy or a memorandum submitted by Mr. M.H. French, explaining the various accounts. From this memorandum it will be noted that these accounts, with the exception of the Alex. Dear Sir:

In reference to removal of old buildings at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School I offer to do the following work.

Demolish stone building 30' x 50', two stories and basement.
Demolish connecting building 20' x 18', two stories.
Demolish pantry and wood shed 12' x 20'.
Fill up old basement and grade off ground to proper level.
Close up all openings in side of building left standing.
Supply all material necessary to side up building left standing, this to include all lumber, paint, hardware necessary.
Remove all pipe, furnaces, wiring and other material in above buildings.
Remove the stairs in connecting building.
That I will make a complete job of all necessary removals of buildings on site under consideration whether mentioned in this list or not, and leave the ground in good shape so no further expense to the Department will be necessary.
Any material worth salvaging will be stored.

For the above I agree to accept... $100

Signed.

Accepted for the Department.

May 18th 1931.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your letter 121-5-5 of May 6th and your telegram of May 16th regards demolishing old buildings at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School I beg to say that this work is being done now by the Principal for the sum of $500.00.

Enclosed please find the original estimate for this work submitted by the contractors Smith Bros. & Wilson for $2,300.00, and the new estimate submitted by the Principal. I have included much more in the new estimate and made it inclusive of all removals and repairs to buildings made necessary by such removals. I trust the Department will find it satisfactory, I know the work will be well done and that the price is much lower than could be done by any other person.

Your obedient servant,

Muscowequan Indian Residential School
Lestock Sask. July 4, 1931.

Dear Sir:

You will pardon me if I once more appeal to your Department for additional expenditures - It is altogether impossible to operate this institution under the present conditions.

1st. A root cellar is one thing absolutely necessary - We had the root cellar under the old Church which was completely demolished and no provision was made in the new school in that connection - You will therefore understand that the preserving of roots and vegetables in an institution of this nature is a most necessary and most urging need. Something must be done before October in this regard.

2ndly, All institutions of this size and importance must be supplied with machineries to take care of the Laundry Work - Surely, the Department cannot expect us to keep up with the old system of washboards and tubs - Therefore, I look upon you for immediate action in this connection and I trust in your ability to have these two requisitions approved and the work started on immediately.

Thanking you most cordially in anticipation of a favourable answer.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;-

I have the honor to report that the Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School has asked if the Department can obtain him an allowance to put in a root cellar at the new school.

His idea is to have one dug and constructed right under part of the old building which was left standing, it would be 15 x 30 by eight feet deep. The cost of such a place, including labor and material would be about $350.00. I know you are held up for funds and have held off asking for any improvements myself, but this place is urgently required.

The Principal is also asking that the laundry projected last winter be gone ahead with, he is getting on just now with a lot of old laundry equipment in a small place he formerly used. He states that all the data for the new equipment is in Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

July 29th, 1931

W.M.Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir: Re - Fire at Muscowequan School

I beg to report that at 7 a.m. today a fire started in the old laundry building at the above school and before it was finished the laundry building, garage, and the frame part of old school were completely destroyed. Mr. F.Doll of the staff was starting a fire under the boiler in the laundry when a gas explosion started the trouble, the gas must have escaped from a small tank on the gas engine used to operate the machinery in the building, no gasoline is stored anywhere close to this place.

The laundry building contained the laundry, bakery, shoe shop, tool shed and ice house, it was two stories, 16 x 50 frame building. The water system with hose connections was put into operation at once, but the fire spread with the wind to the garage close by, a frame building one story 12 x 18 and from there to the three story frame part of the old school and this building 42 x 52 was also burnt.

We have lost all laundry equipment which included three boilers, laundry tubs, washing machines, drier; two bake ovens, bread mixer, baking pans, and equipment were burnt in the bakery. Shoe and clothes repair outfits were also burnt with stock on hand for repairs; the soft water tank and clothes drier are gone, also garden tools and other tools which were in the tool shed. Mr. Doll lived in the old school with his family, and their furniture was saved but a lot of school clothes and sport equipment are burnt. We also lost 1000 ft. of lumber and 40 sax of cement just purchased to fix up a root cellar as well as all the salvaged material saved when part of the old school was pulled down some time ago.

The new school is safe, except that the passage built to connect it with the frame part needs new plaster inside, new doors, window glass and repairs to the roof; the so called fire proof door was the first part of this place to burn out. The rest of the school is not even smoked up. A lot of school equipment is no doubt burnt, it will not be missed until it is needed, just now there is no list of it.

Just now the following should be supplied:

1 dough mixer, with electric motor, two sax capacity, 1 bake oven to hold dough from 2 sax of flour, pans for bread making for above. The bake shop is in the new building size about 12 x 13.

We have a high pressure tank in the boiler room for used laundry, but require a building and full equipment of laundry machinery, there is no space in the new school for a laundry.

Mr. Doll will require a dwelling of some sort; there is no house here for the farming instructor. I placed an item in the estimates for one but have not heard if the item passed.

Mr. Doll broke out of the building with all his clothes in flames, and with patches of skin and flesh burnt off. When in this state he went to the engine room and started up the pumps, attached the hose and got the fire fighting equipment in shape. He is in pretty bad shape but the doctor says not dangerously injured. The wiring connecting the school with the barns and outbuildings is burnt up and will have to be replaced.

(Sgd.) J.W.Waddy
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a report that I requested Mr. Waddy to make in connection with the recent fire which destroyed the laundry building, garage and other small buildings at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

The Department will decide what is to be done with regard to this matter. No doubt laundry equipment will have to be supplied, but I do not know whether the Department will be prepared to go ahead and erect a new laundry building this year or not.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

FIRE DESTROYS INDIAN SCHOOL NEAR LESTOCK

Damage Amounting to $25,000 Done Following Gasoline Explosion

Damage of $25,000 was done to an annex of the newly built Indian school near Lestock Wednesday morning when fire broke out after a gasoline explosion, it was learned here today from Mr. Smith, commissioner of the department of Indian affairs.

The information was to the effect that the annex had been badly destroyed by the main building, completed this year, was not damaged. The only student attending the school, one Dichi, was said to be badly burned and taken away from the fire. No Indian children were injured as they were all away on their holidays.

The annex was in the process of construction and contained the laundry, garage and like rooms. The explosion appeared to have started in the laundry when some gasoline used for cleaning exploded.

August 4th, 1934

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 27th ultimo with reference to the amount you mention as shortage, namely $48.00, I beg to say that it was found on checking your accounts there were 5 days charged for over and above the number of days in the month. This was accounted for by your inspection trip to Birtle, and if you will look over your files you will find that you charged for a day at Birtle and at the same time you charged for a day at the Gordon's School. The Civil Service Commission made the appointment at the rate of $6.00 per day, and of course it is impossible to pay for more days than there are in the calendar month.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;-

In reference to your letter #121-5-5 of July 16th last regards construction of a root cellar at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, stating that an appropriation of up to $300.00 would be granted for this purpose, I beg to say that we figured this would be suitable, and we started work, got the cellar excavated etc and then the place above the cellar was burnt down filling the pit up with debris and destroying the walls which existed.

I inspected the place today and figure that it will take $500.00 to complete it altogether including work done before the fire. I told the principal that I could not exceed your appropriation but he says he has to get the place constructed to accommodate this year's crop. The fire destroyed his work and made it necessary that we construct a roof on the place we had in mind, as formerly the building above it was to be the roof.

Under the circumstance I would be obliged if you would consider increasing the grant, if so kindly wire me.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 22, 1931

J. W. WADDY,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

REFERENCE YOUR LETTER SEVENTEENTH RE ROOT
CELLAR MUSCOUEQUAN SCHOOL AS FUNDS ARE VERY LOW
DEPARTMENT WISHES TO LEARN IF SOME OTHER ARRANGEMENTS
COULD NOT BE MADE FOR HOUSING THIS YEARS CROP.

A. F. MacKENZIE.

Chg. Dept.
I. A.
Dear Sir:

In reference to your telegram of the 22nd inst. regarding appropriation for the root cellar on the Muscowequan Residential School property, I beg to say that on receipt of your telegram I notified the principal of the request of the Department that the expense be kept down as nothing more than the original appropriation was allowed and asked him if he could arrange to store the crop in any other manner. There is no other place to store his root crop except the cellar under construction.

The principal said he would go ahead and complete the place.

To-day I went to the school and the principal told me he intended to construct a cottage on top of the cement root cellar, using the root cellar as his foundation; the cottage to be for the use of his farming instructor. He intends to ask the Department later on for refund of this expense.

My idea of writing this letter is to advise the Department as to what is going on and to point out that I have authorised nothing more than the $300.00 expense as you allowed in the first place.

There is no doubt that a cottage for the farming instructor is required at this school, however, that has not been granted as far as I know.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to enclose vouchers #317 and 318 as follows.

Vchr 317-"$122.65 in favor of Rev J. Poulet.
" 318 $388.25 " " " Reliance L. Co., Lestock.

In reference to the above expenditure I refer to your letter #121-5-5 of the 16th July last authorising $300.00 for the construction of a root cellar at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. On receipt of your letter I took the matter up with the Principal and he said he would put up the place complete, and from figures compiled at that time the price would have been less than the $300.00 noted. However, the fire occurred here and destroyed the work done when it was partly completed. The Department was advised about this but did not allow any increase in the grant for the work. I kept the principal advised that funds were not increased but he stated that the work would have to be completed to save his crop.

In my letter #11A R.O. of the 31st ultimo, to you, I reported on progress of the work here. The building I mentioned is built on the root cellar and the principal states that no part of the dwelling is included in these vouchers except the roof which would have been put on in any case.

I am well aware of the difficulty the Department has in obtaining funds just now, but if there is any way of paying these vouchers I beg to recommend that they be settled.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir;

Re: Muscowequan Indian School, Lestock.

I now wish to make a final report on the concrete floors of the above, and certify that the contractors are now entitled to the balance of the final certificate issued on Feb. 14th last i.e., $800.00 which amount was held back at my suggestion until I was satisfied that the cement floors of the basement were going to stand up.

During the past six months or eight months I have had Mr. Smith and Mr. Johns of Smith Bros. & Wilson Ltd., over the job with me on two occasions and I have made periodical visits to satisfy myself that these floors are now going to be O.K. The chief trouble seemed to be a rather unusual amount of dust from them, but some three months ago I got the contractors to agree to treat the surface with a special oil put up by the Shell Oil Co. for just such conditions as this, and on looking over the floors a few days ago I am quite satisfied that the trouble had been stopped.

Generally speaking I believe the contractors think that I have been a little too hard on them in the matter of these floors as they have spent two hundred dollars for oil, and of course we did hold up the placing of these floors pending the decision from your office on the substitution of mastic flooring as requested by Father Paulet. Now that the thing is settled to both Father Paulet's and my satisfaction I may say that Messrs. Smith Bros & Wilson have gone to a lot of trouble to give the Department a good job on the whole school.

In case you require to have the payment of this $800.00 covered by a certificate in the usual form I enclose copy of such in duplicate.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Your file No. 4882
Pump at Muscowequan School.

We are advised by the Beatty Company that a three inch cylinder will deliver 340 gallons without difficulty. We could supply this and install the larger casing which will permit the cylinder to be withdrawn, for the sum of

ONE HUNDRED AND FIVE DOLLARS .................. $105.

We are not figuring a profit on this, as we are anxious to have the pump give every satisfaction. In addition, we will give you a credit note for any amount allowed us by the Beatty Company, when the old cylinder and casing are returned.

With regard to the thrust of the pump, we quote from their letter as follows:

"Regarding the end thrust on the present Pump, in this head one of the gears is cut right hand, and the other is cut left hand. This means when the head is in operation there is no end thrust on the worm providing the worm is floating in the exact correct position. On the electric driven unit the position of the motor holds the worm shaft in this correct position thus eliminating any necessity for end adjustment on the worm."

They seem to think that someone at the school is unduly nervous about the thrust, but will have their man call and report on the pump again this month.

Yours very truly,

R.A. LISTER & CO (CANADA) LTD.
Ottawa, Ont., December 9, 1931.

Sir:

Re: Muscowequan School,
Lestock, Saskatchewan.

With reference to the pumping equipment for the new deep well at the Muscowequan School at Lestock, Saskatchewan, we have recently had some correspondence with the Commissioner of Irrigation at Calgary.

It appears that the R. A. Lister Company of Winnipeg installed a 2½ inch pipe with a 2¼ inch cylinder. It seems that an error was made, presumably by the agent of the Beatty Pump Company at Winnipeg, in supplying a 2¼ inch cylinder in place of a 3 inch cylinder originally specified by the Commissioner. It has been found, however, that the 2½ inch pipe is not satisfactory, and will require to be replaced by a 3 inch pipe and at the same time the 2¼ inch cylinder must be replaced by a 3 inch cylinder.

The Commissioner of Irrigation took up this matter with the R. A. Lister Company, and they offer to install a cylinder of the proper size and a 3 inch pipe for $105. Copy of this offer, dated September 21st is enclosed. They also offer to allow credit for any amount allowed them by the Beatty Company when the old cylinder and casing are returned.

It now appears that Father Poulet has purchased a 3 inch pipe and the R. A. Lister Company now offer, if this turns out to be the case and the pipe is suitable, to deduct the value of it from their invoice in charging for the work.

It is therefore recommended that authority be given to have the R. A. Lister Company install the larger cylinder and the 3 inch pipe for their offer of $105, less credit for the smaller cylinder to be returned to the Beatty Company, and less the cost of the 3 inch pipe, if this has already been obtained by Father Poulet.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Muscowequan Boarding School R.C. 23rd Decm 1931

The class-room work is carried on in three class-rooms all supervised by Sisters. There are 36 boys in one room and the grades range from Grade 2 to Grade 7. In the girls room there are 34 pupils graded from Grade 2 to Grade 6. In the primary room there are 28 pupils enrolled and all are beginners.

The pupils were all neatly dressed, clean and tidy in appearance. These pupils all speak out well, are good readers. In the exercise books I found the work neatly set down and the work well done. I would judge progress is being made in all the class rooms.

The building throughout was clean. The dormitories were all -
mitories were all well aired and the beds neatly made. Gowns and pyjamas are supplied for each child.

The laundry, sewing-room, and kitchen are each in charge of a sister. The children appear to enjoy their work and are happy. The girls learn to cook, bake bread, and do all kinds of sewing and washing. They also are taught to milk and do gardening.

The fire escapes are all in good condition, as is all fire equipment. The dormitory doors and fire escape doors are never locked. The fire escape doors open from one of the Sister's rooms so that no one can pass out unknown. Fire drill is observed regularly and the children get out in from two to three minutes.

The laundry work is carried on in an outside building and only a power washing machine is supplied in the line of machinery. The washing necessary for the staff and over one hundred children entails a lot of work especially with such poor equipment. The drying of the clothes is a difficult task during the cold winter weather and would be made much better if an extractor and drying tumbler could be provided.

The new root cellar appears quite satisfactory. Above the cellar a building has been erected as a house for the engineer. This is well built and makes a comfortable home.

The meals served are well cooked and the children receive all they want. The general menu is as follows:

**Breakfast**
- Rolled oats, prunes, baked apples or syrup - bread and butter - omelettes or cold meat for the working boys
- tea or cocoa or milk

**Dinner**
- Soup - beef stew or pork roast - vegetables, bread, butter, tea or milk pudding or fruit as convenient

**Supper**
- Hash meat, potatoes, beans, omelettes, or cold meat, bread and lard, tea or milk

Every Friday is fish day - eggs, canned salmon or fresh fish.
Fresh fish as convenient.

Weak or sick children receive a glass of milk or egg-nog as 10 a.m. also 3 p.m.

I found no sick children and they all looked well and appeared to enjoy their meals.

A large herd of cattle is kept and a good supply of milk is available at all times.

The outbuildings are all in good repair except the granary, and this is past repairing. There is no foundation and the floor and sills have rotted. The place is overrun with rats and a new granary is badly needed.

This school is well managed and the Reverend Father Poulet is ably assisted by four men and a staff of Sisters. The children are well fed and clothed and appear in good health.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Regina, Sask., Jan. 4th, 1932.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report received from Mr. Inspector Hamilton on the various schools in the Touchwood agency.

Muscowequan Residential School

The work here seems to be carried on in a satisfactory manner. They are no doubt handicapped by not having a properly equipped laundry.

You will note that the doors leading to the fire escapes here are never locked.

I understand that the Principal of this school, Father Poulet, has been transferred. This is unfortunate, as from reports I have received, the new Principal who has been appointed, Father Bousquet, is not in the same class as Father Poulet.

The two day schools appear to be carrying on in the usual way.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham.

Sir:

I beg to forward and recommend for payment Regina Voucher No. 32 in favor of the Electric Equipment Limited, covering the rewinding of a 2 H.P. motor pump in use at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

I received a telephone message that the pump was out of order and a requisition for a new one. I directed that the pump should be forwarded here for overhauling, and, being placed in the hands of the Electric Equipment Limited, it was found that all that was needed was rewinding and the installation of new bearings. Sir:

I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of a request from the Principal of the Muscowequan School to purchase a starter for the 2 H. P. 110 Volt Motor which was supplied by the Department for the Deep Well Pumping System at the school.

I have taken this matter up with the R. A. Lister Company, and they have this to say:

"By installing the larger cylinder this of course increased the starting load of this motor; therefore when starting this motor without the use of a proper starter the safety fuses protecting the motor have got to be of a heavy enough amperage to take care of the starting current which runs approximately three times the running amperage of the motor. Therefore, with these heavy fuses in you have no protection on your motor if a short should develop in the motor or trouble arise in the equipment."

It seems to me the Department should authorize the purchase of this starter. The cost, I would think, would be approximately $50.00.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:-

With reference to Department No. 121-5-15 of the 26th ultimo, concerning the alleged overpayment of $75.94 to R. A. Lister and Company (Canada) Limited, I have to state that, while this amount appears to be incorporated in an account presented by them for $1,819.02 and again submitted later and therefore duplicated, the Company claims that it is entitled to payment of a further sum of $601.19 covering charges in connection with the installation of the pumping plant at the Muscowequan School. The larger account of $1,819.02 appears to have been certified to and sent in by Mr. Swan, Superintendent of Construction, while the lesser, $601.19, was submitted to Mr. Tempest the Representative of the Department of Irrigation who should have certified to it and sent it on to Ottawa. I do not know whether the latter account reached the Department, but if it did and payment has not yet been made to the Company a deduction from it of $75.94 can be made and this will adjust the Department's account with R. A. Lister and Company (Canada) Limited.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir,

Payment to R.A. Lister & Co., Ltd.

J.S.Tempest,Esq.,

Dear Sir,-

The work carried on by the Employees of the R.A. Lister Co., re-installation of 3" Cylinder and Casings on deep well has proven satisfactory so far - I have no objection to O.K. the bill in this connection - if by so doing I save expenditures to the Department.

Principal.
ANNOUNCEMENT

MOMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED,

have acquired the interests of

Messrs. R. A. Lister & Company (Canada) Ltd.

in Northwestern Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta

HEAD OFFICE: WINNIPEG

PORTAGE AND WALL STS. TELEPHONES: 37 187, 37 188 and 34 920

Branches and Warehouses: REGINA and EDMONTON

Stocks of RUSTON & HORNSBY and LISTER Gasoline, Crude Oil and Diesel Engines, and Repair Parts will be kept at all three points.
Sir:

In further reference to your letter of December 14th in which you authorized the installation of a larger sized pipe with 3" cylinder and casings for the pumping equipment at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School near Lestock, we are now advised by the Commissioner of Irrigation that this work has been satisfactorily completed and there is now enclosed in duplicate the account of the R. A. Lister and Company (Canada) Limited, for $105.00, being the amount of the previous estimate. This has been certified correct by the Commissioner.

It will be noted that the payment is to be made to Mumford, Medland, Limited, of Regina, Saskatchewan, which according to an announcement enclosed have acquired the interests of R. A. Lister and Company, Limited, in the western provinces.

Regarding the credit for the casing which was to be allowed, the R. A. Lister Company have written to the Commissioner as follows:

"In our quotation to you (in a letter dated November 30th 1931) we advised that we would allow credit for the casing bought by Father Poulet, but as he had not settled with the Ashdown Company for it, we are making payment direct to him, and this will not confuse your records".

Following this the Commissioner wrote to Father Poulet requesting a certificate as to the workmanship and efficiency of the installation. A copy of Father Poulet's reply is attached.

It would, therefore, appear in order for the Indian Department to make payment of the $105.00 to Mumford, Medland, Limited, at Regina, Saskatchewan.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Per

Encs.

T. R. L. MacInnes, Esq.,
Acting Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Wall Street,
Winnipeg, Man.
March 9th 1932.

J.S. Tempest, Esq.,
Commissioner of Irrigation,
Department of the Interior,
Calgary, Alta.

Dear Sir,

We have spent considerable time on the account for the pumps at Muscowequan School, and are now in a position to reply more fully to your letter of February 23rd.

The copies of correspondence that you sent us were a very great help, as they were not in our Regina files.

In the detailed original account there are more than a hundred and fifty items, running from ten cents up, and it has been almost impossible to follow Mr. Doupe's trail.

On our original account for $2,420.21, Mr. Swan wrote, "O.K., as to item of $1,800.00 for transfer, repairs, and installation of lighting plant." This was Regina office estimate before the work was done, and not a guaranteed amount. Later, the account was subdivided and we attach, as requested, four copies of the lighting plant account for $1,519.02, which has been passed and paid. We are also enclosing four copies of the account covering the pump, amounting to $601.19. There was an error of $1.00 in adding up the amount of out of pocket expenses for freight, wages, expenses, etc., but we are reducing your account by $1.00 to arrive at the original amount of $2,420.21.

We are also enclosing full details of the expense account of W.J. Montgomery and G. Kettering, as well as copies of the prepaid freight bills for $7.31 and $7.17.

Mr. Doupe apparently thought that Mr. Swan would only pass an account for the original estimate of $1,800.00 and therefore charged the additional amount to the pumpint equipment. Of all the small pipe fittings that were bought, some of them must have been used in connection with the pumps, but it is impossible to make a sharp dividing line, and it would now appear that they have been charged in to the lighting plant, as your account does not cover anything but the price of the pumps, the freight, labour and expenses.

We trust this will now put the account in shape for payment.

Yours very truly,

R.A. Lister & Co. (Canada) Ltd.,
G.T. Mumford.
COPY.

Wall Street,
Winnipeg, Feb.27,1932.

J.S.Tempest,Esq.,
Commissioner of Irrigation,
Calgary.

Dear Sir,-

Very many thanks for your letter of the 23rd inst. and the trouble you have taken to make this account clear.

The copies of documents that you sent us were not in our Regina files, so that we could not understand clearly what had taken place. Mr. Deupe did many very strange things, and as it now turns out, we were unfairly critical of him as we did not realize that he must have been a very sick man.

It will take a little time to get the detailed information you require, but we will do so at the earliest possible moment.

The account for $105.00 covering the Cylinder and Pipe installed at Lestock was in the name of Mumford, Medland, Limited, and we have received payment for it.

Yours very truly,

R.A.Lister & Co.(Canada) Ltd.,
(signed) G.T.Mumford.
February 23, 1932.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the payment of a balance of $601.19 on the installation of a lighting plant, battery and pumping equipment for the Muscowequan School at Lestock, Sask.

In order to make the matter clear to you to the extent of my own knowledge, I will recapitulate all correspondence dealing with the proceedings.

I received a letter from your Regina office dated April 28, 1932, and signed by S.A. Doupe, a copy of which is enclosed. This letter was accompanied by an invoice, a copy of which is also enclosed. This was not added but the total amounted to $602.19. The letter was also accompanied by another invoice which, if I remember correctly, contained this sum and also one for $1800 for transfer and overhaul of Lighting Plant.

I returned this latter invoice to you on May 15 together with a letter, a copy of which is enclosed and which is self-explanatory.

You will note the condition of the first invoice. Items Nos. 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9 total $157.55. Apparently, according to the statement which was returned, the total was $175.57, a difference of $18.02. This is the reason for my reduction from $2420.21 to $2402.19. Items 1 and 3 remain unchanged. Thus $1800 plus $249.94 plus $194.70 plus $157.55 total to $2402.19.

You will also note that paragraph (6) of my letter of May 15 contained directions for supplying details of Items 5 and 6, viz: that these items should be further itemized and at unit prices, similarly to 7, 8 and 9.

I received an answer from Mr. Doupe, dated May 20, 1931, in which occurred the following paragraph: "With regard to the itemizing of the mechanics' expenses and time, we are having this prepared and will have it forwarded to you in the course of a day or two. As per your suggestion, we are having the two accounts separated."

Apparently Mr. Doupe lost sight of this portion of the negotiations in arranging for the replacement of the cylinder, as he never received the invoice for $602.19 with corrections although Mr. Swan seems to have been invoiced for the lighting plant.

Re A. Lister & Co. (Canada) Limited,
Wall Street,
Winnipeg, Man.
Paragraph '2' of my letter stated that several omissions and defects should be rectified before payment was made. This, together with the apparently incorrect invoice, explains the reason for delay. The cylinder has now been replaced and I have notified the Director to that effect.

As mentioned in your letter of the 13th instant you invoiced us for $2420.21. I reduced this to $2402.19 as hereinbefore explained. You state that Mr. Swan "O.K."d" the lighting account for $1819.02, and caused it to be paid. It appears that the $1800.00 account was changed to $1819.02. The $602.19 has apparently been changed to $601.19. The total has now increased to $2421.21 instead of $2420.21 if the original $602.19 be considered.

In order to clear up the question will you kindly prepare the following documents:

1. Four copies of the receipted bill for the Lighting Plant as signed by Mr. Swan, for filing purposes.

2. Four copies of an original invoice to our office for the $601.19 or $602.19, as the case may be, itemized as mentioned above, to be checked and sent to Ottawa.

Would you kindly inform me of the reason for the apparent change from $1800 to $1819.02; and why the items 2, 4, etc., were apparently totalled to $175.57 instead of $157.55? The differences are $19.02 and $18.02 respectively.

It has occurred to me that the reason for your ignorance of conditions is due to the letters being in your Regina office. I note that your letter is signed "R.A. Lister & Co per G.T. Mumford". I was under the impression from a letter I received from Regina on the 26th ultimo, that Mumford, Medland, Limited, had taken over the business and that the payment of $105 for the cylinder and pipe installation was to be made payable to them. Who receives payment for this account?

Your obedient servant,

(signed) J.S. Tempest.

Commissioner of Irrigation.
COPY.

R.A. Lister & Company (Canada) Limited,
Wall Street,
Winnipeg, Man.,
February 13th, 1932.

J.S. Tempest, Esq.,
Commissioner of Irrigation,
Calgary, Alta.

Dear Sir,

On April 10th last we invoiced the Department with $2,420.21, covering the installation of a lighting plant, battery, and pumping equipment for the Muscowequan Indian School.

At the request of Mr. Swan, our Regina manager, afterwards divided this amount into two invoices, one for $1,819.02, which has been passed by Mr. Swan and paid by the Department, and the other we presume must have been for $601.19, covering the balance of the account, which would normally be passed by you. However, we cannot find copies of this as it was done by Mr. Doupe a short time previous to his death, and we are now trying to find out how we are to be paid for the balance of $601.19.

Was this matter taken up with you by our Regina office and can you help us get the matter straightened out?

Yours very truly,

R.A. Lister & Co. (Canada) Ltd.,
sd. G.T. Mumford.
Wall Street,
Winnipeg, Man.

June 15, 1932.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Rev. Father Poulet, O.M.I., late of the Muscovequan Indian Residential School, visited the Department today and he represents that they are in danger of losing their farm instructor - a very valuable employee - if a residence is not provided for him without delay. The school authorities, without help from the Department, have erected a cottage for the engineer and are willing, in view of the cut in the Appropriation, to be responsible for all labour costs for a farmer's cottage, if the Department will make a grant (Miscellaneous and Unforeseen Item, $6167) of $800 for materials.

I have made arrangements to have Father Poulet meet the Honourable the Superintendent General and will get his concurrence, if possible.
June 16, 1932.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

The Department wishes to purchase approximately $600 worth of lumber for a farm instructor's cottage at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask., in the federal district of Last Mountain. The nearest lumber yards are those of the Reliance Lumber Company, Lestock, which was strongly recommended by Mr. F. R. MacMillan, M. P., some months ago, and the North American Lumber Company, Punishby, which is on the list to receive consideration. Will it be satisfactory if the Department secures prices from these firms?

Small quantities of cement and building hardware will also be required, and the Indian Agent will be instructed to get prices from those on the list.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
June 16, 1932.

Memorandum:

P., some months ago, and the North American Lumber Company, Punnichy, which is on the list to receive consideration. Will it be satisfactory if the Department secures prices from these firms?

Small quantities of cement and building hardware will also be required, and the Indian Agent will be instructed to get prices from those on the list.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, July 21, 1932.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Reverend Father Poulet, O.M.I., past Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, has visited the Department and has requested permission to erect a farm instructor's cottage. He has agreed that the school management would provide all the labour, if the Department will grant $800 for materials. The Superintendent General has approved of the scheme and has directed that quotations on the lumber be secured from the Reliance Lumber Company, of Leestock, and the North American Lumber Company, of Punnichy. Father Poulet or the Principal will give you the bill of materials that are required. Cement and building hardware may be purchased from indicated sources. Please see that the expenditure does not exceed $800, and, in due course, when the materials have been supplied, forward a properly certified account, in triplicate. A copy of this letter is being handed to Father Poulet.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

Dear Sir;-

In reference to your letter 121-5-5 of the 26th ultimo regards an account of General Steel Wares Ltd., I beg to say that the $1.51 item was for repairs to stove shipped to the Muscovequan School by the firm who supplied it, the principal says it was the T.Eaton Co., of Regina, Sask. From information I have been able to get it would appear that the principal at that time asked the firm to put the new stove in good repair and they sent on these goods. The $1.51 should therefore not be paid by the Department.

There is nothing on file here about the seventy-six cent item. I cannot recall any heater being purchased, but if the company gives details the transaction might be traced up.

Your obedient servant,

Fyle References Re: Theft of Gasoline (386) from Muscowequan Indian Reserve Residential School, Lestock P.O., Sask.

5 - 10 - 32

Headquarters On this date while making other investigations I interviewed both Norris and Fisher, as mentioned in P.C.R. of Sgt. Lane's, dated the 14th ultimo, in the above connection.

Division or Dist. Questioned as to their movements on or about the 25th August, they both stated that they could not remember as it was so far back, but whatever they were doing it had no connection with the above theft as they had at no time taken gasoline from the above named school, or in the vicinity of same.

Sub-Division I made enquiries at Mr. H. Stern, Lestock, as to any of these Fishers having purchased gas from him, and he stated that they sometimes bought the occasional two or three gallons but he could not remember when they had made their last purchase; but he was sure they had not bought any within the last two or three weeks.

Detachment I made further enquiries but nothing was to be gained, and owing to the lateness of the enquiry it is somewhat difficult for me to place the time and dates.

P.C.R. Nothing further has been mentioned by Mr. Jean in regard to his fence being broken, and therefore presumably no action is being taken in this regard.

Dear Sir:—

In reference to electric lighting installation to the out buildings at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the inspector of the Saskatchewan Power Commission checked over this system this month and condemned it. After I got his report I went to the school to see what he objects to. The equipment is the old stuff put in years ago and has served its time by all appearances, the insulation is off most of the wiring. There are long spans of wire between the buildings without any support. These sort of things go along for years and make no trouble but eventually destroy the property.

I have had estimates made of the cost of necessary expense of putting this place in good condition, it amounts to about $300.00, all correspondence is enclosed.

If the work is not done the light will have to be cut off and lanterns used, this is not good business, the boys might set the barns on fire with lanterns.

Will you please advise me what is to be done about this work; kindly return the papers I enclose.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 29, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, regarding the condition of the electric lighting installation in the outbuildings at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. It is noted that you enclose the report of the Inspector of the Saskatchewan Power Commission, regarding the matter, together with quotations which you received for the placing of the lighting equipment in good condition.

In reply I have to say that no appropriation was provided to cover this expense, and, as our funds for other school expenditures are extremely limited, the full amount we would be able to provide towards the cost of replacing the present equipment would be $150.

As it is considered quite necessary that this lighting equipment to the outbuildings be renewed as soon as possible, it is hoped that the Principal can provide the balance of the cost, from the per capita allowance or other school receipts. You should take this matter up with the Principal at once, and, if he consents to the paying of all costs in excess of the $150 which this Department will allow, you may arrange to have the work undertaken by a firm on the list to receive consideration who quote the lowest price for supplying the material and carrying out the work required. If the Principal is unable to pay the portion of the cost over and above the amount the Department can provide, the renewing of the equipment will have to stand over until next year.

After you have consulted the Principal, please advise the Department of the action taken. I return the correspondence which you forwarded, as requested. If the work is proceeded with, you should, when forwarding the voucher, in triplicate, for the amount of the expense that will be paid by the Department, attach thereto the report of the Inspector of the Saskatchewan Power Commission, together with the quotations received.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your letter 121-5-5 of November 29th last regards electric lighting equipment for the outbuildings at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I beg to say that I have been working on this subject and find that we can get the principal buildings equipped for the sum of $150.00.

Sir:

General Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Dear Sir,

The following is a list of the requirements (for 1933-34) for the Indian Schools under our jurisdiction.

Muscowequan School

1- Installation of electric wiring in barn and granaries. The Inspector of the Province of Saskatchewan reported the present wiring as defective. The authorities of the School will furnish labor if the Department provides the materials.

2- An air compressor for water pump Curtis, Model B, No. 3, 3½ x 3. We understand that Aegidown's of Winnipeg are the agents for this make of pump. We consider this improvement very necessary. On four different occasions last winter, we had to haul water for the needs of the School. As the nearest supply is one mile away, considerable inconvenience is experienced every time the water system of the School goes out of order.

3- Dormitories, recreation halls and dining room need to be painted and varnished. The School will provide labor if the Department will supply the paint and varnish.

4- We are told that linseed oil hardens cement floors. We would like the Department to supply one barrel of good quality oil so that the floors of the School may be treated.

5- There is no extractor for the laundry. As this is considered a very necessary piece of laundry machinery, we ask the Department to supply one.

The School is still without a laundry house, but in view of the present depression the School authorities will continue to use the present temporary building.

(Sgd.) J. C. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot St.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sir:

I enclose herewith Regina Voucher No. 469, amounting to $33.35, in favor of McPherson and Thom Company for board of their well driller from December 8th, 1930, to January 17th, 1931, while drilling a well at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

This well was drilled on Department authority by telegram dated August 22nd, 1930, sent to Mr. William Swan, of Punnichy, Sask. The agreement for the actual drilling was made between Mr. Graham, then Indian Commissioner, and McPherson and Thom by personal interview and I have no record on file here of the actual arrangement entered into. Mr. Swan understood that Mr. Graham arranged that the driller would be boarded at the school, but apparently this arrangement was not carried out. I am submitting the account for consideration by the Department, as I am satisfied that the amount has not been refunded to McPherson and Thom.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,

SASKATCHEWAN POWER COMMISSION

SERVICE CONNECTION PERMIT (Conditional)
(Electrical Licensing Act, 1929)

To: Lestock Indian School,
Lestock, Sask.

The service installation of Granary and barn at Lestock installed before October 1st, 1928 was inspected on the 28th day of October, 1932, and does not conform to the requirements of the Canadian Electrical Code and The Electrical Licensing Act, 1929, in the following respects:

Line between school and granary is #12 W.P. wire partly bare, (approx. 175 feet) Line between granary and barn is #12 W.P. wire (approx. 1200 feet). Line to barn runs through granary. Fuses for barn are under eaves outside, about 15 feet above ground. Interior wiring has been knocked loose and broken in spots. No switch bases. Hay loft light is a brass socket attached to ends of circuit wires which are twisted together and hang on timbers. Joints are badly corroded.

The installation is approved on condition that the following changes are made:

Wires to be repaired, properly supported and insulated. Joints to be soldered and taped. Hay loft light to be rewired. It is very desirable that conduits services be installed and grounded.

and provided also that the insulation resistance is maintained in accordance with the present standard and the load is not increased. All future changes and alterations shall conform to the Code requirements.

DATED at Regina, this 3rd day of Nov., 1932.

Chief Inspector, Saskatchewan Power Commission.
Lestock, Sask.
Dec 22nd 1932.

J.W. Waddy, Esq
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

Build connecting line from engine in main building to the large barn and from there to the pig pen.
Equip the lighting of both barn and pig pen to satisfaction of yourself and the Principal of the school.

All the above complete for the sum of $150.00

Form No. 101
Dear Sir:

I beg to report that the air is not being supplied in sufficient quantities to force the water in the Muscowequan School, the air pump in the well wears out from the mud and sand that comes up in the pipe at times. They require an air compressor similar to the Curtis Model "B" size 3 air compressor in the J.H.Ashdown catalogue, with 2½" x 10'9" endless belt for use with pneumatic tank.

The Principal states that last fall he submitted to the Department a list of material he will require to keep the place in shape, oil, paint etc., he asks for this to be supplied.

Last year we asked for supply to this place of a reservoir for soft water under the laundry, there were no funds at the time for this job. The reservoir with a pump is needed. He also asks for an extension of the lighting system to the pig house, we have it complete to the barn.

The school is well kept and the grounds are being put in shape in front for a nice garden.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 19, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, regarding the supplying of an air compressor for use in connection with the water system at the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that our Estimates for the current fiscal year provide only $1,200 for the purchase of an extractor for the laundry at this school. If, however, the Principal and yourself consider that the supplying of the air compressor is more urgent than laundry equipment and also if other equipment or repairs are more urgent - the total cost of which should not exceed the above stated amount, I would request you advise the Department as soon as possible concerning what equipment, repairs, etc., the Principal and yourself would recommend be provided instead of the extractor for the laundry. When forwarding a recommendation, you should give full details as to cost involved. When we are advised as to the more urgent requirement, consideration will be given to authorizing the expenditure. In any event, the sum mentioned above is the full amount that will be available for this school during the present year.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Dear Sir;-

I have the honor to report that the cylinder in the pump at the Muscowequan School has worn out, sand comes up into the pipe and wears out the washers very often but now the cylinder itself has worn through.

The principal asks for the supply of one 3 inch cylinder for a deep well Beatty pump, it could be procured in Regina.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

- Air compressor for water pump, Curtis Model B No3, 22 X 3 in Ashdown catalogue page 1323: $50.00

June 12, 1935.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 10th ultimo, with reference to equipment and repairs for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I am enclosing herewith E.R. 638, which is your authority for the expenditure as shown.

With reference to the extractor prices will be obtained here, but before same can be given consideration it will be necessary for you to advise me the size of the extractor required, also whether it would not be more advisable to operate same by gasoline engine to save such a heavy drain on the School lighting plant.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Dear Sir;-

In reference to your letter 121-5-5 of the 12th June last authorising some expenditures for Muscowequan School I beg to say that the principal has informed me he requires a 26" power run extractor. I explained to him that you consider it might be advisable to use a gasoline engine for power but he does not agree to this and asks that the motor be supplied. He says he could purchase a machine for about $500.00 in Winnipeg.

I have been away on holiday or would have attended to this matter previously. On my visit to the school I find that the principal decided that the cement allowed, $150.00, will not be sufficient for his purposes, he wants the Department to change the E.R.#36 to make it read for purpose of buying two 5000 galvanized tanks. I told him he could not change anything without order from you. The two tanks would cost close to $200.00. If they will suit his purpose I would recommend that he be allowed the same as formerly viz $150.00 and let him pay the balance. However, the Department can let me know their pleasure in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Pursuant to our conversation on the subject of new residential school buildings to be erected during the coming fiscal year, I have pleasure in informing you that the plans and specifications for the following school buildings are now ready:

New Blue Quill Indian Residential School,
near St. Paul de Metis, Alberta.

New Muscowequan Indian Residential School,
near Lestock, Sask.

New Birtle Indian Residential School,
near Birtle, Man.

As I have stated, I do not think we can carry out our full programme without getting supplementary assistance. Perhaps you will think it proper to ask for tenders at an early date, but I think it would be advantageous to have some assurance of our Supplementary Vote before doing so.

We also have the plan ready for the addition to the Lady Willingdon Hospital on the Six Nations Reserve. As the funds for this building do not come out of the School Vote, I will ask for tenders at an early date.

[Signature]

Duncan C. Scott

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6319, file 657-5, part 3)

Lestock, Sask., June 3, 1930.

Very dear Sir,

After a careful study of the Plans and Specifications of our new School, now on hand, I deem it my duty to express you my sincere appreciation for the wonderful work done. I am certainly more than pleased with the favour granted and may it please God to offer me an opportunity in the near future to prove you my sincere gratitude!

Now, I trust that you will direct a prompt and early commencing of the building - that is -as soon as the Contract will be awarded -

Believe me,

Yours very gratefully,

J. Poulet

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott,

With reference to the attached letter from the Valley City Seating Co. of Dundas, I beg to say that it has been customary in the past to purchase the pews for the Chapels from local mills in the locality where the School is being erected.

The Valley City Seating Co. manufacture exclusively this type of furniture, but it is of much better quality than we install in the schools.

If a building is being erected in Ontario there is no reason why this company should not be given an opportunity to figure.

Memorandum

The Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

With reference to your inquiry regarding plans and specifications for the tables, cupboards, etc., required for the Muscowequan School, I beg to say that plans and specifications for this equipment were prepared by Mr. William Swan, Architect of Punnichy, who is the Inspector of Construction on this work. Mr. Swan was instructed to consult with the Reverend Principal, prepare the plans and specifications for this portion of the equipment and obtain prices; the prices to be forwarded to the Department together with copies of the plans and specifications for consideration. When these were received here it was noted that some of the equipment was specified in oak. As it was considered that fir would serve the purpose and be more economical I requested that new prices be invited with this change. In preparing the specifications Mr. Swan was probably influenced by the Reverend Principal in specifying oak in place of fir.
March 6, 1931.

Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy

In reply to your memorandum of the 4th instant I beg to say that the tenderers on cupboards and fittings for the Muscowequan School at Lestock, Sask., have all been asked to revise their tenders and substitute Douglas fir for oak. Mr. William Swan, an Architect of Punnichy, is the Inspector of Construction at this school. He was previously the Inspector of Construction at the George Gordon's Church of England School. He is a highly competent man, and prepared the plans and specifications for the George Gordon School requirements, specifying that fir should be used. He was asked to prepare plans and specifications and to ask for tenders on cupboards and fittings for the Muscowequan School from firms approved by yourself. He did so and submitted the results. It was noticed by our Architect that he had specified oak instead of fir, which could not be approved by the Department.

MEMORANDUM

April 1, 1931.

MR. WILLIAMS,

The attention of the Minister has been drawn to the list of furnishings and supplies which it is proposed to provide for the new Muscowequan School. It is represented that the furnishings and supplies in the old school can be used to advantage in the new building, and that the list on which prices are being obtained by the Department, is altogether unnecessary.

The Minister would like a memorandum from you stating:

1st: At whose request the list was prepared?

2nd: If any check was made of the furnishings and supplies in the old school? A report presented as to what portion of these furnishings and supplies can be utilized in the new building.

3rd. What is the general practice of the Department in matters of this kind?

[Signature]

Private Secretary.
April 7, 1931.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Buskard,

Referring to your memorandum of the 1st instant with reference to the furnishing of the new Muscowequan Indian Residential School, I beg to quote from a memorandum addressed to the Honourable Superintendent General on December 22nd, as follows:—

"As for the general method employed in furnishing these residential schools, I may say that it has been the practice in the past to allow the Principal, after consulting with his staff, to submit to the Department a list of the furnishings required. When this list is received here it is carefully checked in order that the equipment will conform to that furnished other schools. It is necessary to disallow some of the items asked for, and in some cases to make additions. This list is then subdivided and forms of tender prepared and submitted to the different firms for prices. The names of the firms who are asked to quote are obtained from the Minister's Office. We have furnished all our schools under this system and it has been found to work well."

This procedure was followed in the case of the Muscowequan School, and when the Architect of the Department made an inspection of the new building last fall he instructed the Reverend Principal to forward to the Department a list of the furnishings required with detailed instructions as to how to prepare these lists. He was also instructed to forward a list of the equipment that could be transferred from the old building for use in the new. When these lists were received from the Principal there was attached a list of the usable equipment and this was taken into account when the forms of tender were being prepared.

C.S. Williams

MR. WILLIAMS,

Will you please refer to your memorandum of the 7th instant, with regard to the furnishings of the New Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

April 17th, 1931.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Thomas G. Murphy -

My attention has been drawn to the interchange of memoranda with reference to the furnishings for the new Muscowequan school. I do not think you were given the full facts so I desire to supplement them with further information.

The old Muscowequan school was built and owned by the Church authorities. The older portion was erected in 1895 and additions were made in 1909. The Department purchased the property and the buildings and contents from the Church in 1924. The only furnishings that were supplied by the Department were a few desks, a dough-mixer, a bake-oven and a few beds. It can be readily understood the condition this equipment was in after all these years of hard usage in an Indian residential school. I saw the equipment myself in 1928 when we were considering the question of rebuilding, and it was apparent to even casual inspection that the equipment was worn out. I am sending a list herewith of the articles transferred from the old to the new building, and you will observe that there was considerable salvage.

The old school accommodated 60 pupils and the new school provides for 110. The new and larger building necessitated additional furnishings. The list was prepared and checked with the greatest care, as usual; every article of furniture is shown in its place on the plan of the building.

Father Poulet, the Principal of the school, is a reasonable man and a good manager, and the Sisterhood of Nuns who look after the domestic part of the building are very economical and reasonable in their demands.

On Mar. 18, 1931, we shipped to the Muscowegnan Indian School, Lestock, Sask., one only Hydro Pneumatic Pressure Tank.

The order for this tank was placed with us by Mr. J.S. Tempest at that time, Commissioner of Irrigation, under his file No. 4882. No Sales Tax was charged on this tank, as we believe it was understood at that time, that tax was not applicable.

This year, however, during the visit to our plant of the Sales Tax Inspectors, we were assessed the Sales Tax on this item, amounting to $7.51 for which we enclose our invoice here-with, and which we would appreciate your passing for payment. Upon receipt of your remittance, we will in turn forward our cheque to the Dept. of National Revenue in settlement of same.

We also enclose for your information copy of the original invoice for this tank, to assist you in tracing this item.

Yours very truly,

DOMINION BRIDGE COMPANY LIMITED

[Signature]

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE,
W. REGINA, SASK., 20th December, 1933.

Dear Sir:

I am forwarding a letter herewith from the Dominion Bridge Company Limited, of Calgary, which was sent to Mr. Christianson in connection with the Pneumatic Pressure Tank supplied the Muscowequan Residential School on March 16th, 1931. It appears that the Sales Tax was not taken into consideration when submitting the voucher and the Company have since had to put up the amount of $75.51. It is a case of taking it out of one pocket and putting it in the other. I have looked through the files here and have no record of this tank. Possibly the voucher was issued through your office and no doubt certified to by Mr. Wm. Swan.

I would be glad if you would look into the matter and forward on the account with your recommendation, if you find that it is correct.

Yours truly,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir;-

I have the honor to enclose voucher for $7.51 in favor of the Dominion Bridge Co of Calgary, Alta.

As will be seen from the correspondence this is a charge for sales tax on the pressure tank supplied to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School. The tank was installed by the engineer of the Water Power Branch who was looking after the water supply to this place, and I did not have anything to do with the vouchers at that time. However, as someone has to O.K. the voucher if the Department agrees to pay the charge I have signed for it. Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, January 8, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, enclosing voucher for $7.51 in favour of the Dominion Bridge Company, Calgary.

When this firm quoted on the pressure tank for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, they stated that their price included sales tax. Under these circumstances, the voucher is not being paid.

However, it will not be necessary for you to take any further action in the matter, as the Department is communicating with Mr. Inspector Christianson and asking him to advise the Dominion Bridge Company.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.
Ottawa, January 5, 1934.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the Dominion Bridge Company's letter of the 15th ultimo addressed to you, requesting payment of $7.51 for sales tax on a pressure tank supplied by them to the Muscowequan Indian Residential School in March of 1931.

This pressure tank was installed under the supervision of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau. The quotation of the Dominion Bridge Company, in letter dated December 30th, 1930, was addressed to Mr. J. S. Tempest, the Calgary Agent of the Dominion Water Power Bureau. This letter, which is on file in the Department, reads, in part, as follows:

"With reference to your enquiry of the 26th, we are pleased to quote the sum of eight hundred and sixty-six dollars ($866.00) F.O.B. cars, Lestock, Sask., sales tax included, for one tank, designed to your specifications and including all fittings you specify."

You will note that the quoted price of $866.00 included sales tax, and a cheque for $866.00 was issued in favour of the Dominion Bridge Company in March of 1931.

In view of the above quotation, the Department is not prepared to pay the $7.51 sales tax now requested by the Dominion Bridge Company. Please inform them accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

Winnipeg, Jan. 26, 1934.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sirs:—

Attention Purchasing Agent.

Re: Mosowequan Indian Residential School, Lestock, Sask.

We quoted you on August 28th on a new 26" Solid Curb Extractor, Motor Driven, 110 volts, D.C. a price of $960.00 f.o.b. Lestock, Sask., and are wondering if anything has been done regarding this machine.

We have recently acquired some reconditioned machinery and it may be that we could supply you with an Extractor to be driven by a motor, which motor would be set on the floor. This would certainly give the Indian School at Lestock proper extraction capacity, and you would save money, in fact we have several Extractors hooked up this way and they are all working most satisfactorily.

We have several 26" Extractors which we would rebuild and completely guarantee, and would appreciate very much hearing as to whether you would be interested in this proposition.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

STANLEY BROCK LIMITED.

Dear Sir:

In reference to report of the visit I made to Muscowequan School last month I beg to state that the principal drew certain matters to my attention, he asks for consideration of the following requests.

The supply of three large fire extinguishers for use in the barns of the school.

A large pump to be used to empty the septic tank, there is no pump at the school for this purpose.

Plank flooring for repairs in the horse stable, the cost would be $25.00.

He also asks that the Department consider the construction at this school of a small warehouse about like a garage, made of galvanized iron with a cement floor, for purposes of storing flour, and he asks me to remind the Department of the necessity of a laundry here. The extractor supplied is in use and is working very well.

The timing gears of the Lister lighting plant were wearing out and liable to put the plant out of commission, I told him to get it fixed before more trouble develops.

Will you please send me the circular regards supply of refills for fire extinguishers, I cannot find the old instructions here but remember they were issued some years ago.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
